description:
# [EPIC] Reliability Hardening

## Mission
Make wa **resilient to failures** at every level—external services, internal components, and edge cases.

## Why This Matters
wa controls terminal interactions. Failures must be handled gracefully:
- Browser automation fails → do not spam retries
- WezTerm CLI hangs → do not block forever
- DB corrupts → continue observing, degrade gracefully

Reliability is a trust multiplier. Users need confidence that wa will not make things worse when something goes wrong.

## Components

### 1. Circuit Breaker Pattern
Stop hammering failed services:
```
Service: browser_auth
Status: OPEN (tripped 3 failures)
Last failure: 2026-01-18T14:32:01 (timeout)
Retry after: 2026-01-18T14:37:01 (5 min cooldown)
```

Circuit breakers for:
- Browser automation (auth flows)
- `caut` CLI wrapper
- WezTerm CLI (if consistently failing)
- External webhooks

### 2. Watchdog/Heartbeat System
Monitor wa's own health:
- Heartbeat thread checks main loop liveness
- Deadlock detection (no progress for N seconds)
- Auto-restart on unrecoverable hang
- Crash report with diagnostic context

### 3. Chaos Testing Harness
Inject failures to prove resilience:
- Kill WezTerm mid-capture
- Corrupt DB file
- Simulate network timeouts
- Exhaust disk space
- Fill queues to capacity

Chaos tests validate:
- Data integrity after failures
- Graceful degradation behavior
- Recovery procedures work

### 4. Retry with Exponential Backoff
Standardized retry policy:
- Initial: 100ms
- Max: 30s
- Backoff factor: 2x
- Jitter: ±10%
- Max attempts: configurable

Applied to:
- WezTerm CLI calls
- DB writes (transient lock conflicts)
- External service calls

### 5. Graceful Degradation Modes
When components fail, continue with reduced functionality:
- DB read-only → continue observing, queue writes
- Pattern engine error → skip detection, keep ingesting
- Workflow failure → pause workflow, keep observing
- WezTerm CLI unavailable → retry with backoff, surface status

## Observability
All reliability mechanisms emit structured logs:
- Circuit state changes
- Retry attempts and outcomes
- Degradation mode transitions
- Watchdog warnings

## Testing
- Unit tests: Circuit breaker state machine
- Integration tests: Retry behavior under failure injection
- Chaos tests: System survives failure scenarios
- Load tests: Behavior under resource exhaustion

## Success Criteria
- Circuit breakers prevent retry storms
- Watchdog detects and recovers from hangs
- Chaos tests pass for critical failure scenarios
- Graceful degradation maintains core observability

## Acceptance Criteria
- Circuit breakers, retries, and watchdogs prevent runaway failures.
- Graceful degradation keeps core commands usable.
- Chaos harness runs without crashes and produces actionable logs.

title: Circuit breaker infrastructure: state machine, cooldowns, and status reporting
description:
# Circuit Breaker Infrastructure

## Purpose
Implement a generic circuit breaker pattern to prevent retry storms when services fail.

## State Machine
```
     failures < threshold
CLOSED ◄────────────────────────► OPEN
  │                                  │
  │ failure >= threshold             │ cooldown elapsed
  └──────────────────►               ▼
                              HALF-OPEN
                                  │
                    success → CLOSED
                    failure → OPEN
```

## Implementation
```rust
pub struct CircuitBreaker {
    name: String,
    state: CircuitState,
    failure_count: u32,
    failure_threshold: u32,
    cooldown: Duration,
    last_failure: Option<Instant>,
}

impl CircuitBreaker {
    pub fn call<T>(&self, f: impl FnOnce() -> Result<T>) -> Result<T, CircuitError>;
    pub fn record_success(&mut self);
    pub fn record_failure(&mut self, error: &Error);
    pub fn status(&self) -> CircuitStatus;
}
```

## Circuit Breakers to Implement
- browser_auth: For Playwright auth flows
- caut_cli: For account usage queries
- wezterm_cli: For pane operations
- webhook: For notification delivery

## Status Reporting
```
$ wa doctor --circuits

Circuit Breaker Status:
  browser_auth: CLOSED (healthy)
  caut_cli:     OPEN (3 failures, retry in 4m32s)
  wezterm_cli:  CLOSED (healthy)
  webhook:      HALF-OPEN (testing...)
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] CircuitBreaker struct with state machine
- [ ] Configurable thresholds and cooldowns
- [ ] Status visible in wa doctor
- [ ] Structured logging on state changes

## Testing
- Unit tests for breaker/backoff logic and state transitions.
- Integration tests simulating IO failures and recovery paths.
- Chaos harness scenarios with verbose logs and recovery assertions.

description:
# Watchdog/Heartbeat System

## Purpose
Monitor wa's own health and recover from hangs or deadlocks.

## How It Works
1. Main loop updates heartbeat timestamp each iteration
2. Watchdog thread checks heartbeat every N seconds
3. If heartbeat stale > threshold, trigger recovery

## Implementation
```rust
pub struct Watchdog {
    heartbeat: Arc<AtomicU64>,  // Unix timestamp
    stale_threshold: Duration,
    recovery_action: RecoveryAction,
}

pub enum RecoveryAction {
    LogWarning,
    DumpDiagnostics,
    ForceRestart,
}
```

## Recovery Sequence
1. Log warning with stack traces
2. Dump diagnostic state (queue depths, lock holders)
3. If still stale after N seconds: force restart
4. Generate crash report with diagnostics

## Diagnostic Dump
When watchdog triggers:
- Thread states
- Queue depths
- Lock holder info (if available)
- Recent event log
- Memory usage

## Status Reporting
```
$ wa status --health

Watchdog:
  Main loop: healthy (last heartbeat 0.1s ago)
  DB writer: healthy (queue: 3 items)
  Ingest: healthy (lag: 15ms)
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Heartbeat updated each main loop iteration
- [ ] Watchdog thread monitors heartbeat
- [ ] Recovery actions trigger at configurable threshold
- [ ] Diagnostic dump provides useful context
- [ ] Crash report generated on force restart

## Testing
- Unit tests for breaker/backoff logic and state transitions.
- Integration tests simulating IO failures and recovery paths.
- Chaos harness scenarios with verbose logs and recovery assertions.

title: Retry with exponential backoff: standardized retry policy across all I/O
description:
# Retry with Exponential Backoff

## Purpose
Provide a consistent, well-tuned retry mechanism for all fallible operations.

## Retry Policy
```rust
pub struct RetryPolicy {
    pub initial_delay: Duration,    // 100ms default
    pub max_delay: Duration,        // 30s default
    pub backoff_factor: f64,        // 2.0 default
    pub jitter_percent: f64,        // 10% default
    pub max_attempts: Option<u32>,  // None = infinite
}

pub async fn with_retry<T>(
    policy: &RetryPolicy,
    operation: impl AsyncFn() -> Result<T>,
) -> Result<T>;
```

## Jitter Formula
```
delay = base_delay * jitter_factor
jitter_factor = 1.0 + random(-jitter_percent, +jitter_percent)
```

## Application Points
- WezTerm CLI calls: 3 attempts, 100ms initial
- DB writes: 5 attempts, 50ms initial
- Webhook delivery: 5 attempts, 1s initial
- Browser actions: 2 attempts, 500ms initial

## Logging
Each retry logged with:
- Attempt number
- Delay applied
- Error that triggered retry

## Integration with Circuit Breaker
- Retries happen within circuit breaker
- Exceeded retries count as circuit failure
- Circuit OPEN prevents retry attempts

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] RetryPolicy struct with configurable parameters
- [ ] with_retry helper function
- [ ] Jitter implemented correctly
- [ ] All I/O points use retry policy
- [ ] Logging shows retry attempts

## Testing
- Unit tests for breaker/backoff logic and state transitions.
- Integration tests simulating IO failures and recovery paths.
- Chaos harness scenarios with verbose logs and recovery assertions.

title: Graceful degradation modes: continue operating with reduced functionality
description:
# Graceful Degradation Modes

## Purpose
When components fail, continue operating with reduced functionality rather than crashing.

## Degradation Scenarios

### 1. DB Read-Only Mode
**Trigger**: DB write failures (corruption, disk full)
**Behavior**:
- Continue observing panes
- Queue writes in memory (bounded)
- Log warning about degraded mode
- Resume normal operation when DB recovers

### 2. Pattern Engine Failure
**Trigger**: Pattern compilation error, regex timeout
**Behavior**:
- Skip pattern detection
- Continue ingesting output
- Log which patterns are disabled
- Partial detection if some patterns work

### 3. Workflow Engine Pause
**Trigger**: Workflow step fails repeatedly
**Behavior**:
- Pause the failing workflow
- Continue other workflows
- Keep observing for new events
- Notify user of paused workflow

### 4. WezTerm Unavailable
**Trigger**: CLI consistently fails
**Behavior**:
- Stop action attempts
- Continue any cached observation
- Poll for WezTerm availability
- Resume automatically when available

## Status Reporting
```
$ wa status

System Status: DEGRADED

Active Degradations:
  ⚠ DB writes queued (disk full) - 47 pending
  ⚠ Workflow paused: handle_usage_limits (step 3 failed)

Core Functions:
  ✓ Observation: active
  ✓ Detection: active
  ✗ Actions: degraded
```

## Recovery
- Automatic: Poll for recovery conditions
- Manual: `wa recover <component>` to retry

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Each degradation mode implemented

title: [EPIC] Performance Optimizations: Lazy Loading, Caching, Pooling
description:
# [EPIC] Performance Optimizations

## Mission
Make wa **fast and efficient** without sacrificing safety or correctness.

## Why This Matters
wa runs continuously in the background. Performance impacts:
- CPU usage (battery life on laptops)
- Memory footprint
- Latency of operations
- Scalability to many panes

Optimizations must be:
- Measurable (benchmarks prove value)
- Safe (no correctness regressions)
- Conditional (only apply when beneficial)

## Components

### 1. Lazy Pattern Compilation
Do not compile regex/Aho-Corasick engines until first use:
```rust
static PATTERN_ENGINE: Lazy<PatternEngine> = Lazy::new(|| {
    PatternEngine::compile(load_packs())
});
```

Benefits:
- Faster startup time
- Memory saved if patterns not used
- Hot-reload ready

### 2. Bloom Filter Pre-Filter
Before running Aho-Corasick, check Bloom filter:
```rust
if !bloom_filter.possibly_contains(&text) {
    return vec![]; // Quick reject
}
// Only then run full pattern matching
```

Budget: < 1µs for Bloom check

### 3. Connection Pooling for WezTerm CLI
Keep warm connections to WezTerm mux server:
```rust
struct WezTermPool {
    connections: Vec<MuxConnection>,
    max_size: usize,
}
```

Benefits:
- Avoid process spawn overhead
- Reduce socket churn
- Enable connection reuse

Note: Only beneficial if vendored mode or mux protocol direct access.

### 4. Memory-Efficient Output Cache
Already exists as `wa-4vx.4.12` - enhance with:
- LRU eviction by memory pressure
- Rolling hash for dedup detection
- Configurable cache size limits

### 5. Background Segment Compression
Already gated by `wa-4vx.3.11` decision - if needed:
- Compress segments older than N days
- Use zstd for good ratio and speed
- Transparent decompression on read
- Background compaction thread

### 6. Incremental FTS Sync
Ensure FTS index only processes new content:
- Track last-indexed segment per pane
- Batch index updates
- Avoid full reindex on restart

## Benchmarks
All optimizations must be validated by Criterion benchmarks:
- Baseline before optimization
- Result after optimization
- Regression tests to prevent backsliding

## Testing
- Benchmark suite for each optimization
- Memory profiling under sustained load
- No correctness regressions (same outputs)

## Success Criteria
- Startup time < 100ms (no feature flags)
- Pattern quick-reject < 1µs for non-matching text
- Memory usage < 100MB for typical workload
- CPU usage < 5% when idle

## Acceptance Criteria
- Each optimization yields measurable latency or memory improvement.
- Performance budgets are enforced in CI.
- Regression thresholds and baselines are documented.

title: Lazy pattern compilation: defer engine initialization until first use
description:
# Lazy Pattern Compilation

## Purpose
Defer compilation of pattern matching engines until they're actually needed, improving startup time.

## Current Behavior
PatternEngine compiles all patterns at startup, even if pattern matching isn't used in this run.

## Proposed Behavior
```rust
use once_cell::sync::Lazy;

static PATTERN_ENGINE: Lazy<PatternEngine> = Lazy::new(|| {
    tracing::debug\!("Compiling pattern engine (first use)");
    PatternEngine::compile(load_packs())
});
```

## Benefits
- Faster startup for non-watch commands
- Memory saved if patterns not used
- Enables future hot-reload capability

## Benchmark Targets
- Startup time: reduce by ~50-100ms (depends on pattern count)
- First pattern match: may have one-time ~100ms delay
- Overall: net positive for typical usage

## Implementation Notes
- Use `once_cell::sync::Lazy` for thread-safe lazy init
- Ensure compile errors surface correctly
- Consider warming on `wa watch` start

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Pattern engine compiled lazily
- [ ] Commands that don't use patterns are faster
- [ ] First pattern match latency acceptable
- [ ] Benchmark proves improvement

## Testing
- Criterion benchmarks with budgets and baseline comparison.
- Microbenchmarks for the specific optimization.
- CI regression guard with perf logs.

title: Bloom filter pre-filter: quick reject non-matching text before regex
description:
# Bloom Filter Pre-Filter

## Purpose
Use a Bloom filter to quickly reject text that definitely doesn't match any pattern, avoiding expensive regex evaluation.

## How It Works
1. Build Bloom filter from all pattern keywords
2. For each incoming text segment:
   a. Hash key substrings through Bloom filter
   b. If Bloom returns "definitely not present" → skip
   c. Only if Bloom says "possibly present" → run full patterns

## Implementation
```rust
use bloomfilter::Bloom;

pub struct PatternEngine {
    bloom: Bloom<str>,          // Quick reject filter
    aho_corasick: AhoCorasick,  // Actual pattern matcher
}

impl PatternEngine {
    pub fn matches(&self, text: &str) -> Vec<Match> {
        // Quick reject: < 1µs
        if !self.bloom_possibly_contains(text) {
            return vec![];
        }
        // Full match: ~10-100µs
        self.aho_corasick_match(text)
    }
}
```

## Bloom Filter Parameters
- Size: ~10KB for 1000 patterns
- False positive rate: ~1%
- Hash functions: 3

## Benchmark Targets
- Bloom check: < 1µs
- Typical text (no matches): ~1µs total
- Text with matches: ~10-100µs (unchanged)
- 90%+ of segments rejected by Bloom

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Bloom filter built from pattern keywords
- [ ] Quick reject path < 1µs
- [ ] False positive rate verified < 5%
- [ ] Benchmark shows improvement for non-matching text

## Testing
- Criterion benchmarks with budgets and baseline comparison.
- Microbenchmarks for the specific optimization.
- CI regression guard with perf logs.

title: Connection pooling for WezTerm: reuse mux connections when available
description:
# Connection Pooling for WezTerm

## Purpose
Reduce overhead of WezTerm CLI calls by pooling connections to the mux server.

## Current Behavior
Each WezTerm CLI call spawns a new process, connects to mux, executes, and disconnects.

## Proposed Behavior
When using vendored mode (direct mux protocol):
```rust
pub struct WezTermPool {
    connections: Vec<MuxConnection>,
    max_size: usize,
    idle_timeout: Duration,
}

impl WezTermPool {
    pub async fn execute<T>(&self, cmd: MuxCommand) -> Result<T> {
        let conn = self.acquire().await?;
        let result = conn.execute(cmd).await;
        self.release(conn);
        result
    }
}
```

## Benefits
- Avoid process spawn overhead (~10ms per call)
- Reduce socket churn
- Enable connection keepalive
- Batch multiple operations efficiently

## Prerequisites
- Requires vendored mode (wa-nu4.4.1)
- Direct mux protocol access

## Fallback
CLI mode: No pooling possible, but can batch commands.

## Benchmark Targets
- With pooling: ~1ms per operation
- Without pooling: ~10-20ms per operation
- 10x improvement for high-frequency operations

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Connection pool implemented for vendored mode
- [ ] Idle connection cleanup
- [ ] Graceful fallback for CLI mode
- [ ] Benchmark proves improvement

## Testing
- Criterion benchmarks with budgets and baseline comparison.
- Microbenchmarks for the specific optimization.
- CI regression guard with perf logs.

title: Incremental FTS sync: avoid full reindex, track per-pane progress
description:
# Incremental FTS Sync

## Purpose
Ensure FTS index only processes new content, avoiding expensive full reindex operations.

## Current Challenge
On restart, wa might need to determine what's already indexed and what's new.

## Solution
```rust
pub struct FtsIndexState {
    /// Last indexed segment seq per pane
    per_pane_progress: HashMap<PaneId, SegmentSeq>,
    /// Global index version for schema changes
    index_version: u32,
}
```

## Sync Process
1. On startup: Load `per_pane_progress` from DB
2. For each pane: Query segments where `seq > last_indexed_seq`
3. Index only new segments
4. Update progress after successful batch

## Batching Strategy
- Batch size: 100 segments or 1MB text
- Commit progress after each batch
- Resume from last batch on crash

## Performance Impact
- Full reindex: O(total segments)
- Incremental: O(new segments)
- Startup overhead: O(1) - just load progress

## Recovery
If index corrupt or schema changed:
- Detect via `index_version` mismatch
- Trigger full rebuild
- Show progress indicator

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Per-pane progress tracked in DB
- [ ] Only new segments indexed on restart
- [ ] Batch processing with progress commits
- [ ] Full rebuild triggered on version mismatch
- [ ] Benchmark shows startup improvement

## Testing
- Criterion benchmarks with budgets and baseline comparison.
- Microbenchmarks for the specific optimization.
- CI regression guard with perf logs.

title: Performance benchmarks and budgets: Criterion suite with regression guards
description:
# Performance benchmarks and budgets (Criterion)

## Goal
Establish benchmarks for all performance-critical paths and prevent regressions with explicit, documented budgets.

This system sits on the hot path of “every command the user runs” (watch loop, pattern matching, policy checks). Performance regressions are user-visible.

## Benchmark suite (Criterion)
Benchmarks must target *real* hot paths and be runnable locally:

```rust
// benches/pattern_engine.rs
criterion_group!(
    pattern_benchmarks,
    bench_bloom_check,
    bench_aho_corasick_match,
    bench_full_pattern_pipeline,
);

// benches/ingest.rs
criterion_group!(
    ingest_benchmarks,
    bench_delta_extraction,
    bench_segment_persistence,
    bench_fts_indexing,
);
```

## What we benchmark (minimum set)
- Quick reject / prefilter:
  - `memchr`/bloom/no-match fast paths
  - worst-case “near match but reject” path
- Pattern pipeline:
  - no-hit text (must be very fast)
  - one-hit typical text
  - extraction path with captures
- Ingest/deltas:
  - delta extraction on typical scrollback
  - gap detection path
- Storage:
  - write queue throughput (bounded queue)
  - FTS indexing cost for typical segment sizes
- Query surfaces:
  - typical FTS query latency (scoped)
  - worst-case query guardrails (bounded)

## Performance budgets (absolute ceilings)
Budgets are set as “this must feel snappy to users” ceilings. Exact numbers may be tuned after first implementation, but budgets must exist before optimization work is called done.

| Operation | Budget (target ceiling) | Notes |
|-----------|--------------------------|-------|
| Bloom filter check | < 1µs | hot path prefilter |
| Pattern match (no hit) | < 10µs | must be cheap for most text |
| Pattern match (with hit) | < 100µs | includes extraction |
| Delta extraction | < 1ms | per pane per tick typical |
| FTS insert (single) | < 5ms | typical segment size |
| FTS query (typical) | < 50ms | scoped query; “feels instant” |
| Startup (no patterns) | < 100ms | CLI responsiveness |

## Regression detection strategy (CI realities)
Perf measurement is noisy on shared runners. The plan must be robust:

- Local dev loop:
  - `cargo bench` is the source of truth for tuning.
  - Provide a short “budget check” summary line per benchmark so developers can self-serve.

- CI loop (two-tier):
  1) **PR job (warn-only by default)**
     - Run benches and upload `criterion` output + a short summary artifact.
     - Fail only on catastrophic regressions (e.g., >2x slower OR exceeding a hard ceiling by a large margin).
  2) **Main/perf job (enforce budgets)**
     - Prefer a stable environment (self-hosted runner if available).
     - Enforce budgets strictly and record historical trend artifacts.

- Baselines:
  - Store a baseline artifact from main (or a tagged commit) and compare PR results against it.
  - Comparisons must ignore obviously-noisy fields and focus on timing deltas.

## Reporting
Example (desired UX):
```
$ cargo bench --bench pattern_engine

bloom_check         time:   [0.8 µs 0.9 µs 1.0 µs]  ✓ (budget: 1µs)
aho_corasick_match  time:   [8.2 µs 8.5 µs 8.8 µs]  ✓ (budget: 10µs)
full_pipeline       time:   [45 µs 48 µs 51 µs]     ✓ (budget: 100µs)
```

On regression, the report must include:
- which benchmark regressed
- old vs new timings
- which budget was exceeded (if any)
- where to find the artifacts (CI URL/path)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Criterion benchmarks exist for the minimum hot paths listed above.
- [ ] Budgets are documented and checked by an automated “budget check” step.
- [ ] CI produces artifacts for every run (raw criterion + summarized results).
- [ ] CI regression detection works (warn-only on PR; enforced on stable perf job).

## Testing
- Benchmark harness self-checks:
  - benches compile and run on supported platforms.
  - the budget-checking logic is covered by unit tests (parsing/threshold evaluation).
- CI regression guard tests:
  - include a small synthetic “known regression” fixture in test mode to verify:
    - the budget checker fails when it should
    - output includes the expected summary fields

title: [Human command] `wa backup export` (database + config archive with checksum)
description:
# Task: wa backup export

## Goal
Create portable backup archives that users can store, copy, and restore from.

## Command Design
```bash
# Basic export
$ wa backup export
Backup saved: ~/.local/share/wa/backups/wa_backup_2026-01-18_143015.wa

# Custom output
$ wa backup export --output /path/to/backup.wa

# With compression
$ wa backup export --compress

# Include specific workspaces only
$ wa backup export --workspace /project/a --workspace /project/b

# Exclude large transcript data (config/events only)
$ wa backup export --metadata-only
```

## Output Format
Archive structure (tar + optional zstd):
```
backup.wa/
├── manifest.json      # Version, timestamp, checksums
├── schema_version     # Plain text: "3"
├── database.sql       # SQLite dump
├── config.toml        # Effective configuration
├── patterns/          # Custom pattern packs
│   └── custom.toml
└── checksums.sha256   # Per-file checksums
```

manifest.json:
```json
{
  "wa_version": "0.1.0",
  "schema_version": 3,
  "created_at": "2026-01-18T14:30:15Z",
  "workspaces": ["/project/a", "/project/b"],
  "stats": {
    "segments": 12345,
    "events": 567,
    "panes": 8
  },
  "checksum": "sha256:abc123..."
}
```

## Implementation Notes
- Use SQLite `.dump` for portability
- Acquire read lock during export (snapshot isolation)
- Stream large exports to avoid memory issues
- Verify checksum immediately after write

## Testing
- Unit tests: archive format validation, manifest generation
- Integration: export with active watcher, verify no corruption
- E2E: export + import round-trip preserves all data

## Acceptance Criteria
- Export creates valid, portable archive
- Checksum included and verified on write
- Progress shown for large databases
- Metadata-only mode for quick config backup

title: Multi-account exhaustion handling: all accounts at limit → graceful degradation
description:
# Multi-account exhaustion handling

## Purpose
Handle the scenario where ALL configured accounts have reached their usage limits simultaneously.

## Problem
Current usage limit workflow assumes at least one account is available for failover.
When all accounts are exhausted, we need graceful degradation:
1. Don't attempt impossible failovers
2. Provide clear status to user
3. Schedule auto-resume at earliest reset time
4. Support notification of this critical state

## Detection
```rust
// In account selection logic
let available = accounts.iter()
    .filter(|a| a.percent_remaining > 0.0 || a.reset_time < now)
    .collect::<Vec<_>>();

if available.is_empty() {
    return Err(AccountExhausted {
        next_reset: accounts.iter()
            .map(|a| a.reset_time)
            .min(),
        accounts_checked: accounts.len(),
    });
}
```

## Workflow Behavior
When `AccountExhausted` detected:

### Step 1: Capture state
- Save current session transcript
- Record in-progress task (if determinable)
- Log which accounts were checked

### Step 2: Calculate resume time
```rust
let earliest_reset = accounts.iter()
    .filter_map(|a| a.reset_time)
    .min();
```

### Step 3: Persist "awaiting reset" state
```sql
INSERT INTO workflow_paused 
(pane_id, reason, resume_at, state_snapshot)
VALUES (?, 'all_accounts_exhausted', ?, ?);
```

### Step 4: Notify user
```
🔴 All accounts exhausted

All 3 configured OpenAI accounts have reached their usage limits.

Next reset: account-2 @ 2026-01-19 00:00 UTC (6h 23m)

Options:
  1. Wait for reset (wa will auto-resume if enabled)
  2. Add new account: wa accounts add
  3. Continue manually in exhausted account (with limits)

Status: wa accounts status
Resume: wa workflow resume --when-available
```

### Step 5: Schedule resume (optional)
If auto-resume enabled:
- Create timer/cron for earliest reset time
- Resume workflow when triggered

## Configuration
```toml
[accounts.exhaustion]
notify_channels = ["desktop", "webhook"]
auto_resume_on_reset = true
save_transcript = true
```

## Robot Mode Error
```json
{
  "ok": false,
  "error": {
    "code": "E_ALL_ACCOUNTS_EXHAUSTED",
    "message": "All configured accounts have reached usage limits",
    "data": {
      "accounts_checked": 3,
      "next_reset": "2026-01-19T00:00:00Z",
      "next_reset_account": "account-2"
    }
  }
}
```

## Testing
- Unit: Account selection returns exhaustion error correctly
- Unit: Resume time calculation
- Integration: Workflow pauses correctly
- E2E: Full exhaustion → notification → resume flow

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Exhaustion detected when all accounts at limit
- [ ] Clear user notification with reset times
- [ ] State preserved for resume
- [ ] Auto-resume works when enabled
- [ ] Robot mode returns structured error

title: E2E CI integration: GitHub Actions workflow with artifact collection
description:
# E2E CI Integration: GitHub Actions workflow with artifact collection

## Purpose
Run E2E tests in CI with detailed logging and artifact preservation.

## Implementation

### GitHub Actions Workflow
```yaml
# .github/workflows/e2e.yml
name: E2E Tests

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]

env:
  CARGO_TERM_COLOR: always
  E2E_LOG_LEVEL: debug
  E2E_TIMEOUT: 300

jobs:
  e2e-tests:
    name: E2E Test Suite
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    timeout-minutes: 30

    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Install Rust
        uses: dtolnay/rust-toolchain@stable

      - name: Cache cargo
        uses: Swatinem/rust-cache@v2

      - name: Install WezTerm
        run: |
          curl -fsSL https://apt.fury.io/wez/gpg.key | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /etc/apt/keyrings/wezterm-fury.gpg
          echo 'deb [signed-by=/etc/apt/keyrings/wezterm-fury.gpg] https://apt.fury.io/wez/ * *' | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/wezterm.list
          sudo apt update
          sudo apt install -y wezterm

      - name: Build wa (release)
        run: cargo build --release

      - name: Create logs directory
        run: mkdir -p tests/e2e/logs

      - name: Run E2E tests
        run: |
          echo "Starting E2E test suite..."
          cargo test --test e2e -- --test-threads=1 --nocapture 2>&1 | tee tests/e2e/logs/test_output.log
        env:
          RUST_BACKTRACE: 1
          WA_BIN: target/release/wa

      - name: Upload test logs
        if: always()
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: e2e-logs-${{ github.run_id }}
          path: |
            tests/e2e/logs/
            target/release/wa
          retention-days: 7

      - name: Upload coverage (if available)
        if: success()
        uses: codecov/codecov-action@v4
        with:
          files: ./coverage.json
          fail_ci_if_error: false
```

### Test Runner Script
```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# tests/e2e/scripts/run_all.sh
set -euo pipefail

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
PROJECT_ROOT="$(cd "$SCRIPT_DIR/../../.." && pwd)"
LOG_DIR="$PROJECT_ROOT/tests/e2e/logs"

# Colors
RED='\033[0;31m'
GREEN='\033[0;32m'
YELLOW='\033[1;33m'
NC='\033[0m'

log() { echo -e "[$(date +%H:%M:%S)] $*"; }
log_ok() { log "${GREEN}✓${NC} $*"; }
log_err() { log "${RED}✗${NC} $*"; }
log_warn() { log "${YELLOW}!${NC} $*"; }

# Setup
mkdir -p "$LOG_DIR"
TIMESTAMP=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)
MAIN_LOG="$LOG_DIR/e2e_run_$TIMESTAMP.log"

log "E2E Test Suite starting..."
log "Logs will be written to: $LOG_DIR"

# Pre-flight checks
log "Running pre-flight checks..."

if ! command -v wezterm &> /dev/null; then
    log_err "WezTerm not found. Install it first."
    exit 1
fi
log_ok "WezTerm found: $(wezterm --version)"

if [[ ! -f "$PROJECT_ROOT/target/release/wa" ]]; then
    log_warn "wa binary not found. Building..."
    cargo build --release
fi
log_ok "wa binary found"

# Run tests
log "Running E2E tests..."
FAILED=0
PASSED=0

for test_file in "$PROJECT_ROOT"/tests/e2e/scenarios/*.rs; do
    test_name=$(basename "$test_file" .rs)
    log "Running: $test_name"

    if cargo test --test "e2e_$test_name" -- --nocapture >> "$MAIN_LOG" 2>&1; then
        log_ok "$test_name passed"
        ((PASSED++))
    else
        log_err "$test_name failed (see $MAIN_LOG)"
        ((FAILED++))
    fi
done

# Summary
log ""
log "========================================="
log "E2E Test Summary"
log "========================================="
log "Passed: $PASSED"
log "Failed: $FAILED"
log "Logs: $LOG_DIR"
log "========================================="

if [[ $FAILED -gt 0 ]]; then
    log_err "Some tests failed!"
    exit 1
fi

log_ok "All E2E tests passed!"
```

### Log Aggregation
```bash
# tests/e2e/scripts/aggregate_logs.sh
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# Combine all test logs into a single report

LOG_DIR="${1:-tests/e2e/logs}"
OUTPUT="$LOG_DIR/combined_report.md"

echo "# E2E Test Report" > "$OUTPUT"
echo "Generated: $(date)" >> "$OUTPUT"
echo "" >> "$OUTPUT"

for log_file in "$LOG_DIR"/*.log; do
    test_name=$(basename "$log_file" .log)
    echo "## $test_name" >> "$OUTPUT"
    echo '```' >> "$OUTPUT"
    tail -100 "$log_file" >> "$OUTPUT"
    echo '```' >> "$OUTPUT"
    echo "" >> "$OUTPUT"
done

echo "Report generated: $OUTPUT"
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] GitHub Actions workflow runs on PR and push
- [ ] WezTerm installed in CI environment
- [ ] All test logs uploaded as artifacts
- [ ] Test failures clearly reported
- [ ] Run time < 15 minutes

## Testing
- CI self-check: workflow runs the E2E suite and produces artifacts on both success and failure.
- Artifact validation: assert that log files and the main summary report are uploaded.
- Time budget: CI job enforces max runtime and fails with a clear message if exceeded.

title: [EPIC] Phase 1: Foundation - Core Infrastructure
description:
# Phase 1: Foundation - Core Infrastructure

## Overview
This epic covers the foundational infrastructure for WezTerm Automata (wa), establishing the core capabilities needed before any higher-level features can be built. This is the critical path - nothing else can proceed until these components exist.

## Strategic Importance
The foundation phase establishes the architectural patterns and core abstractions that ALL other code will depend on. Mistakes here propagate everywhere. We must:
- Get the WezTerm client abstraction right (it's the I/O layer for everything)
- Design storage schema carefully (migrations are painful)
- Build the pattern engine for extensibility (we'll add many patterns over time)
- Create the watcher with proper delta extraction (performance-critical hot path)

## Key Components

### 1. Cargo Workspace Setup
- wa (main binary)
- wa-core (library crate)
- wa-browser (browser automation, optional feature)
- wa-mcp (MCP server, optional feature)

### 2. WezTerm CLI Client Wrapper
- Thin wrapper around \`wezterm cli\` commands
- list-clients, list-panes (ListPaneResponse parsing)
- get-text (GetTextResponse with coordinates)
- send-text (with or without paste-mode)
- spawn (create panes in specific domains)
- Abstraction layer for future vendoring

### 3. SQLite Storage with FTS5
- Schema: domains, panes, captures, captures_fts, events, agent_sessions, workflow_runs, accounts, config
- Delta-first storage (append chunks, not full pane content)
- Gap detection and tracking
- FTS5 for full-text search of all captured output

### 4. Basic Pattern Engine
- Aho-Corasick for literal patterns (O(n) multi-pattern matching)
- Quick reject with memchr (eliminate 99%+ of text before regex)
- Pattern packs: core.codex, core.claude_code, core.gemini
- Extraction via named capture groups

### 5. Watcher Daemon
- Adaptive polling (faster when active, slower when idle)
- Delta extraction algorithm (overlap matching for reliable diff)
- Event emission on pattern detection
- Per-pane state tracking

### 6. Basic Robot Mode
- wa robot state - Get all panes as JSON
- wa robot get-text <pane_id> - Read pane output
- wa robot send <pane_id> "<text>" - Send input to pane
- JSON envelope with ok/data/error/hint/elapsed_ms

## Success Criteria
- [ ] \`wa watch\` runs and captures pane output continuously
- [ ] \`wa robot state\` returns JSON list of all panes
- [ ] \`wa robot get-text <id>\` returns pane content
- [ ] \`wa robot send <id> "test"\` sends text to pane
- [ ] FTS search finds text in captured output
- [ ] Pattern engine detects compaction, usage limits for at least one agent
- [ ] Tests pass, clippy clean, formatted

## Technical Decisions

### Why SQLite?
- Zero-config deployment
- Excellent FTS5 for search
- WAL mode for concurrent access
- Single-file portability

### Why Aho-Corasick + Regex?
- Aho-Corasick: O(n) for matching multiple patterns simultaneously
- Quick Reject: Eliminates 99%+ of text before regex
- Regex for extraction: Named captures for structured data

### Why adaptive polling vs push?
- WezTerm CLI doesn't support push notifications
- Adaptive polling balances responsiveness vs CPU
- Future vendoring may enable true event subscription

## Dependencies
- This epic has NO dependencies (it's the foundation)
- ALL other epics depend on this one

## Estimated Scope
- Foundation for everything else
- Must be rock-solid before proceeding

## Testing
This phase is the “spine” of the whole system, so tests here must be **fast, deterministic, and multi-layer**:

- Unit tests (tight, deterministic):
  - WezTerm CLI JSON parsing fixtures and edge cases (see `wa-4vx.2.5`, `wa-4vx.10.4`).
  - Storage schema/query helpers (including audit/redaction invariants) (see `wa-4vx.3.9`).
  - Pattern detection core: quick reject, extraction, pack semantics, and stable rule IDs (see `wa-4vx.5.*`).
  - Safety/policy decisions and redaction behavior (see `wa-4vx.8.*`).
  - Robot mode JSON envelope + stable error codes (see `wa-4vx.7.8`, `wa-4vx.7.10`).

- Integration tests (no real WezTerm required):
  - Synthetic/fixture delta streams drive watcher/ingest → storage → search → robot read paths (see `wa-4vx.6.4`).
  - Explicit negative-path tests for gaps/backpressure and “unhandled event” flows.

- E2E test scripts (real-ish wiring, with artifacts):
  - Must follow the E2E harness contract (`wa-4vx.10.6`) and runner (`wa-4vx.10.11`) and use structured logging (`wa-4vx.6.5`).
  - Cover core wiring and reliability scenarios (examples: `wa-4vx.10.14`, `wa-4vx.10.15`, `wa-4vx.10.19`, `wa-4vx.10.21`, `wa-4vx.10.22`).

- Artifact requirements (for every integration/E2E run):
  - Structured logs (machine-parseable), a per-case metadata file, and failure screenshots when available.
  - A redacted audit extract verifying “deny” decisions never leak secrets.
  - A deterministic DB snapshot/export sufficient to reproduce assertions offline.

- Performance regression gates:
  - Criterion budgets for the hot path (delta extraction, pattern scan, FTS queries) live in `wa-4vx.10.2`.
  - When budgets fail, output must include enough profiling/log context to localize the regression.

Note: this phase is linked under the `wa-nu4` umbrella milestone for tracking, but it should be treated as the root prerequisite for later phases.

- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.

description:
# Task: Feature flags + crate boundary rules

## Goal
Prevent optional heavy integrations from polluting the hot path.

This is both a performance and UX requirement:
- fast default builds
- small default dependency surface
- optional integrations don’t slow down contributors who don’t need them

## Feature flags
Workspace feature set (names may evolve, but intent must remain):
- `vendored` (wezterm crates)
- `browser` (playwright)
- `mcp` (fastmcp_rust)
- `web` (fastapi_rust)
- `tui` (charmed_rust)
- `metrics` (prometheus endpoint)
- `distributed` (wa-agent + aggregator)

## Crate boundary conventions
- `wa-core` contains business logic and must avoid UI/transport deps.
- `wa` (binary) depends on `wa-core`.
- Optional frontends live in their own crates and depend on `wa-core`:
  - `wa-mcp`, `wa-web`, `wa-tui`, `wa-browser` (names flexible)

## Dependency hygiene rules
- `wa-core` must not take unconditional deps on:
  - Playwright / browser automation
  - MCP / web / TUI frameworks
- Optional features must be guarded with `cfg(feature = "...")` all the way down.
- No “accidental” imports (e.g., a `use` that forces a heavy dep even when the feature is off).

## Testing
- `cargo check --all-targets` passes with default features.
- `cargo check --all-targets --all-features` passes.
- Each optional feature must compile in isolation:
  - `cargo check --all-targets --features browser`
  - `cargo check --all-targets --features mcp`
  - … etc.
- (If practical) add a small CI feature matrix so breakages are caught immediately.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Building without optional features yields a small dependency set.
- Each optional feature can be enabled independently without breaking the build.
- `wa-core` has no unconditional dependency edges to browser/mcp/web/tui crates.

title: Golden corpus regression harness (tests/corpus/*.{txt,expect.json})
description:
# Task: Golden corpus regression harness

## Goal
Make output-format drift explicit and easy to address.

## Canonical corpus layout (PLAN Appendix G.4)
We standardize on this directory structure so adding fixtures is obvious and deterministic:

```
tests/corpus/
├── codex/
│   ├── usage_limit_v1.txt
│   ├── usage_limit_v1.expect.json
│   ├── compaction_v1.txt
│   └── compaction_v1.expect.json
├── claude_code/
│   ├── session_end.txt
│   └── session_end.expect.json
└── gaps/
    ├── scrollback_truncation.txt
    └── scrollback_truncation.expect.json
```

Rules:
- Every `*.txt` fixture has a sibling `*.expect.json` containing the expected detections.
- Keep fixtures small-but-realistic; redact secrets.
- Prefer “field drift” fixtures (missing fields, reordered lines, extra banners) so robustness improves without changing rule IDs.

## Harness behavior
- Discover fixtures by globbing `tests/corpus/**/*.txt`.
- For each fixture:
  - read input text
  - deserialize expected detections
  - run PatternEngine detection
  - compare expected vs actual with stable ordering + stable serialization

Reference sketch (from PLAN; implementation can differ but behavior must match):

```rust
#[test]
fn corpus_regression() {
    for entry in glob("tests/corpus/**/*.txt").unwrap() {
        let input = std::fs::read_to_string(&entry).unwrap();
        let expected_path = entry.with_extension("expect.json");
        let expected: Vec<Detection> = serde_json::from_str(
            &std::fs::read_to_string(&expected_path).unwrap()
        ).unwrap();

        let actual = pattern_engine.detect(&input);
        assert_eq!(actual, expected, "Corpus regression: {:?}", entry);
    }
}
```

## Why
Agents change UI output formats. Corpus tests are how we keep the system correct over time.

## CI integration
- The corpus regression test runs in the default `cargo test` suite.
- On mismatch, output must be actionable:
  - fixture path
  - rule ids involved
  - bounded diff (expected vs actual) or a compact mismatch report

## Testing
- The harness itself must be deterministic:
  - stable ordering of fixtures
  - stable ordering/serialization of detections
- Negative harness tests:
  - missing `.expect.json` yields a clear error
  - invalid JSON yields a clear error pointing at the file

## Acceptance Criteria
- Running tests catches mismatches when rules change.
- Mismatch output is debuggable without rerunning locally with a debugger.

# Task: E2E test script — workflow resume after watcher restart

## Goal
Prove the core durability promise:
- workflows resume after crash/restart
- step logs are correct
- actions are not duplicated/spammed

- Spawn a dummy pane that triggers a workflow requiring at least one wait step.
- During the workflow:
  - kill the watcher process abruptly (simulate crash)
  - restart watcher

## Assertions
- On restart, the workflow resumes from the last completed step.
- No step that sends input is executed twice (unless explicitly designed to be retryable with backoff).
- Final status is completed/aborted with a clear reason.

## Test runner integration
- Must run via the E2E runner (`./scripts/e2e_test.sh`) and follow the harness artifacts contract.
- Must be deterministic (no sleeps-as-synchronization; use wait-for markers/timeouts).

  - workflow execution record
  - step log before/after restart
  - watcher logs with restart markers
  - audit log entries for any sends (to prove “no double-send”)

title: E2E script: wa watch graceful shutdown (SIGINT flush, lock release, restart clean)
description:
# Task: E2E script — graceful shutdown and restart

## Goal
Validate that `wa watch` behaves safely under real-world stop/restart cycles.

This test guards against a class of user-hostile failures:
- Ctrl-C leaves the DB writer queue half-flushed
- lock files are left behind and prevent restart
- partial writes break FTS or schema invariants

## Scenario
- Start a mux server and spawn a dummy pane that prints a predictable token stream.
- Start `wa watch` with verbose logging and a dedicated workspace.
- Wait until at least one segment is persisted (FTS finds a unique token).
- Send SIGINT to `wa watch`.

## Assertions
- `wa watch` exits cleanly within a bounded timeout.
- Storage is flushed:
  - FTS still works after shutdown (search finds previously written token)
- Lock is released:
  - restarting `wa watch` in the same workspace succeeds

## Artifacts
- Same artifacts contract as `wa-4vx.10.6`, plus:
  - shutdown summary section
  - restart attempt logs

## Registry
- Register this case in the E2E case registry (`wa-4vx.10.20`), including prerequisites and default inclusion status.
- Ensure `./scripts/e2e_test.sh --all` includes this case (or mark non-default with justification).

## Acceptance Criteria
- Test is deterministic.
- On failure, artifacts make it obvious whether the bug is:
  - signal handling
  - storage flush
  - lock release
  - FTS corruption


## Testing
- Meta-validation:
  - Add a deliberate failure mode (e.g., kill -9) in a separate variant to confirm the test distinguishes graceful vs abrupt termination.
  - Ensure the test fails if the lock is not released (second watcher start must be an assertion, not “best effort”).

- Artifact validation:
  - Assert the artifacts include the shutdown/restart summary sections and that FTS queries are recorded as evidence.

# Task: E2E script — approval allow-once

## Goal
Validate the full RequireApproval UX loop:
1) an action requires approval
2) wa returns a structured allow-once payload
3) a human grants approval via `wa approve`
4) the action succeeds on retry
5) the whole flow is auditable and redacted

This is the critical "human-in-the-loop" bridge that keeps wa safe and ergonomic.

## Scenario
- Use a policy config that forces RequireApproval for SendText in a safe situation (so this test is deterministic).
- Spawn a dummy pane that echoes received input.

Steps
1. Attempt a send (`wa send` or `wa robot send`): expect RequireApproval.
2. Extract `allow_once_code` from the output.
3. Run `wa approve <code> --yes`.
4. Retry the same send: expect Allow and successful injection.
5. Verify audit trail contains:
   - initial require-approval decision
   - approval grant
   - successful retry
   - redacted summaries (no raw secret-like input)

## Assertions
- RequireApproval returns a stable allow-once payload.
- Approval is scoped (wrong pane/action/workspace does not match).
- Retry succeeds only for the matching fingerprint.

## Artifacts
- Effective config used.
- Robot/human command outputs.
- Audit export JSONL (or query output).

title: Criterion benchmarks + budgets (pattern detect, delta extraction, FTS query)
description:
# Task: Benchmarks + budgets

## Goal
Prevent performance regressions on hot paths.

This is the “performance test suite” complement to unit/E2E tests: it ensures wa stays fast enough to run continuously.

## Bench targets (must exist)
- Overlap/delta extraction (hot ingest path)
- Pattern engine quick reject (typical no-match)
- Pattern detection on “typical pane output”
- FTS query latency for common queries on representative DB size
- Watcher loop overhead when idle (per-pane check cost)

## Initial budgets (PLAN §13.4 + Appendix G.7)
These are v0 targets; we can tune later, but they must be explicitly recorded so regressions are real failures, not vibes.

- Quick reject no-match: **< 1µs** for typical non-matching text.
- Pattern detection (typical corpus): **p50 < 1ms**, **p99 < 5ms**.
- FTS query common patterns (DB ~100k captures):
  - **p50 < 10ms**, **p99 < 50ms** (hard cap: < 50ms for common queries).
- Watcher loop overhead (idle): **< 100µs per pane check**.

Notes:
- Budgets should be reported with machine metadata (OS/CPU/rustc/features).
- CI should enforce budgets in a non-flaky way (relative threshold vs baseline, or dedicated perf runners).

## CI integration
- Local-only initially is acceptable if CI is too noisy, but the harness must produce machine-readable artifacts.
- Once stable, integrate into CI (tracked by `wa-nu4.3.4.4`) with:
  - clear pass/fail thresholds
  - artifact upload of benchmark results on failure

## Artifacts & logging
Bench runs must produce debuggable artifacts:
- raw Criterion JSON output
- a short summary (top regressions, top slowest benches)
- build/machine metadata:
  - OS, CPU model, rustc version, enabled features
  - git commit hash when available

## Testing
- Bench harness self-check:
  - Add a small “sanity bench” guaranteed to run so the harness failing to execute is caught early.

- Budget enforcement tests:
  - If budget checks are implemented as code, include a unit test that feeds a fake benchmark JSON and asserts:
    - regression triggers failure
    - outputs include which benchmark regressed and by how much

## Acceptance Criteria
- Bench suite runs locally and produces a baseline.
- Budgets above are documented and emitted in summaries.
- CI enforcement can come later if early CI is too noisy, but the artifacts/logging are in place.
notes: Progress (2026-01-21): added bench metadata/budget emission (JSONL) via benches/bench_common.rs; each bench now emits budgets + machine metadata and writes target/criterion/wa-bench-meta.jsonl.

# Task: E2E suite completeness (case registry)

## Goal
Make sure `./scripts/e2e_test.sh --all` is a comprehensive, maintained suite that:
- runs every **registered** E2E scenario (not just the ones under `wa-4vx.10.*`)
- produces stable artifacts per case
- prints a clear PASS/FAIL summary

This task exists to avoid coupling “runner quality” to “suite completeness”.

## Requirements
- Maintain a single authoritative registry of cases (names + descriptions).
- The registry must also record (at least):
  - prerequisites (e.g., requires WezTerm, requires docker, requires feature flags)
  - whether the case is part of the default `--all` run
  - a human-readable “why this case exists” note (what it protects)

- `./scripts/e2e_test.sh --all` iterates that registry.
- Each case has:
  - deterministic steps
  - explicit assertions
  - artifacts directory
  - clear failure summary

## Cross-repo case coverage (important)
Some E2E scenarios live outside `wa-4vx.10.*` (for example setup safety, new IPC lanes, and UX overlays):
- `wa-nu4.3.3.10` (wa setup idempotency)
- `wa-4vx.2.7.3` (status_update IPC lane)
- `wa-nu4.1.6.4` (pane reservations)
- `wa-0go.7` (natural-language event descriptions)
- `wa-5em.9` (rollback visualization tests/E2E)
- `wa-dug.7` (environment detection + recommendations)
- `wa-tp4.8` (suggestion engine)
- `wa-nu4.4.3.5` (distributed E2E tests; non-default unless distributed feature enabled)
- `wa-9lh` (quick-fix suggestions E2E)
- `wa-am5` (dry-run mode E2E)
- `wa-jl5` (notification webhook delivery E2E)
- `wa-ugg` (timeline correlation E2E)
- `wa-p3i` (watch-and-notify mode E2E)

Suite completeness means the registry accounts for these cases too.
Implementation options (either is acceptable; pick the simplest):
- unify everything under `./scripts/e2e_test.sh` as runnable `--case` entries, OR
- allow registry entries to delegate to another script (adapter entry) while still producing the same artifacts contract.

## Change discipline
- Adding a new E2E case requires updating the registry.
- CI should catch:
  - “case exists but not in registry”
  - “case is in registry but not included in default suite” (unless explicitly tagged as non-default with justification)

## Registry
- This bead *is* the registry. Update the case list here when new E2E cases are added.

## Logging
- Follow the standard E2E harness logging contract (`wa-4vx.10.6`) and runner (`wa-4vx.10.11`).
- Emit per-step start/end markers with timestamps + durations.
- Include case name and pane ids in every log line.
- Redact secrets (device codes, tokens) in logs and artifacts.

## Acceptance Criteria
- A developer can run `./scripts/e2e_test.sh --all` and trust it covers the full default suite.
- The suite remains usable even as cases evolve across phases.
- `wa-nu4.3.3.10`, `wa-4vx.2.7.3`, `wa-nu4.1.6.4`, `wa-0go.7`, `wa-5em.9`, `wa-dug.7`, and `wa-tp4.8` are represented in the case registry (directly or via adapter), with stable artifacts.


## Testing
- Registry correctness tests:
  - Add a check that enumerates available E2E cases and fails if any are missing from the registry.
  - Add a check that fails if the registry references a non-existent case.

- `--all` behavior tests:
  - Include a small dummy registry in test mode to verify:
    - ordering and selection flags

    - per-case artifact dir naming is stable

  - audit records the attempted action and the rule id/reason

  - pane echoes it
  - audit records allow

# Task: Fuzz targets (cargo-fuzz)

## Goal
Harden parser/decoder surfaces via fuzz testing and prevent:
- panics
- infinite loops / pathological backtracking
- unbounded allocations

Fuzzing is especially valuable for wa because we ingest adversarial-ish terminal output and untrusted-ish config inputs.

## Targets (initial)
1) Pattern pack parsing
   - TOML/YAML parsing and validation
   - rule id uniqueness and required fields

2) OSC / marker parsing
   - OSC 133 prompt markers
   - any additional user-var lane formats

3) Search query handling
   - FTS query normalization and error paths
   - ensure malformed queries return structured errors (not panics)

## Harness requirements
- Use `cargo-fuzz` with libFuzzer.
- Provide small seed corpora for each target:
  - valid minimal examples
  - edge-case examples (empty, very long, unicode, invalid bytes)
- Ensure targets are deterministic and do not require filesystem/network.

## Crash handling conventions
- On crash, artifacts should be reproducible with a single command:

description:
# Task: E2E harness spec (deterministic + great logging)

## Goal
Define an end-to-end test harness that validates wa as a real system:
- ingest captures output
- storage persists segments + gaps
- patterns detect events
- workflows act safely (when enabled)
- robot/human surfaces remain consistent

## Constraints
- Must be deterministic and not require real Codex/Claude/Gemini credentials.
- Must run locally on a dev machine that has WezTerm installed.
- Must produce excellent logs/artifacts on failure.

## Core idea: "dummy agent panes"
For E2E we will spawn panes that run deterministic scripts:
- emit OSC 133 markers (or user-vars) to simulate prompt boundaries
- print known banner/pattern strings to trigger detections
- accept input and echo it so we can verify sends

## Scenarios (minimum)
1. Capture + search
   - start mux server
   - spawn pane that prints N lines
   - run wa watch briefly
   - assert segments exist and FTS finds a unique token

2. Compaction workflow
   - dummy pane prints compaction marker
   - watcher detects event
   - handle_compaction sends refresh prompt
   - dummy pane echoes received input
   - assert workflow logs show success

3. Policy denial
   - dummy pane enters alt-screen simulation (or we mark it via a fixture state)
   - wa send / wa robot send is denied with correct error code

## Registry
- Not a case. This bead defines the harness contract that the registry and runner must follow.

## Logging/artifacts contract
This harness assumes we have structured logs with stable correlation fields (`wa-4vx.6.5`).

On every run, write an artifacts folder (timestamped):
- env.txt (versions, uname, wezterm version)
- wa_watch.log (stdout/stderr with timestamps)
- wa_robot_state.json
- events.jsonl
- wa_config_effective.toml (or json): the fully-resolved config incl workspace/paths
- optional DB snapshot (if small) or export slices

On failure:
- print a clear summary + pointers to artifacts
- do NOT swallow errors

## Testing (harness self-check)
The harness itself should have a lightweight self-check mode that validates:
- required prerequisites (wezterm present, required feature flags)
- artifacts directory is writable
- the case registry is coherent (no missing case implementations)

This prevents “E2E is broken” failures that are actually just environment drift.

## Deliverables
- A written spec for the script(s): args, artifacts layout, exit codes.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Another contributor can implement the harness from this issue alone.

title: [EPIC] WezTerm interface layer (CLI-first + future tiers)
description:
# WezTerm interface layer (CLI-first)

## Goal
Provide a robust abstraction for interacting with WezTerm panes/domains without brittle UI automation.

wa must be able to:
- discover panes/domains deterministically
- read output reliably (for capture/detection)
- send input safely (for workflows)
- perform lifecycle actions (spawn/split/activate) when needed

## Rationale
The WezTerm interface is the **I/O layer** for the entire system. If this is wrong, everything above it becomes unreliable.

We explicitly avoid timing-based automation ("sendkeys") and instead rely on WezTerm-supported interfaces:

### Tier 1 (required): `wezterm cli`
- stable, upstream-supported
- JSON output for `list`
- explicit commands for `get-text` and `send-text`

### Tier 2 (recommended): Lua IPC + OSC user-vars
- low-latency state signals from panes
- allows deterministic prompt boundaries (via shell integration) and "ready" signals

### Tier 3 (optional): selective vendoring
- direct mux protocol access for streaming output / lower overhead
- gated behind benchmarks and strict version checks

## Key decisions
- CLI-first is the foundation.
- Vendoring is explicitly optional and must not block shipping v0.1.

## Deliverables
- `WeztermCliClient` wrapper with:
  - `list_panes()` (`wezterm cli list --format json`)
  - `get_text(pane_id, escapes)` (`wezterm cli get-text`)
  - `send_text(pane_id, text, no_paste)` (`wezterm cli send-text`)
  - `spawn`, `split-pane`, `activate-pane`, `get-pane-direction`
- Domain/pane metadata model:
  - domain name, window_id/tab_id/pane_id, title, cwd URI, size
- Socket targeting strategy:
  - support `WEZTERM_UNIX_SOCKET` override
  - future: explicit socket selection per domain
- Error model:
  - distinguish "pane not found" vs "wezterm not running" vs "socket mismatch".

## Acceptance
- Can list panes on a running WezTerm session.
- Can fetch text from a pane.
- Can send text to a pane (including control characters like Ctrl-C).



## Success Criteria
- WezTerm CLI wrapper provides stable list/get-text/send-text primitives with timeouts and clear errors.
- Pane identity and text acquisition are reliable enough to support ingest, waits, and action verification.
- Unit tests cover command normalization and parsing; integration tests validate against a test mux server where feasible.


## Testing
- Fixture-first parsing tests:
  - Golden JSON fixtures for `wezterm cli list --format json` and edge cases (missing fields, unknown enums, stale panes) (see `wa-4vx.2.5`, `wa-4vx.10.4`).
  - Golden text fixtures for `get-text` including escapes/no-escapes variants.

- Failure-mode tests (must exist before we trust this layer):
  - Socket mismatch / WezTerm not running / pane not found / transient CLI failures.
  - Retry/backoff correctness (bounded retries; timeouts enforced).

- Optional integration tests:
  - Where feasible, run against a real WezTerm in CI only if it’s hermetic; otherwise keep as local/manual scripts.
  - Ensure integration logs include exact CLI command lines, sanitized env, and timing so failures are diagnosable.

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Success Criteria, Deliverables.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.
close_reason: All child tasks completed: JSON models, CLI wrapper, additional commands, hardening, tests, and PaneWaiter utility all implemented.

title: PaneWaiter utility: shared wait-for (substring/regex) with timeout/backoff
description:
# Task: PaneWaiter (shared wait logic)

## Goal
Provide a single, well-tested implementation for "wait until a pane satisfies a condition" that can be reused everywhere:
- `wa robot send --wait-for` verification
- `wa robot wait-for`
- workflow `WaitCondition::Pattern` and other waits
- E2E harness synchronization points

## Why this matters
Waiting is one of the easiest places to accidentally introduce:
- flakiness (sleep loops, overly short tails, missed matches)
- performance issues (polling too aggressively, reading too much scrollback)
- duplicated logic that diverges across robot/workflow code paths

A shared PaneWaiter makes behavior consistent and debuggable for users.

## Design (v0)
- API: `wait_for(pane_id, matcher, timeout, options) -> WaitResult`
- Matcher types:
  - `Substring(String)` (fast path)
  - `Regex(Regex)` (explicit flag; avoid footguns)
- Text acquisition:
  - uses the same underlying pane text acquisition (WezTerm CLI get-text)
  - configurable `tail_lines` (default small, but enough for common prompts)
  - optional `escapes` mode when required for alt-screen detection

## Polling/backoff
- Bounded polling loop with adaptive backoff:
  - start fast (low latency for interactive flows)
  - backoff to a max interval (avoid CPU churn)
  - always respect timeout/deadline
- Add a guard like `max_polls` to prevent runaway loops in case of clock bugs.

## Cancellation + shutdown
- Must be cancellable (tokio cancellation) so workflows can abort cleanly and `wa watch` shutdown is fast.

## Logging + audit
- Log start/success/timeout at INFO with pane_id + timeout + elapsed.
- Never log full pane content; at most log a short redacted matcher description.
- When used by actions (send/workflow), the caller records verification details into audit trail.

## Testing
- Deterministic unit tests using a fake text source (scripted sequence of tails).
- Timeout behavior: stable error + elapsed_ms.
- Backoff behavior: does not busy-loop and respects deadline.
- Cancellation behavior: aborts quickly when cancelled.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Robot send, robot wait-for, and workflows share this implementation (no duplicated polling loops).
- Unit tests cover success, timeout, cancellation, and backoff bounds.
close_reason: Implemented PaneWaiter with shared matcher/backoff, redacted logging, and deterministic tests

title: [EPIC] Lua IPC status updates (WezTerm update-status signals)
description:
# [EPIC] Lua IPC status updates (WezTerm update-status signals)

## Mission
Add a low-latency, deterministic lane for pane metadata updates (cursor, dimensions, title, alt-screen) using WezTerm's `update-status` hook.

## Why this matters
CLI polling only gives us output text. For safe automation we also need *current pane state* and *metadata*:
- PromptActive / CommandRunning hints (used for policy and workflow guards)
- Alt-screen status (must never inject input)
- Title + cursor position to interpret agent readiness

`update-status` lets WezTerm report this state without parsing output, improving correctness and reducing guesswork.

## Scope
- Define a small `status_update` JSON schema.
- Use the existing watcher IPC socket to accept `status_update` messages.
- Update in-memory pane state and persist any relevant fields.
- Provide rate limiting / coalescing so status updates do not spam the event bus.

## Non-goals
- Real-time output streaming (handled by vendored streaming in Phase 5).
- Replacing OSC 133 prompt markers (this is additive, not a replacement).

## Deliverables
- Versioned schema for `status_update` payloads.
- Watcher handling that updates pane state deterministically.
- WezTerm Lua snippet support (installed via `wa setup`).
- Tests + E2E case with artifacts.

## Success Criteria
- Pane state is updated even when there is no new output.
- Policy and workflows can rely on the status updates to make safer decisions.
- Logs/artifacts are clear and never include sensitive payloads.

## Testing
- Unit tests for schema validation and coalescing behavior.
- Integration tests for watcher IPC receiving status updates.
- E2E script with real WezTerm (or deterministic stub) that proves updates flow end-to-end with artifacts.

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Deliverables.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.

title: IPC status_update schema + watcher ingestion (pane state refresh)
description:
# Task: IPC status_update schema + watcher ingestion

## Goal
Define a small, versioned `status_update` payload and teach the watcher to ingest it safely and update pane state.

## Schema (v0)
Minimal, deterministic payload:
- `pane_id` (u64)
- `domain` (string, optional)
- `title` (string, optional, bounded length)
- `cursor` (row/col)
- `dimensions` (cols/rows)
- `is_alt_screen` (bool)
- `is_active` (bool, optional)
- `ts` (unix ms or ISO8601)
- `schema_version` (int)

## Behavior
- Validate size limits and schema_version.
- Coalesce rapid updates (rate-limit per pane).
- **Respect pane selection filters**: if a pane is ignored, drop status updates and avoid persistence.
- Update in-memory pane registry:
  - title, dimensions, cursor
  - alt-screen flag
- Persist fields that matter (if we store them in `panes` table).
- Emit a lightweight internal signal if state changes materially (e.g., alt-screen toggles).

## Safety
- Never log raw payloads by default.
- Treat malformed payloads as non-fatal (drop + structured error).
- If pane is unknown, record a warning and skip (do not create phantom panes).

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - schema validation and size limits
  - rate limiting/coalescing (no event bus spam)
  - alt-screen state transitions are handled deterministically
  - ignored panes do not update state
- Integration tests:
  - send a synthetic status_update into the IPC receiver and assert pane registry updates

## Acceptance Criteria
- Status updates change pane state without requiring output text.
- Alt-screen changes are reflected in `PaneCapabilities` (and policy gates can use them).
- Malformed payloads never crash the watcher.
- Ignored panes do not change state or persist metadata.

# Task: Extend wezterm.lua patcher to emit status_update signals

## Goal
Install a safe, idempotent Lua snippet that sends `status_update` payloads from WezTerm to wa.

## Why
The watcher needs low-latency pane metadata without parsing output. `update-status` is the right hook.

## Lua behavior
- Use `wezterm.on('update-status', ...)`.
- Build a minimal JSON payload:
  - pane_id, domain, title, cursor, dimensions, alt-screen
- Send to wa via `wezterm.background_child_process { 'wa', 'event', '--from-status', ... }` (or the agreed event flag).
- Rate-limit per pane (e.g., 1 update per 2s) to avoid spam.

## Idempotent patching
- Extend the existing WA-managed block (`WA-BEGIN/WA-END`).
- Must remain safe if re-run (`wa setup` idempotency test stays green).
- If Lua snippet cannot run (missing wezterm.json), it must fail silently (no impact on terminal UX).

## Testing
- Fixture tests (reuse `wa-nu4.3.3.5`):
  - snippet inserted exactly once
  - re-run is a no-op
- E2E covered by status_update lane test (see new E2E case)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Re-running `wa setup` does not duplicate the snippet.
- The snippet emits `status_update` payloads without blocking the UI.
