title: [EPIC] Storage & indexing (SQLite WAL + FTS5 + async writer)
description:
# Storage & indexing — SQLite WAL + FTS5

## Goal
Persist:
- raw pane output as **append-only segments** (delta-first)
- explicit `GAP` events when continuity cannot be guaranteed
- detected events + extracted facts
- workflow execution traces (step logs) for resumability

and provide fast query surfaces:
- full-text search (FTS5) across all captured output
- scoped search per pane/domain/time

## Rationale
The database is wa’s "world memory". It enables:
- debugging (what happened?)
- agent coordination (search + recall)
- workflow correctness (structured facts, resumability)

We choose SQLite because:
- zero-config, embeddable, portable
- supports WAL for concurrent readers + single writer
- FTS5 is excellent for terminal transcript search

## Architectural constraints
- `rusqlite::Connection` is not `Send` and cannot be used directly inside async tasks.
- We must not block the async runtime with DB writes.

Therefore the design is:
- **single dedicated writer thread** receiving bounded write commands
- **small read-only connection pool** for queries (WAL allows concurrent reads)

## Deliverables
- Schema and migrations strategy (even if v0 is "init schema only"):
  - domains, panes
  - output segments (seq monotonic per pane)
  - output gaps (explicit discontinuities)
  - FTS virtual table + triggers
  - events (detections)
  - agent sessions (token usage, session IDs, etc.)
  - workflow executions + step logs
  - accounts + config + maintenance log
- `StorageHandle` async API with:
  - `append_segment`, `record_gap`, `record_event`
  - `search(fts_query, options)` with correct bm25 ranking
  - `workflow_step_*` methods for durable step logs
- Retention + hygiene mechanisms:
  - retention-by-age and/or size
  - explicit `vacuum` command only

## Acceptance
- `wa` can write segments and query them back.
- FTS finds known text quickly.
- Writer thread enforces per-pane seq monotonicity and emits/records gaps when violated.



## Success Criteria
- SQLite schema + migrations exist and are exercised by tests.
- StorageHandle provides single-writer semantics and supports concurrent read queries without blocking the async runtime.
- FTS search works end-to-end (segments written → indexed → searchable) with deterministic scoping.
- Core storage invariants are enforced (seq monotonicity, explicit gaps, audit/event/workflow trace durability).
- Unit/integration tests cover writer queue behavior, migrations, FTS queries, and workflow/audit storage paths.


## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - Schema/migration roundtrips and “invariant checks” (seq monotonicity, explicit gaps, FK consistency).
  - Writer queue behavior under load (bounded queue backpressure, graceful shutdown flush).
  - FTS query correctness and scoping (pane/domain/time) including snippet/highlight determinism.

- Integration tests:
  - End-to-end “write segments → index → search” with deterministic fixtures.
  - Restart/resume: open DB, write, close, reopen, verify writer thread state rehydrates correctly.

- Property/fuzz tests (as additive confidence for correctness):
  - Proptest seq generation ensures monotonic enforcement and correct GAP insertion semantics (`wa-4vx.10.5`).
  - Fuzz inputs for query parsing / escaping / injection-hardening (`wa-4vx.10.3`).

- Artifact/log requirements (for integration/E2E):
  - On failure, dump the minimal DB snapshot or deterministic query output needed to reproduce.

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Success Criteria, Deliverables.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.
close_reason: All child tasks completed: schema (3.1), StorageHandle (3.2), segments (3.3), FTS (3.4), events/workflows (3.5), retention (3.6), tests (3.7, 3.9), audit (3.8), migrations (3.10), sizing study (3.11). Storage & indexing fully implemented.

title: Define SQLite schema (segments+gaps+events+workflows+FTS) + init/migration strategy
description:
# Task: Define SQLite schema + init/migration strategy

## Goal
Define the database schema that supports:
- append-only output segments (delta-first)
- explicit output gaps
- panes metadata + observation status (observed vs ignored)
- events (detections) with extracted JSON
- event lifecycle: unhandled vs handled, workflow linkage, idempotency/dedupe
- agent sessions and token usage
- workflow executions + step logs (durability/resumability)
- accounts mirror (usage tracking)
- config + maintenance log
- (later) audit trail of actions (see wa-4vx.3.8)

## Rationale
DB schema mistakes are expensive. We want a schema that:
- is append-friendly (write-optimized)
- is easy to query for recent state
- enables FTS for fast recall
- supports workflow resumption after crash
- supports user trust: we can explain why wa acted (events + workflows + audit)

## Required properties
- WAL mode, foreign_keys on.
- output_segments has UNIQUE(pane_id, seq).
- GAPs are explicit (output_gaps).
- FTS5 virtual table over output_segments + triggers.

## Panes table requirements
We need a panes table to support:
- stable UI/state surfaces (wa status / wa robot state)
- observation decisions (privacy/perf)

Minimum fields (names flexible):
- pane_id (and domain/window/tab identifiers)
- title, cwd
- last_seen_at
- observed: bool
- ignore_reason: nullable short string (rule id/name)
- last_decision_at

## Event lifecycle requirements
We need to support:
- events that start as unhandled
- linkage to a handling attempt:
  - handled_by_workflow_execution_id (nullable)
  - handled_at (nullable)
  - handled_status (completed/aborted/failed/paused per semantics)
- idempotency/deduping:
  - optional dedupe_key (pane_id + rule_id + window) to prevent duplicates

Exact column naming is flexible, but the schema must make:
- `wa events --unhandled` cheap
- marking handled a single write

## Deliverables
- SCHEMA string (or migrations folder if we choose migrations now).
- Documented conventions:
  - timestamps: use epoch ms for hot paths (captured_at int)
  - JSON columns are TEXT containing JSON (v0)
  - indexing strategy for common queries

## Testing
- Schema/migration tests (see `wa-4vx.3.10`):
  - create fresh DB
  - upgrade from prior schema versions
  - validate core invariants and indexes exist
- Storage tests (see `wa-4vx.3.7`):
  - insert/query round-trips for segments/gaps/events/workflows

## Acceptance Criteria
- DB initializes successfully on first run.
- Basic inserts into segments/events/panes succeed.
- We can mark an event as handled and query unhandled events efficiently.
close_reason: Implemented comprehensive SQLite schema with 9 tables, FTS5 full-text search, WAL mode, foreign keys, triggers, and 14 schema tests

title: SQLite migrations & upgrade tests: schema versioning, forward upgrades, invariants
description:
# Task: SQLite migrations & upgrade tests

## Goal
Ensure DB schema evolution is safe and predictable.

Even though we do not care about long-term backwards compatibility, we DO care about:
- wa users upgrading from yesterday's build to today's build
- avoiding "my DB is bricked" situations
- making schema changes intentional and test-backed

## Strategy
- Use an explicit schema version (e.g., `PRAGMA user_version`) and a clear migration runner.
- Keep a minimal set of historical fixtures for N-1 and N-2 schema versions.

## Testing (minimum)
1. Fresh init
   - new empty workspace initializes DB
   - required tables/indexes exist
   - WAL + foreign_keys configured

2. Upgrade path
   - start from an older fixture DB
   - run wa startup migration path
   - verify:
     - user_version bumped correctly
     - no required tables are missing
     - FTS tables/triggers exist and are functional

3. Invariants
   - output_segments `UNIQUE(pane_id, seq)` enforced
   - events lifecycle columns exist and unhandled queries are indexed/fast

## Diagnostics on failure
- Print clear errors:
  - expected vs actual user_version
  - missing table/index names
  - migration step that failed

## Acceptance Criteria
- A contributor can safely change schema by updating migrations AND updating these tests.
- CI catches broken migrations before users do.

title: Data volume sizing + compression decision gate
description:
# Task: Data volume sizing + compression decision gate

## Goal
Answer the open question: is retention alone sufficient, or do we need compression in v0.1/v0.2?

## Why
We need predictable disk usage and query performance as pane counts grow.
A data-volume study prevents surprises and avoids premature complexity.

## Work items
- Build a synthetic capture workload:
  - N panes (e.g., 20/50/100)
  - realistic output rate (lines/sec)
  - typical session duration (1h, 8h, 24h)
- Measure:
  - DB growth rate
  - FTS insert performance
  - query latency at 1M / 10M / 50M rows
- Decide:
  - keep retention-only, OR
  - add compression (and where: segments table, cold storage, export-only)

## Deliverables
- A sizing table and recommendation.
- If compression is required, create follow-up beads for:
  - compression format
  - migration strategy
  - query impact

## Testing
- Add a repeatable benchmark harness (can be a test-only helper) that generates synthetic segments and reports sizes.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Decision recorded in this bead with rationale and thresholds (e.g., "if DB > 1GB in 30 days, add compression").
close_reason: Sizing study complete. Decision: RETENTION ONLY sufficient for v0.1/v0.2. No compression needed. Benchmark: crates/wa-core/benches/sizing_benchmark.rs

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
## Sizing Study Results

### Performance Results
- Insert Throughput: ~7,000 segments/sec (target: >1000) ✓
- Query Latency at 1K: 600µs-1.1ms ✓
- Query Latency at 10K: 2-25ms ✓
- Average segment size: ~128.7 bytes

### DB Growth Estimates (30-day retention)
- Light use (10 panes, 1h/day): ~15MB
- Medium use (20 panes, 8h/day): ~240MB
- Heavy use (50 panes, 24h/day): ~1.8GB
- Extreme use (100 panes, 24h/day): ~3.6GB

### Decision: RETENTION ONLY is sufficient for v0.1/v0.2

Rationale:
1. Insert throughput exceeds needs by 7x
2. Query latency meets FTS budget
3. 30-day retention keeps DB under 10GB
4. No compression complexity needed at this scale

Thresholds for future compression:
- DB > 5GB after 30 days
- FTS p99 > 100ms consistently
- Insert throughput < 2000/sec

Artifacts: crates/wa-core/benches/sizing_benchmark.rs

title: Implement StorageHandle (single writer thread + read pool) with bounded write queue
description:
# Task: Implement StorageHandle async architecture

## Goal
Provide an async-safe storage API:
- never blocks the Tokio runtime on SQLite I/O
- centralizes all writes through one dedicated writer thread
- allows concurrent reads via small read-only pool (WAL)

## Why
`rusqlite::Connection` is not Send/Sync; direct use inside async tasks causes runtime stalls.

## Workspace/path behavior
- StorageHandle should be constructed from a resolved workspace/config path (`wa-4vx.9.2` / `wa-4vx.9.6`).
- It must create parent directories for the DB path if missing.

## Deliverables
- StorageHandle with:
  - bounded mpsc channel for write commands (backpressure)
  - writer thread main loop
  - read pool via deadpool_sqlite (or equivalent)
- Clear shutdown path:
  - stop accepting new writes
  - flush queued writes
  - close connections

## Testing
- Unit/integration tests (see `wa-4vx.3.7`):
  - bounded queue enforces backpressure (no unbounded growth)
  - writer thread serializes writes correctly
  - concurrent reads function while writes are happening (WAL)
  - shutdown flushes pending writes deterministically
  - failure modes (DB locked/unwritable) yield actionable errors (no panics)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Writes succeed under load without blocking async tasks.
- Reads can run concurrently while writes happen.
- On shutdown, queued writes are flushed deterministically.
close_reason: Implemented StorageHandle with bounded mpsc channel for write commands, writer thread loop, spawn_blocking for concurrent reads, and clean shutdown with flush. All 111 tests pass.

title: Persist output segments + enforce per-pane seq monotonicity; record gaps on discontinuity
description:
# Task: Persist output segments + seq monotonicity + gaps

## Goal
Persist the ingest delta stream as append-only rows:
- output_segments (pane_id, seq, captured_at, text)
- output_gaps (pane_id, seq_range, reason)

## Why
This is the foundation for:
- FTS search
- deterministic event reconstruction
- workflow resumption and verification

## Requirements
- Enforce seq monotonicity:
  - UNIQUE(pane_id, seq)
  - reject or record inconsistency with a gap (depending on decision)
- Record gaps when:
  - overlap detection fails
  - cursor jumps / truncation detected
  - seq discontinuity detected

## Testing
- Unit/integration tests (see `wa-4vx.3.7` and `wa-4vx.4.8`):
  - inserting duplicate `(pane_id, seq)` fails predictably
  - discontinuities create explicit gap rows with a stable reason
  - last-N queries return deterministic ordering and are indexed
  - no panics on malformed input; errors are actionable

## Acceptance Criteria
- Inserting segments with the same (pane_id, seq) fails predictably.
- Gap rows are created for overlap failures and discontinuities.
- Queries can fetch the last N segments for a pane efficiently.
close_reason: Completed: storage schema enforces (pane_id, seq) uniqueness, gap recording helpers, and last-N segment queries with tests in wa-core/src/storage.rs

title: Storage tests: writer queue, seq monotonicity, FTS queries, workflow step logs
description:
# Task: Storage tests

## Goal
Make the storage layer trustworthy by asserting its **core invariants** under realistic concurrency.

This bead is intentionally about *behavioral guarantees* (what must never break), not about covering every line.

## Core invariants to lock down
- **Monotonic per-pane seq**
  - appending a segment with a lower/equal seq is rejected or converted into an explicit GAP + diagnostic (choose and test).

- **Single-writer semantics**
  - writes are serialized through the writer thread
  - bounded queue behavior is predictable under load

- **FTS correctness**
  - segments written are indexed and searchable
  - scoping (pane/domain/time) behaves deterministically
  - snippets/highlights do not panic on weird unicode

- **Workflow/audit durability**
  - workflow step logs persist and can be queried back
  - audit/event writes do not block reads

## Testing approach
- Use temp SQLite DBs in WAL mode.
- Prefer deterministic fixtures over timing-based tests.
- When concurrency is involved:
  - use explicit barriers/handshakes
  - assert bounded queue behavior without relying on sleeps

## Required test cases
- Writer queue:
  - backpressure behavior when queue is full
  - graceful shutdown flushes pending writes

- Segments + gaps:
  - happy path append/search
  - explicit GAP insertion and retrieval
  - seq monotonic enforcement

- FTS:
  - query finds known text
  - scoping works
  - empty/no-match behaves

- Workflow step logs:
  - write steps
  - query by workflow execution id

## Acceptance Criteria
- Tests are deterministic and run in CI.
- Regressions in schema or invariants are caught by a small set of focused tests.

title: [EPIC] Ingest pipeline + event bus (deltas, seq, backpressure, gaps)
description:
# Ingest pipeline + event bus

## Goal
Build the passive observation subsystem that:
- discovers panes/domains continuously
- tails output from each pane as **delta segments**
- assigns a strict per-pane sequence number (`seq`) to each segment
- applies backpressure (bounded queues)
- persists segments to DB and emits **explicit GAP events** when continuity is uncertain

## Key invariant
The ingest loop must **never** mutate terminal state.
It is pure observation: read, segment, persist, emit.

## Why this is critical
Everything depends on ingestion correctness:
- pattern detection relies on seeing the right bytes in the right order
- workflows rely on accurate, current state
- search relies on complete history

We explicitly avoid a design that silently drops data. If scrollback rotated or the cursor jumps, we record a GAP.

## Deliverables
- Pane discovery scheduler:
  - periodically call `wezterm cli list --format json`
  - maintain a registry of active panes with fingerprints (title/cwd/banner signature)
  - close out sessions when panes disappear

- Per-pane tailer:
  - polling baseline via `get-text`
  - overlap-based delta extraction to avoid re-storing full scrollback
  - adaptive polling speed (fast when active, slow when idle)
  - deterministic state parsing (OSC 133 markers) when enabled

- Event bus:
  - bounded channels for deltas/detections/workflow signals
  - fanout to consumers (storage writer, pattern engine, robot subscriptions)
  - no blocking the producer indefinitely (backpressure + metrics)

- Gap detection:
  - if overlap fails OR seq discontinuity OR obvious cursor jump → emit/record GAP

## Acceptance
- With N panes, ingestion runs stably without high CPU when panes are idle.
- Segments are written in-order per pane.
- GAP events occur explicitly under simulated discontinuity.



## Success Criteria
- wa can discover panes deterministically and only observe panes allowed by include/exclude rules.
- Tailers produce deltas with monotonic seq per pane and emit explicit GAP events when continuity breaks.
- Ingest writes segments and events through StorageHandle without unbounded buffering or deadlocks.
- PatternEngine receives deltas and emits detections/events reliably via the event bus.
- Unit/integration tests cover delta extraction, gap detection, backpressure behavior, and pane filtering; E2E covers capture+search.


## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - Delta extraction overlap algorithm correctness (including tricky boundary cases and repeated text).
  - OSC 133 marker parsing and state-machine transitions.
  - Pane include/exclude filtering and fingerprint stability.

- Integration tests:
  - Synthetic multi-pane streams to validate:
    - bounded backpressure (producer never blocks forever)
    - per-pane seq monotonicity
    - explicit GAP emission on discontinuity and on forced overlap failure
  - “Slow consumer” simulation to ensure the ingest loop degrades gracefully.

- E2E tests:
  - Verify capture → store → search works end-to-end and produces diagnosable artifacts.
  - At least one E2E scenario must intentionally induce a GAP and assert:
    - GAP is persisted
    - robot/status surfaces show it
    - workflows refuse to act when a recent GAP exists

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Success Criteria, Deliverables.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.

title: Memory-efficient output cache: skip redundant tail processing (LRU+rolling hash)
description:
# Task: Memory-efficient output cache (skip redundant tail processing)

## Goal
Reduce idle CPU and avoid redundant downstream work by detecting when a pane’s polled output hasn’t changed and skipping the expensive parts of the ingest pipeline.

This bead implements PLAN.md §13.3 “Memory-Efficient Output Cache”.

## Why (user value)
Without a cache, `wa watch` can end up repeatedly:
- parsing the same tail text
- running delta extraction even when nothing changed
- running quick reject / Aho-Corasick / regex extraction against identical content

That wastes CPU, increases fanout pressure, and increases the chance of “busy loop” style behavior when many panes are idle.

The cache is an *optimization with correctness constraints*:
- it must never cause us to miss new output
- it must have bounded memory
- it must be safe under concurrent pane processing

## Design (concrete)
Implement an `OutputCache` with two complementary mechanisms:

1. **Global LRU of recent content hashes**
   - key: content hash (u64)
   - value: last-seen timestamp
   - goal: skip processing when many panes repeat common boilerplate content

2. **Per-pane rolling hash state**
   - key: pane_id
   - value: rolling hash + basic metadata (line_count, last_updated)
   - goal: skip processing if this specific pane’s output hasn’t changed since last poll

### Hashing and safety
- Hash function must be fast and deterministic.
- Avoid allocations and avoid storing full content.
- Collisions are extremely unlikely but *possible*.
  - Mitigation: optionally include a second lightweight discriminator (e.g., content length, last N bytes hash) if needed.

### Eviction/TTL
- Cache must be bounded:
  - LRU capacity (configurable)
  - per-pane map pruned by age (e.g., drop pane rolling hash after N minutes without updates)

### Where it plugs in
The cache should be checked at the stage where we have the raw `get-text` result (or equivalent vendored streaming chunk) but before:
- delta extraction
- pattern scanning
- DB write enqueue

If `is_new(pane_id, text)` returns false:
- emit a debug/trace event (structured log) indicating skip
- do not enqueue work downstream for this tick

## Deliverables
- `OutputCache` type with:
  - `new(capacity)`
  - `is_new(pane_id, content) -> bool`
  - `prune(max_age)`
- Config knobs (defaults can be conservative):
  - capacity
  - max_age
- Structured logs/metrics:
  - cache hit rate
  - skipped panes per tick

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - repeated identical content returns `false` after first `true`
  - per-pane rolling hash correctly de-duplicates
  - global LRU de-duplicates across panes
  - pruning drops stale pane entries and old hashes

- Integration tests:
  - synthetic ingest loop over many panes with mostly-idle output:
    - verifies skips happen
    - verifies that when content changes, processing resumes

- Perf/bench:
  - add a micro-benchmark for `is_new` overhead and validate it stays tiny relative to full detection.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Under a simulated workload of many idle panes, ingest CPU drops measurably (cache hit rate visible in logs/metrics).
- No correctness regressions: when content changes, new segments/events still flow through.
- Memory is bounded and does not grow with time/pane churn.

title: Delta extraction (overlap window) + seq assignment + per-pane cursors
description:
# Task: Delta extraction + seq assignment

## Goal
Convert repeated get-text snapshots into a clean delta stream:
- detect when text changed
- extract only new content when possible
- assign strictly increasing per-pane seq

## Why
Storing full snapshots is too heavy. Delta-first is cheaper and improves FTS behavior.

## Algorithm
- Maintain per-pane:
  - last content hash
  - recent tail lines window (OVERLAP_WINDOW)
  - last seq
- On new snapshot:
  - if hash unchanged → no delta
  - else attempt overlap match:
    - find where recent tail appears in current snapshot
    - delta = lines after overlap
  - if no overlap:
    - delta = full snapshot
    - emit a GAP reason (handled by gap pipeline)

## Deliverables
- IncrementalCapture implementation.
- Definition of PaneDelta / OutputSegment payload.

## Testing
- Unit tests (see `wa-4vx.4.8`):
  - append-only output produces minimal deltas
  - edits/truncations produce full snapshot + gap
  - seq is strictly increasing per pane
  - overlap logic is robust to repeated lines and partial overlaps

## Acceptance Criteria
- Produces correct deltas for append-only output.
- Emits full snapshot when necessary (and triggers a gap).
- Never produces decreasing or duplicated seq values.

title: Gap detection: overlap failure, cursor jump, seq discontinuity → explicit GAP events
description:
# Task: Gap detection and GAP events

## Goal
Ensure wa never silently loses output continuity.

A GAP is a first-class signal that "we might have missed output". This must propagate into safety policy (deny or require approval for sends).

## When to emit GAP
- overlap match fails (cannot align snapshots)
- obvious cursor jump / alt-screen toggles that invalidate overlap assumptions
- seq discontinuity detected by writer (storage also records)

## Design
- GAP is an explicit record with:
  - pane_id
  - last_seq (and/or seq_range)
  - reason (scrollback_truncation, cursor_jump, overlap_failed, ...)
- GAPs are persisted in DB.
- GAPs are surfaced in status/events views (at least as a flag).

## Testing
- Unit tests (see `wa-4vx.4.8`):
  - overlap failure emits a GAP reason deterministically
  - cursor-jump / truncation heuristics (if any) are conservative
- Integration/E2E:
  - `wa-4vx.10.10` validates policy gating denies sends when RecentGap is true

## Acceptance Criteria
- Simulated discontinuity yields a persisted GAP record.
- Policy treats RecentGap state as "uncertain" and refuses or requires approval for SendText.

title: User-var event lane: implement `wa event --from-uservar` (decode, validate, deliver to watcher)
description:
# Task: User-var event lane (`wa event --from-uservar`)

## Goal
Support deterministic, out-of-band signals from panes via WezTerm’s `user-var-changed` event, forwarded by `wezterm.lua`.

The plan’s Lua snippet calls:
- `wa event --from-uservar --pane <id> --name <name> --value <value>`

wa must:
- decode/validate the payload
- deliver it to the running watcher runtime so it can update state and/or emit internal events

## Why this improves UX and reliability
- OSC 133 prompt markers are great, but user-vars provide an additional deterministic channel.
- Enables future features like explicit checkpoints, "agent ready" signals, and safer workflow gating.

## Emitting user-vars from inside a pane (PLAN Appendix E.2)
Minimal emission example:

```bash
# Emit a user-var from within a pane
printf "\033]1337;SetUserVar=%s=%s\007" \
  wa_event \
  "$(printf '%s' '{"kind":"prompt","pane":"$WEZTERM_PANE"}' | base64)"
```

Notes:
- The `value` is typically base64-encoded JSON.
- Be careful with shell quoting: if you want `$WEZTERM_PANE` expanded, the JSON string must not be single-quoted.

Use cases (v0+):
- Mark prompt boundaries / “agent ready” checkpoints
- Mark workflow checkpoints
- Emit structured status updates (future; see Lua `update-status` lane)

## Inputs
- `pane_id: u64`
- `name: String`
- `value: String` (raw)

## Extensibility (important)
Design the payload envelope so additional event kinds can be introduced without inventing new IPC:
- recommended: base64 JSON payload with at least `{ "kind": "...", ... }`.

## Validation
- Size limits on payload.
- Optional decoding of JSON values when `name` indicates structured payload.

## Delivery
- If watcher socket is present:
  - connect and send the event JSON to the watcher
- If watcher socket is missing:
  - fail with actionable error ("is `wa watch` running in this workspace?")

## Logging
- Never log raw values by default.
- On failure, include:
  - size
  - name
  - pane id

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - payload decode + size limit enforcement
- Integration tests:
  - start a local test receiver and ensure message arrives

## Acceptance Criteria
- Given a fixture payload, `wa event` decodes it and sends it to a local test receiver.
- If watcher socket is missing, error message is actionable.

title: [EPIC] Pattern detection engine (packs, quick reject, extraction, tests)
description:
# Pattern detection engine

## Goal
Detect meaningful agent state transitions from terminal output quickly and reliably:
- usage warnings / usage reached
- compaction events
- session end summaries (token usage, resume IDs)
- auth-required prompts (device codes)

and produce structured `Detection` events:
- `rule_id` (stable)
- `agent_type`
- `event_type` + severity
- confidence score
- extracted JSON facts

## Rationale
The pattern engine is how we translate raw transcripts into “facts” that workflows and operators can trust.
It must be:
- fast (sub-millisecond typical)
- correct (near-zero false positives)
- maintainable (pack system + fixtures)

## Architecture
Tiered matching for performance:
1. Quick reject (`memchr/memmem`) — skip 99%+ of text
2. Aho-Corasick for literal anchors
3. Regex extraction with named captures (tight, anchored)
4. Optional advanced regex (fancy-regex) only when necessary

## Packs
- `core.codex`, `core.claude_code`, `core.gemini`
- `core.wezterm` (mux/server diagnostics)
- `org.local` custom overrides

## Deliverables
- Pack format (in-code or data-driven) with stable IDs.
- Initial rules for Codex/Gemini/Claude compaction per plan.
- State gating integration:
  - detections can require inferred agent match
  - avoid matches in non-agent panes when possible
- Test harness:
  - unit tests per rule
  - golden corpus regression fixtures (input text + expected detections)

## Acceptance
- Known fixtures produce deterministic detections.
- Non-matching text is fast (quick reject).
- Adding a new rule requires only:
  - add rule def
  - add fixture(s)
  - tests pass



## Success Criteria
- Pattern packs load deterministically (stable rule ids, overrides) and PatternEngine can run continuously without leaks.
- Quick reject path keeps typical commands/deltas sub-millisecond (benchmarked in tests/benches where applicable).
- Detections include stable rule ids + extracted facts and are persisted as events.
- Golden corpus harness prevents regression (fixtures fail loudly with actionable diffs).
- Unit/integration tests cover pack parsing, extraction correctness, and engine behavior.


## Testing
- Unit tests are mandatory for every rule:
  - Each rule has at least:
    - a positive fixture
    - a near-miss negative fixture (the “false positive guard”)
    - extraction validation (named captures → structured facts)

- Golden corpus regression harness:
  - Corpus lives as fixtures with explicit expected detections.
  - Failures must show actionable diffs (what changed, which rule, which capture).

- Performance tests:
  - Bench the quick-reject path and common-match path and enforce budgets (see `wa-4vx.10.2`).
  - Include “worst-case” fixtures to avoid regex-timeout surprises.

- Integration/E2E:
  - At least one E2E script per critical workflow-triggering event validates real-ish transcripts still match (compaction, usage limit).

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Success Criteria, Deliverables.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.

title: Define pattern pack format + rule IDs + loading/override strategy
description:
# Task: Define pattern pack format + rule IDs

## Goal
Create a scalable way to define detection rules:
- stable `rule_id`
- literal anchors (for fast matching)
- optional extraction regex (named captures)
- event_type + severity + suggested remediation/workflow

## Why
Hardcoding patterns directly in code does not scale and makes drift painful.

We need a pack abstraction so we can:
- version packs
- add org-local overrides
- test packs independently

## Design options
- v0: built-in packs in Rust (fast, simple).
- v1: data-driven packs (TOML/YAML) loaded from config for extensibility.

Start with built-in packs but design the internal API as if packs could come from config.

## Deliverables
- `PatternPack`, `RuleDef` structs.
- Stable naming scheme for IDs:
  - `codex.*`
  - `claude_code.*`
  - `gemini.*`
  - `wezterm.*`
- Override rules:
  - later packs override earlier packs by `rule_id`

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - enumerating rules is deterministic (stable ordering)
  - override semantics are correct (later pack wins)
  - invalid rule definitions fail fast with actionable errors
- Pack hygiene tests/lints:
  - rule ids are unique and stable
  - each rule has at least one fixture/corpus entry or unit test (enforced by tooling)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Rules can be enumerated programmatically (for `wa robot rules` / `wa rules` later).
- Rule IDs remain stable as packs evolve.
close_reason: Implemented pattern pack format with RuleDef, PatternPack, PatternLibrary structs. Includes builtin packs for Codex, Claude Code, Gemini, and WezTerm with stable rule ID naming (codex.*, claude_code.*, gemini.*, wezterm.*). Supports pack override semantics and has 25 unit tests covering validation, deterministic ordering, and override logic.

title: Implement PatternEngine (quick reject + Aho-Corasick + extraction regex)
description:
# Task: Implement PatternEngine core

## Goal
Implement a high-performance detector that runs on deltas and emits `Detection` objects.

## Architecture
1) Quick reject via memchr/memmem keyword prefilter.
2) Aho-Corasick for literal anchor matches.
3) Extract structured data with regex using named capture groups.
4) Deduplicate overlapping detections.

## Deliverables
- `PatternEngine::detect(text) -> Vec<Detection>`
- Confidence scoring:
  - v0: 1.0 for anchor matches
  - later: refine per-rule confidence
- Dedup function for overlapping detections.

## Performance
- Typical non-matching text must return quickly (fast path).
- Avoid allocations on the hot path where possible.

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - quick reject correctly avoids regex engine for obvious non-matches
  - anchor matching emits expected detections
  - extraction regexes produce expected JSON payloads (named captures)
  - dedup behavior is deterministic
- Golden corpus regression:
  - real-world captures under `tests/corpus/` prevent silent drift
- Property/invariant tests (when feasible):
  - no panics on weird unicode / odd byte sequences
  - stable ordering of detections

## Acceptance Criteria
- Typical non-matching text returns quickly.
- Matching fixtures produce correct detections.
- Per-rule unit tests and golden corpus detect drift/regressions.
close_reason: Completed

title: Implement initial built-in packs: core.codex/core.claude_code/core.gemini (+ core.wezterm stub)
description:
# Task: Implement initial built-in packs

## Goal
Ship the first stable rule set sufficient to drive v0.1 workflows.

## Required rules (minimum)
### Codex
- usage warnings (25/10/5)
- usage reached (retry time)
- token usage summary (total/input/cached/output/reasoning)
- resume hint (session id)
- device auth prompt (device code)

### Claude Code
- compaction anchor
- session banner (version/model) (best-effort)

### Gemini
- usage reached
- session summary (session id)
- model used

### WezTerm
- optional: mux/server diagnostics placeholders

## Deliverables
- Rule definitions with stable IDs and extraction regexes.
- Suggested remediation/workflow hints for:
  - handle_compaction
  - handle_usage_limits

## Testing
- Every rule must have at least one of:
  - a dedicated unit test, OR
  - a golden corpus fixture (`tests/corpus/**/*.txt` + `.expect.json`).

- Drift variants:
  - for each agent pack, include fixtures for at least one “format drift” variant (missing fields, reordered lines, extra banners).

- Safety:
  - extraction must never capture/store secrets; fixtures should include “secret-ish” strings to ensure redaction behavior is exercised.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Every rule has unit tests or corpus fixtures.
- Rule IDs are stable and namespaced by pack.


## Rule IDs (v0; pinned)
This bead is the canonical place for the initial stable rule IDs (derived from PLAN.md Appendix C).

Per the naming scheme in `wa-4vx.5.1`, we use:
- `codex.*`
- `claude_code.*`
- `gemini.*`
- (`wezterm.*` reserved)

### Codex (`core.codex`)
| rule_id | anchors (fast path) | extraction (named) | event_type |
|--------|----------------------|--------------------|-----------|
| `codex.usage.warning_25` | `less than 25%` | `remaining`, `limit_hours` | `usage.warning` |
| `codex.usage.warning_10` | `less than 10%` | `remaining`, `limit_hours` | `usage.warning` |
| `codex.usage.warning_5` | `less than 5%` | `remaining`, `limit_hours` | `usage.warning` |
| `codex.usage.reached` | `You've hit your usage limit` | `try_again_at` | `usage.reached` |
| `codex.session.token_usage` | `Token usage:` | `total`, `input`, `cached`, `output`, `reasoning` | `session.summary` |
| `codex.session.resume_hint` | `codex resume` | `session_id` | `session.resume_hint` |
| `codex.auth.device_code_prompt` | `Enter this one-time code` | `code` | `auth.device_code` |

### Claude Code (`core.claude_code`)
| rule_id | anchors | extraction | event_type |
|--------|---------|------------|-----------|
| `claude_code.compaction` | `Conversation compacted` | none | `session.compaction` |
| `claude_code.banner` | `Claude Code v` | `version`, `model` (best-effort) | `session.start` |
| `claude_code.usage.warning` | (evolves) | (evolves) | `usage.warning` |
| `claude_code.usage.reached` | (evolves) | (evolves) | `usage.reached` |

### Gemini (`core.gemini`)
| rule_id | anchors | extraction | event_type |
|--------|---------|------------|-----------|
| `gemini.usage.reached` | `Usage limit reached for all Pro models` | none | `usage.reached` |
| `gemini.session.summary` | `Interaction Summary` | `session_id` | `session.summary` |
| `gemini.model.used` | `Responding with gemini-` | `model` | `session.model` |

### Naming note (PLAN vs wa conventions)
PLAN Appendix C.2 shows rule ids prefixed with `claude.*` (e.g., `claude.compaction`). The pack name, however, is `core.claude_code`.

To avoid ambiguity in our own namespaces, we standardize on `claude_code.*` internally.

Mapping (plan → canonical):
- `claude.compaction` → `claude_code.compaction`
- `claude.banner` → `claude_code.banner`
- `claude.usage.warning` → `claude_code.usage.warning`
- `claude.usage.reached` → `claude_code.usage.reached`

If we ever choose to support aliases, do it at the pack boundary (do not fork semantics).

### Notes / invariants
- IDs above are stable: we prefer improving match robustness (anchors/regex) while keeping IDs stable.
- If we must represent genuinely different semantics, add a new rule id rather than mutating an old one.
- Every rule above must have fixtures (positive + near-miss negative) and extraction validation.
close_reason: All 51 pattern tests pass. Built-in packs for Codex, Claude Code, Gemini, and WezTerm implemented with anchor-based detection and regex extraction.

description:
# Task: Pattern tests + golden corpus

Patterns are the “sensory system” of wa; if they drift silently, automation becomes unreliable.

  1) capture real output
  2) drop into `tests/corpus/<agent>/...`
  3) run tests to see the diff

title: ast-grep tooling: enforce pattern code organization + ban ad-hoc regex usage
description:
# Task: ast-grep tooling for pattern development (codebase lints)

## Goal
Use `ast-grep` to enforce *structural* codebase constraints that keep the detection system maintainable:
- rule definitions live in the pattern system (packs / dedicated module)
- ad-hoc regex usage for detection is disallowed outside the pattern engine
- tests/fixtures exist for rules and for any code that defines patterns

This implements the “Rule development tooling” part of PLAN.md §6.4 ast-grep Integration.

## Why
Pattern drift is inevitable. What kills projects is when:
- patterns are sprinkled throughout the codebase
- regex logic grows “organically” without tests
- contributors add quick hacks to fix one drift case and accidentally increase false positives

A structure-aware lint is the fastest way to prevent long-term entropy.

## Deliverables
- An `ast-grep` ruleset (committed with the repo) that enforces:
  1) **No ad-hoc detection regex in non-pattern modules**
     - Example: forbid `Regex::new("...")` in most modules except the pattern engine / pack loader.

  2) **Pattern definitions centralized**
     - Any new pattern rule must be added via the pack system (`wa-4vx.5.1`) rather than inline matching.

  3) **Tests/fixtures exist**
     - When rule definitions are modified, ensure there is at least one:
       - unit test, or
       - golden corpus fixture

- A documented “how to run” workflow for contributors:
  - `ast-grep` invocations and how to interpret failures

- Optional CI integration (recommended):
  - run the ast-grep ruleset in CI for changed Rust files

## Testing
- Meta-tests for the lints themselves:
  - include small fixture Rust snippets that should pass
  - include small fixture Rust snippets that should fail

- CI test:
  - ensure the ast-grep tool is invoked and failures are actionable

## Acceptance Criteria
- A contributor cannot accidentally add new detection regex logic outside the pattern system without CI catching it.
- Lint failures point to a precise file:line:col with an actionable message.
close_reason: ast-grep tooling implemented: rule, lint script with allowlist, self-tests, and fixtures. See sgconfig.yml, rules/, scripts/lint-patterns.sh

title: [EPIC] Watcher daemon runtime (observe loop + subscriptions)
description:
# Watcher daemon runtime

## Goal
Provide the long-running `wa watch` process that ties together:
- pane discovery + ingest tailers
- storage writer
- pattern detection
- event feeds (robot/MCP subscriptions)

while maintaining the critical split:
- Observation loop never mutates terminal state
- Action loop (workflows) is separate and guarded

## Why this exists
Most value comes from continuous monitoring. The daemon is the “always-on nervous system”.

## Deliverables
- `wa watch` command that:
  - starts ingest pipeline
  - persists segments/events
  - runs pattern engine
  - optionally emits metrics and health snapshots
- subscription surfaces:
  - robot/MCP can read state/events from wa without re-polling WezTerm
- lifecycle:
  - clean shutdown with DB flush
  - restart safety (no corrupt state)

## Acceptance
- `wa watch` runs for hours without leak or drift.
- Idle overhead is low due to adaptive polling.
- Health output shows queue depth + lag + DB write status.



## Success Criteria
- `wa watch` runs as a single-instance, workspace-scoped daemon (lock enforced) with graceful shutdown.
- Observation pipeline runs end-to-end: discover panes → tail → persist → detect → persist events.
- IPC lane (user-var events) delivers signals reliably to the watcher.
- Health/metrics/logging make failures diagnosable; crash reports are redacted and actionable.
- Integration tests validate runtime wiring without requiring a real WezTerm session; E2E validates with a real mux server.


## Testing
- Integration tests (synthetic):
  - Drive the runtime with deterministic delta fixtures (no WezTerm required) and assert:
    - segments/events persisted
    - health snapshot reports expected queue depths/lag
    - graceful shutdown flushes writer queue
  - Include “crash/panic path” tests to ensure crash report generation is redacted and bounded.

- E2E tests (real-ish):
  - At least one runner scenario exercises a real `wa watch` lifecycle (start → ingest → stop → restart) and validates artifacts (`wa-4vx.10.15`, `wa-4vx.10.21`).

- Logging observability tests:
  - Verify per-pane correlation IDs and structured fields exist and can be used to reconstruct a workflow failure from logs alone.

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Success Criteria, Deliverables.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.
close_reason: All child tasks completed. Watcher daemon runtime implemented with observe loop, discovery, tailers, persistence, pattern detection, IPC, and hot-reload.

title: Implement `wa watch` CLI command (args, lifecycle, graceful shutdown)
description:
# Task: Implement wa watch CLI command

## Goal
Provide the entry point for the long-running watcher/daemon.

This is the command users run to "turn wa on".

## Workspace + config UX (critical)
wa watch must not make users guess where state lives.

- Accept workspace selection:
  - --workspace <path>
  - WA_WORKSPACE
- Accept config selection:
  - --config <path> (optional override)
  - otherwise load from OS-default config location
- Always print (in verbose logs and/or startup banner) the resolved paths:
  - workspace root
  - DB path
  - lock path
  - IPC socket path
  - log file path (if enabled)

## Requirements
- Starts the observation runtime.
- Acquires the workspace single-instance lock before doing any work.
- Supports safe shutdown:
  - stops ingest
  - drains channels
  - flushes DB writer queue
  - closes IPC endpoints
  - releases lock

## Flags (v0)
- poll interval override
- enable/disable pattern detection
- (Phase 2) enable workflows / auto-handle
- (Phase 4) metrics bind
- logging verbosity / log-to-file toggle

## Testing
- Integration tests:
  - start/stop lifecycle acquires/releases lock deterministically
  - graceful shutdown flushes storage writer queue
  - restart in same workspace succeeds (no stale lock)
- E2E:
  - `wa-4vx.10.7` (capture+FTS), `wa-4vx.10.15` (graceful shutdown), `wa-4vx.10.21` (wa stop), and related cases exercise wa watch under real mux

## Acceptance Criteria
- wa watch uses the shared config loader and workspace resolution (no ad-hoc paths).
- wa watch can be stopped cleanly and exits quickly even under load.
- After shutdown, restarting wa watch in the same workspace works (lock released, DB usable).
close_reason: Implemented wa watch CLI command with: --poll-interval, --no-patterns, --auto-handle, --foreground flags. Prints resolved paths on startup. Creates storage, pattern engine, and ObservationRuntime. Handles SIGINT/SIGTERM for graceful shutdown.

title: Daemon integration tests using synthetic deltas (no WezTerm required)
description:
# Task: Daemon integration tests (synthetic deltas)

## Goal
Test the full observation pipeline without requiring a live WezTerm instance.

This is the test bed for the core architecture:
`ingest → persist segments → pattern engine → persist detections/events`.

## Approach
- Construct a synthetic pane + domain model.
- Feed synthetic `PaneDelta` segments into the event bus:
  - include prompt markers / OSC 133 boundaries
  - include text that should trigger known patterns
  - include a deliberate discontinuity to force a GAP path

- Assert end-to-end outcomes:
  - segments are persisted
  - gaps are recorded when expected
  - pattern engine emits detections
  - detections are persisted as events

## Determinism requirements
- No timing-based assertions.
- Use deterministic clocks or explicit timestamps in test inputs.
- Use temp DBs and fixed ordering.

## Logging requirements
- Tests should capture structured logs and assert:
  - ingest tick ran
  - counts of segments/events written
  - no panics or busy loops

## Acceptance Criteria
- Tests pass in CI environments without WezTerm.
- A regression in any stage (ingest/persist/pattern/event) fails with a clear assertion.


## Testing
- Meta-validation:
  - Include at least one fixture that would *not* match any pattern to ensure quick-reject/no-match path is exercised.
  - Include an explicit “GAP required” fixture and assert the GAP record exists (prove the discontinuity path is truly tested).

- Observability assertions:
  - Assert structured log fields include per-pane identifiers and stage counters so failures can be triaged quickly.

title: Structured logging baseline: tracing spans, per-pane correlation ids, log-to-file option
description:
# Task: Structured logging baseline

## Goal
Make `wa` debuggable under real load and make E2E/diagnostic artifacts useful.

This is the baseline logging layer used by:
- `wa watch` runtime
- robot/human CLI commands
- E2E harness artifacts (`wa-4vx.10.6`, `wa-4vx.10.11`)

## Requirements
- Use `tracing` + `tracing-subscriber` (no ad-hoc `println!`).
- Support both:
  - human-friendly pretty logs (interactive default)
  - JSON logs (machine-parseable; required for CI/E2E/ops)

## Required fields / correlation
Key spans and events must include (where applicable):
- `workspace`
- `domain`
- `pane_id`
- `window_id`/`tab_id` (when available)
- `rule_id` / `event_id`
- `workflow_name` / `execution_id`
- `action_id` (audit linkage)

## Configuration
- `log_level`:
  - from config
  - overridable via `RUST_LOG`
- `log_format`: `pretty | json`
- `log_file`: optional path; when set, logs are written to file (E2E/diag bundles rely on this)

## Safety / redaction
- Never log raw pane contents.
- Any user-provided text that could contain secrets must be logged only via the redaction layer (`wa-4vx.8.3`).
- JSON logs must not include secrets, device codes, auth tokens, cookies, or full DOM dumps.

## Implementation notes
- Prefer a single global subscriber configured once at startup.
- Ensure JSON logging is valid even under concurrent spans.
- Include a stable timestamp field for JSON logs.

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - logger initialization does not panic
  - JSON log lines parse as JSON
  - required correlation fields appear on key spans (where practical via helper macros)
  - redaction invariants: known secret patterns do not appear in emitted log lines

- E2E:
  - harness captures logs reliably and includes them in artifacts (`wa-4vx.10.6`, `wa-4vx.10.11`)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Running `wa watch` emits structured logs with pane/domain correlation fields.
- JSON logging mode produces parseable JSON lines.
- E2E runs can enable verbose logging and capture it to an artifacts directory without code changes.
close_reason: Implemented structured logging baseline with JSON/pretty formats, correlation fields, and redaction integration. All 355 tests pass.

title: Watcher IPC receiver: accept user-var events over local socket; update state; emit signals
description:
# Task: Watcher IPC receiver (user-var events)

## Goal
Allow short-lived `wa event` processes (spawned by WezTerm) to deliver pane signals to the long-running watcher.

## Design
- Watcher opens a local unix socket (path in config).
- Message format: small JSON envelope:
  - pane_id
  - event_type (e.g., user_var, status_update)
  - name
  - value (raw + optional decoded JSON)
  - received_at
- Receiver task:
  - accepts connections
  - reads one message
  - validates size limits
  - enqueues into the event bus as a `Signal` event

## How the watcher uses the signal
- Update per-pane state if relevant (e.g., prompt boundary checkpoint or status_update metadata).
- Optionally persist as a separate table (`pane_signals`) if we want historical record.

## Failure behavior
- If message is invalid/too large: reject with an error (do not crash watcher).
- Logging: do not log raw payload content by default.

## Testing
- Unit/integration test starts the receiver, sends a synthetic event, and observes it on the event bus.

## Acceptance Criteria
- A synthetic `wa event` message reaches the watcher and appears on the internal event bus.
- Invalid payloads are rejected safely with clear errors and without logging raw secrets.
close_reason: Implementation complete. IpcServer and IpcClient fully working with UserVar/Ping/Status support. All 6 tests pass.

title: Watcher single-instance lock: prevent multiple wa watch writers per workspace
description:
# Task: Watcher single-instance lock (workspace guard)

## Goal
Prevent accidental multi-instance runs of `wa watch` that:
- compete for the same SQLite DB and cause busy loops or confusing interleavings
- duplicate ingest work and distort event timelines
- race on IPC endpoints (user-var lane socket)

Users should get a clear, actionable error instead of subtle corruption or "it feels flaky".

## Behavior (v0)
- On startup, `wa watch` acquires an exclusive lock scoped to the selected workspace/DB.
- Lock file lives under the workspace scope (`wa-4vx.9.6` conventions).
- If the lock is already held:
  - exit non-zero with a stable error code
  - print a message that includes:
    - workspace path
    - pid/host if recorded
    - a safe remediation (stop the other watcher, or run with an explicit override)

## Locking details
- Use an OS-level file lock (not just a pid file).
- Record diagnostic metadata adjacent to the lock (pid, started_at, wa version) for humans.

## Overrides (escape hatch)
Provide an explicit, scary flag (proposed): `--dangerous-disable-lock`.

Rules:
- If `--dangerous-disable-lock` is used, require the user to also provide an explicit `--db <path>` that is distinct, OR print a warning that they may corrupt timelines.

The goal is to make “I really want two watchers” possible, but never accidental.

## Testing
- Unit/integration tests:
  - first instance acquires lock successfully
  - second instance fails with stable error + hint
  - lock is released on clean shutdown
  - crash-y path: simulate a process exit and confirm the lock is not permanently wedged

## Acceptance Criteria
- Running two `wa watch` processes against the same workspace fails fast and explains why.
- The lock mechanism is robust across crashes (lock releases when process dies).
close_reason: Implemented single-instance lock with fs2 crate. Lock module at crates/wa-core/src/lock.rs with WatcherLock, LockMetadata, and sidecar JSON. Integrated into run_watcher with --dangerous-disable-lock flag for override. Build passes; tests blocked by unrelated lifetime errors in policy.rs.

title: Watcher lifecycle hardening: SIGINT/SIGTERM shutdown + panic crash report
description:
# Task: Watcher lifecycle hardening

## Goal
Make `wa watch` behave like a trustworthy daemon:
- shuts down cleanly on SIGINT/SIGTERM
- flushes and closes storage without leaving the DB in a confusing partial state
- produces actionable crash artifacts on panic

This is pure UX/reliability: users must be able to stop wa without fear.

## Requirements
### Graceful shutdown
- On SIGINT/SIGTERM:
  - stop ingest polling
  - drain/close channels
  - flush StorageHandle writer queue
  - close IPC endpoints
  - release workspace lock
- Emit a short shutdown summary (logs):
  - elapsed
  - final queue depths
  - last persisted seq per pane (optional if cheap)

### Panic/crash reporting
- Install a panic hook that:
  - writes a crash report artifact in the workspace artifacts dir
  - includes backtrace + build/version + workspace id
  - includes last-known health snapshot (queue depth, ingest lag)
  - is redacted (no raw pane text)

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - shutdown path drains queue and closes cleanly
- Integration tests:
  - synthetic ingest load + SIGINT simulation → clean exit
  - panic simulation → crash report file layout + redaction
- E2E:
  - `wa-4vx.10.15` graceful shutdown
  - `wa-4vx.10.21` `wa stop` coordination

## Acceptance Criteria
- Ctrl-C during heavy ingest does not lose already-enqueued writes.
- A panic produces an artifact that enables debugging without reproducing.

title: [EPIC] Robot mode CLI (stable JSON envelope + core commands)
description:
# Robot mode CLI

## Goal
Provide an agent-first CLI surface that is:
- stable (schema + error codes)
- token-efficient
- composable
- functionally complete for core operations

Robot mode is how an AI agent controls wa without relying on UI.

## Contract
Every robot command returns a consistent JSON envelope:
- ok/data/error/hint/elapsed_ms/version/now

## Core commands (minimum)
- `wa robot state` — list panes + inferred agent/state
- `wa robot get-text <pane_id>` — read tail or full text
- `wa robot send <pane_id> <text>` — send input (guarded)
- `wa robot wait-for <pane_id> <pattern>` — wait with timeout
- `wa robot search <fts query>` — query SQLite FTS
- `wa robot events` — recent/unhandled events
- `wa robot workflow <name> <pane_id>` — trigger workflow (Phase 2 will implement)
- `wa robot quick-start` — high-density help output

## Why this exists
Human-first CLIs are too verbose and inconsistent for agent consumption.
Robot mode must be deterministic so agents can compose reliable loops.

## Acceptance
- All commands work without interactive prompts.
- Error codes are stable and actionable.



## Success Criteria
- `wa robot` commands have stable JSON envelopes and versioned schemas for outputs/errors.
- Robot surfaces can query panes/state/events/search and perform policy-gated actions (send/workflow) safely.
- All robot outputs are validated in unit tests against JSON schemas.
- E2E scripts exercise robot commands as part of end-to-end scenarios with detailed artifacts.


## Testing
- Schema validation:
  - Robot outputs and errors are validated against versioned JSON schemas (see `wa-4vx.7.10`).
  - Tests must validate stable `error.code` values and stable envelope shape across commands.

- Contract tests:
  - For each command, include “happy path” + at least one failure mode (pane missing, invalid args, DB not initialized, policy denied).
  - Ensure error messages remain actionable but do not leak secrets.

- E2E coverage:
  - Robot commands are exercised as building blocks inside end-to-end scenarios (search, send gating, workflow triggers) with artifacts.

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Success Criteria.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.
close_reason: All child tasks completed: wa-4vx.7.1 through wa-4vx.7.10 closed. Robot mode CLI implemented with stable JSON envelope and all core commands.

description:
# Task: Robot mode scaffolding

## Goal
Build the foundational CLI plumbing for `wa robot`.

Robot mode is an API surface for other tools/agents. It must be:
- stable
- machine-parseable
- explicit about errors and hints

## Requirements
### Subcommand structure
- Define a clear subcommand tree per plan.
- Centralize handler dispatch.

### Global flags (critical UX)
All robot subcommands must accept consistent global flags:
- --workspace <path> / WA_WORKSPACE
- --config <path> (optional)

Robots must not guess where the DB is.

### Output contract
- Stable JSON envelope:
  - ok / data / error / hint / elapsed_ms / version / now
- Stable error codes (string constants).

## Deliverables
- CLI parsing + dispatch to handlers.
- Shared response builder.
- Shared "context" builder that resolves:
  - effective config
  - workspace paths (DB/lock/socket/log)
  - and hands them to handlers

## Testing
- Unit/integration tests:
  - envelope shape is stable and schema-validated (`wa-4vx.7.10`)
  - unknown subcommand yields a structured error
  - `--workspace` changes scope deterministically
  - handlers can be tested with a fixture workspace without a real WezTerm

## Acceptance Criteria
- `wa robot help` prints stable JSON.
- Unknown subcommand yields a structured error.
- Passing --workspace changes the DB/workspace scope deterministically.

## Goal
Make the wa robot API contract explicit, versioned, and mechanically validated.

Robot mode is an API. Treating it like "just CLI output" is how integrations break.

## Deliverables
- Versioned JSON Schema files committed to the repo, e.g.:
  - docs/json-schema/wa-robot-envelope.json
  - docs/json-schema/wa-robot-state.json
  - docs/json-schema/wa-robot-search.json
  - docs/json-schema/wa-robot-events.json

  - **docs/json-schema/wa-robot-reservations.json**
  - **docs/json-schema/wa-robot-reserve.json**
  - **docs/json-schema/wa-robot-release.json**

- Clear versioning rules
  - bump schema versions intentionally
  - document backward/forward expectations (even if we don't promise long-term compatibility)

title: wa robot accounts - JSON account listing
description:
## Summary
Implement `wa robot accounts` command that provides JSON-formatted account information for AI agents to query API account status, usage, and rate limits.

## Background & Rationale
From PLAN.md Appendix A.2 Robot Commands:
```
wa robot accounts [--service <openai|anthropic|google>]
```

AI agents need programmatic access to account information to:
1. Check remaining API credits/tokens before starting expensive operations
2. Verify account authentication status
3. Query rate limit status and reset times
4. Make intelligent decisions about which service to use

This is the robot-mode counterpart to the human CLI `wa accounts` command (wa-nu4.3.2.5).

## Implementation Details

### Command Structure
```bash
wa robot accounts                           # All services
wa robot accounts --service anthropic       # Specific service
wa robot accounts --refresh                 # Force refresh cached data
```

### JSON Output Schema
```json
{
  "ok": true,
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "command": "accounts",
  "data": {
    "accounts": [
      {
        "service": "anthropic",
        "status": "active",
        "authenticated": true,
        "usage": {
          "tokens_used": 150000,
          "tokens_limit": 1000000,
          "reset_at": "2025-02-01T00:00:00Z"
        },
        "rate_limit": {
          "requests_remaining": 450,
          "reset_at": "2025-01-18T12:00:00Z"
        }
      }
    ],
    "cached_at": "2025-01-18T10:30:00Z"
  }
}
```

### Error Cases (from Appendix B)
- E_CONFIG_INVALID: Invalid service name
- E_AUTH_FAILED: Authentication failed for service
- E_NETWORK: Network error checking account

### Implementation Notes
1. Reuse account checking logic from wa-nu4.3.2.5 (human CLI)
2. Cache results with configurable TTL (default 5 minutes)
3. Support --refresh flag to bypass cache
4. Handle partial failures gracefully (some services may fail)

## Success Criteria
- [ ] `wa robot accounts` returns valid JSON for all configured services
- [ ] `wa robot accounts --service X` filters to single service
- [ ] `--refresh` flag bypasses cache
- [ ] Error codes match Appendix B specification
- [ ] Output schema is versioned and documented
- [ ] Unit tests for JSON serialization
- [ ] Integration test with mock account data

## Dependencies
- wa-4vx.7.1 (robot scaffolding) - for JSON envelope and error codes
- wa-nu4.3.2.5 (human accounts command) - shares account checking logic

title: wa robot rules test - JSON pattern testing

## Summary
Implement `wa robot rules test` command that allows AI agents to test text against pattern rules and get JSON-formatted match results.

## Background & Rationale
From PLAN.md Appendix A.2 Robot Commands:
```
wa robot rules test "<text>" [--agent <type>]
```

AI agents need to test patterns programmatically to:
1. Validate pattern matching before deploying workflows
2. Debug why patterns aren't matching expected text
3. Test custom patterns during development
4. Extract named captures from test text

This is the robot-mode counterpart to the human CLI `wa rules test` command (wa-nu4.3.2.6).

## Implementation Details

### Command Structure
```bash
wa robot rules test "some text to test"                    # Test against all patterns
wa robot rules test "text" --agent claude                  # Test agent-specific patterns
wa robot rules test "text" --pack my_pack                  # Test specific pack
wa robot rules test "text" --pattern "regex" --extract    # Test custom pattern
```

```json
{
  "ok": true,
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "command": "rules.test",
  "data": {
    "input_length": 150,
    "matches": [
```

- E_PATTERN_INVALID: Invalid custom regex

title: Implement `wa robot state` (live panes + DB enrichment + inferred agent/state)
description:
# Task: `wa robot state`

## Goal
Return a **single canonical JSON view** of all panes so agents can decide what to do next.

## Output fields (v0)
Per-pane (minimum):
- `pane_id`
- `domain`
- `title`
- `cwd` (raw + normalized path)
- `pane_state`:
  - prompt_active
  - command_running
  - alt_screen
  - recent_gap
- `last_activity` timestamp
- `unhandled_event_count`
- `observed` / `ignored` + ignore reason
- **reservation state** (if present):
  - owner_kind / owner_id
  - reason
  - expires_at
- **optional live metadata** (when available from status_update IPC):
  - cursor (row/col)
  - dimensions (cols/rows)
  - is_active

## Data sources
- WezTerm list panes (live)
- DB enrichment for:
  - unhandled events
  - reservation state
  - last detection timestamps
- Optional IPC status updates for cursor/dimensions/active state

## Error behavior
- Stable error codes for:
  - WezTerm unreachable
  - workspace/DB unavailable

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - deterministic ordering of panes
  - error shape stability
- Integration tests:
  - DB enrichment fields are present and correct
  - reservation fields present when a reservation exists
  - cursor/dimensions appear when status_update events have been received

## Acceptance Criteria
- Robot state is stable, deterministic, and sufficient for agents to select a pane safely.
notes:
Background / Why:
- Robot state is the canonical snapshot for automation; it prevents unsafe guesswork.
- A stable snapshot reduces repeated DB queries and log scraping.

Considerations:
- Keep ordering deterministic and include ignore reasons for privacy.
- Any live-vs-DB mismatches should be surfaced explicitly.

Logging / Observability:
- Log state refresh timings and pane counts (observed/ignored).
- Emit structured warnings when live data and DB differ.

title: Implement `wa robot get-text` (tail/escapes options, robust errors)
description:
# Task: wa robot get-text

## Goal
Fetch pane text for agent decision-making.

This is the primary read primitive for:
- agent reasoning loops
- wait-for verification
- workflow waits (indirectly)

## Requirements
- Supports tail N lines (token-efficient; default should be small).
- Supports --escapes for ANSI parsing use cases (e.g., best-effort alt-screen detection).
- Returns structured error if pane not found.
- Honors global flags:
  - --workspace / WA_WORKSPACE
  - --config (optional)

## Output contract
- Always returns the stable robot envelope.
- Data includes:
  - pane_id
  - requested tail_lines
  - whether escapes were included
  - text payload

## Safety / performance
- Avoid reading excessive scrollback by default.
- Never log pane content.
- Enforce output-size limits (truncate deterministically and report truncation metadata).

## Testing
- Unit/integration tests:
  - output validates against the robot schema (`wa-4vx.7.10`)
  - tail line truncation is deterministic and includes truncation metadata
  - `--escapes` behavior is stable on fixtures
  - error mapping is stable for:
    - pane not found
    - wezterm not running
    - wezterm get-text failures

## Acceptance Criteria
- Works on live panes.
- Errors are stable and actionable (pane not found, wezterm not running, get-text failure).
notes:
Background / Why:
- get-text is the primary read primitive for agents; stability prevents brittle parsing.
- Safe bounds avoid accidental large payloads.

Considerations:
- Enforce size limits with deterministic truncation metadata.
- Preserve a stable escaping policy.

Logging / Observability:
- Log request parameters (pane_id, tail_lines, escapes) but never raw pane text.
- Emit structured errors for missing panes/wezterm failures.
close_reason: Implemented with tail/escapes options, stable error codes, truncation metadata, RobotGetTextData struct. Tests pass.

title: Implement `wa robot send` (PolicyEngine-gated, optional wait-for, timeout)
description:
# Task: wa robot send

## Goal
Send input to a pane safely and optionally wait for a pattern.

This is the highest-risk robot command and must be conservative by default.

## Safety requirements
- Must pass PolicyEngine authorization before sending.
- Must never send into AltScreen or RecentGap panes.
- Must apply rate limiting.
- Must emit an audit record for allow/deny/require-approval outcomes.

## Features
- `--no-newline`
- `--wait-for <pattern>` + `--timeout-secs N` (optional verification)
- `--dry-run` (no injection; return policy decision + redacted preview of what would be sent)

## Workspace/config
- Honors global flags:
  - `--workspace` / `WA_WORKSPACE`
  - `--config` (optional)

## Implementation notes
- Reuse the shared PaneWaiter (`wa-4vx.2.6`) for all wait-for verification logic.
  - Avoid duplicated polling loops.
  - Use shared backoff/timeout/cancellation semantics.
- Output must be stable and validated against robot schemas (`wa-4vx.7.10`).
- When wait-for is requested, include verification outcome details in the audit trail emission layer.

## Testing
- Unit/integration tests validate:
  - allow/deny/require-approval are stable outcomes
  - `--dry-run` never injects input
  - wait-for succeeds/fails deterministically with timeout

## Acceptance Criteria
- Denies sends when policy requires (deny/require-approval are both explicit outcomes).
- `--dry-run` never injects input and returns a stable, redacted preview + policy decision.
- Wait-for succeeds/fails deterministically with timeout.
- Output error codes are stable and actionable.
notes:
Background / Why:
- Send is highest risk; explicit constraints prevent unsafe automation.
- A uniform send API keeps workflows and robots consistent.

Considerations:
- Always go through PolicyEngine and audit; no bypass.
- Wait-for must reuse shared waiter to avoid divergent behavior.

Logging / Observability:
- Audit allow/deny/require-approval with rule_ids and redacted previews.
- Log wait-for timeouts with correlation ids.
close_reason: Implementation complete. Robot send command with PolicyEngine gating, dry-run, wait-for verification, approval integration, and audit trail all working.

title: Quick-start mode (no args) + `wa robot quick-start` output tuned for agents
description:
# Task: Robot quick-start output

## Goal
When invoked with no args (or via explicit command), output a dense, agent-friendly quick start.

This is a critical UX surface for agents:
- it teaches the stable contract (envelope + schemas)
- it reduces “guessing” about workspace/config
- it points to the safest default actions first

## Invocation
Support at least one (either is fine; both is ideal):
- `wa robot` (no subcommand) → quick-start
- `wa robot quick-start` → quick-start

## Output requirements
- Must be **stable JSON** (robot envelope) and validated against schemas (`wa-4vx.7.10`).
- Must be minimal tokens but still actionable.
- Must include:
  - a short description of wa robot mode
  - the canonical global flags:
    - `--workspace` / `WA_WORKSPACE`
    - `--config`
  - the “core loop” for an agent:
    1) `wa robot state`
    2) pick `pane_id`
    3) `wa robot get-text` / `wa robot search`
    4) `wa robot send --dry-run` (safety-first)
    5) `wa robot send` (only when policy allows)
  - references to safety expectations:
    - sends are policy-gated
    - `--dry-run` exists
    - how RequireApproval is surfaced (and how a human can approve)

## Design notes
- Treat this as a *structured help payload*, not a prose wall.
- Prefer a JSON structure like:
  - `commands: [{name, args, summary, examples[]}]`
  - `tips: [...]`
  - `error_handling: { common_codes: [...] }`

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - output validates against the quick-start schema
  - output includes the required command list and flags
  - output remains “small enough” (token/byte budget) so it’s usable in agent loops
- E2E:
  - runner can invoke the command and capture artifacts (stdout JSON + stderr logs)

## Acceptance Criteria
- `wa robot` (no subcommand) and/or `wa robot quick-start` returns a stable JSON payload that teaches an agent how to use wa safely.
- The output is schema-validated and regression-tested (snapshot or schema validation + key field asserts).

title: Robot mode tests: envelope stability, error codes, command outputs (synthetic)
description:
# Task: Robot mode tests

## Goal
Prevent breaking changes in robot schemas and error codes.

Robot mode is the primary API surface for other tools/agents. A minor formatting change can break automation.

## Coverage

### Envelope stability
- Assert the JSON envelope contains the expected top-level fields (and only intentional additions):
  - ok
  - data (on success)
  - error (on failure)
  - hint (optional)
  - elapsed_ms
  - version
  - now

### Error code stability
- For common error cases, assert:
  - error.code is stable
  - error.message is actionable
  - hint is present when it improves remediation

### Command-level contract tests (incremental)
- **Phase 1 robot commands:**
  - state
  - get-text
  - search
  - events
  - send
  - wait-for

- **Harmonized commands (bd-h1ai):**
  - why (bd-1dnn - implemented)
  - approve (bd-39wn)
  - workflow run/list/status/abort (bd-qvbz tests these)

- **Later phases:**
  - accounts / accounts-refresh
  - rules list/test
  - reservations / reserve / release

## Schema approach
- Validate outputs against versioned JSON schemas (wa-4vx.7.10) in addition to snapshots.
- Snapshots are still useful for human review (especially for error payloads), but schema validation is the real guardrail.

## Testing Requirements

### Robot Why Tests
```rust
#[test]
fn test_robot_why_known_code() {
    let output = execute_robot(&["why", "deny.alt_screen"]);
    assert!(output["ok"].as_bool().unwrap());
    assert!(!output["data"]["explanation"].as_str().unwrap().is_empty());
}

#[test]
fn test_robot_why_unknown_code() {
    let output = execute_robot(&["why", "unknown.code"]);
    assert!(!output["ok"].as_bool().unwrap());
    // Should include list of valid codes
    assert!(output["hint"].as_str().unwrap().contains("available codes"));
}
```

### Robot Approve Tests
See bd-39wn for comprehensive approve testing.

### Workflow Subcommand Tests
See bd-qvbz for comprehensive workflow testing.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Tests fail if:
  - a required field is removed/renamed
  - an error code changes
  - output becomes non-JSON or non-deterministic

## Meta-validation
- Include a "schema + snapshot mismatch" test to ensure both systems are actually running (not silently skipped).
- Add at least one test per command that asserts deterministic field ordering (or explicitly documents if ordering is not guaranteed).

title: [Robot] `wa robot wait-for` (pattern wait with timeout, robust errors)
description:
# Task: wa robot wait-for

## Goal
Provide a dedicated robot command for waiting until a pane satisfies a condition without sending input.

This is a core building block for:
- agent orchestration loops (avoid sleeping blindly)
- workflows (shared wait logic)
- tests (deterministic sync points)

## Behavior
Command:
- wa robot wait-for <pane_id> "<pattern>" [--timeout-secs N] [--tail N] [--regex]

Semantics:
- Repeatedly poll the pane tail using the same underlying pane text acquisition as wa robot get-text.
- Default matcher is plain substring.
- Optional --regex enables regex matcher (must be explicit).
- Return success when matched.
- Return a stable error when timeout occurs.

## Workspace/config
- Honors global flags:
  - --workspace / WA_WORKSPACE
  - --config (optional)

## Implementation notes
- Use the shared PaneWaiter (wa-4vx.2.6) so robot, workflows, and send verification have identical polling/backoff semantics.
- Avoid logging full pane content.

## Error model (stable)
- WA-ROBOT-PANE-NOT-FOUND
- WA-ROBOT-TIMEOUT
- WA-ROBOT-GET-TEXT-FAILED

## Logging
- Log at INFO when:
  - starting wait (pane_id, timeout)
  - success (elapsed)
  - timeout

## Testing
- Unit tests with a synthetic pane/text source:
  - returns success when the pattern appears
  - returns timeout with stable error envelope
  - regex mode requires explicit flag

## Acceptance Criteria
- With a synthetic fixture, wait-for returns success when the pattern appears.
- Timeout returns a stable error envelope with elapsed_ms and a remediation hint.

title: [EPIC] Safety & policy engine (capability gates, rate limits, redaction)
description:
# Safety & policy engine

## Goal
Ensure wa never becomes a liability by enforcing deterministic safety constraints before any action that mutates state.

## Why this is critical
We are automating typing into terminals running powerful tools. A single wrong send can cause data loss.
We therefore treat action authorization as a first-class subsystem.

## Design requirements
- **Capability-based gates** (deterministic):
  - never send into alt-screen
  - require prompt-active for SendText where possible (OSC 133)
  - block SendText if output gap indicates uncertain state
- **Rate limiting** per pane and per action kind
- **Approval modes**:
  - interactive: prompt user for approvals
  - robot/mcp: return `RequireApproval` as an error with a clear reason
- **Secret redaction** for audit logs and outputs

## Deliverables
- `ActionKind` classification (SendText/Spawn/Split/BrowserAuth/WriteFile/ExecuteWorkflow/etc.)
- `PolicyEngine` evaluation:
  - allow/deny/require-approval
  - rule table loaded from config
- `Redactor`:
  - recognize API key patterns, tokens, passwords
  - ensure secrets never appear in logs or robot output
- Integration points:
  - all sends and workflows must call policy authorize

## Acceptance
- Attempting SendText while pane is AltScreen or CommandRunning is denied.
- Policy logs include redacted input.
- Robot mode returns stable error codes for denied actions.



## Success Criteria
- All input injection paths are policy-gated (robot/human/workflow) with safe defaults.
- Policy decisions are explainable (stable reasons + rule ids) and auditable (including denials).
- Secret redaction is applied consistently to logs/audit/export artifacts.
- Approval (allow-once) works with tight scoping and TTL, and is audited.
- Unit/integration tests cover capability gates, rate limiting, redaction, and approval behavior; E2E covers deny/approve flows.


## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - Capability gate matrix: {PromptActive, CommandRunning, AltScreen, RecentGap} × action kinds → expected decision.
  - Approval allow-once scoping (command hash, TTL) and audit output stability.
  - Redaction property tests: secrets never appear in structured logs, audit records, or exported artifacts.

- Integration tests:
  - Wire policy into robot send + workflow send paths and assert:
    - deny returns stable error codes
    - deny/approve decisions are recorded in audit storage

- E2E tests:
  - Deny-by-default scenario for unsafe sends + explicit allow-once override with artifacts (`wa-4vx.10.10`, `wa-4vx.10.16`).

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Success Criteria, Deliverables.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.
close_reason: All children complete: policy model, rate limiting, redaction, PaneCapabilities, approval tokens, config rules, integration, and 125 policy tests. All tests pass.

## Why
We want policy decisions that are:
- explicit (stable enums + reasons)
- testable (pure logic)
- portable (CLI/robot/MCP/workflows share one engine)

## Deliverables
