title: Docs: README/quickstart + architecture + CLI/robot/MCP reference
description:
# Task: Documentation for v0.1

## Goal
Make the project approachable for a new contributor and operable for users.

This bead is intentionally self-contained and mirrors PLAN Appendix A + F so contributors don’t need to dig through planning docs.

## Deliverables
### 1) README (operator-first)
- What wa is (WezTerm mux “terminal hypervisor” for agent fleets).
- Quickstart:
  - install wa
  - `wa setup`
  - `wa watch`
  - `wa status`
  - `wa query` / `wa events`
- Safety guarantees:
  - observe vs act split
  - no silent gaps
  - policy-gated sending + approvals

### 2) Architecture doc
- Ingest → Storage (SQLite+FTS5) → Pattern engine → Workflow engine → Robot/MCP.
- Deterministic state via OSC 133.
- Explicit GAP semantics.

### 3) CLI reference (PLAN Appendix A)
Human-oriented commands (rich output by default via `rich_rust`):
- `wa status` — panes + inferred agent state
- `wa watch` — run daemon (foreground/background)
- `wa stop` — stop watcher in workspace safely
- `wa events` — recent/unhandled events
- `wa query` — FTS search
- `wa send` — guarded send to a pane
- `wa reserve` — reserve a pane for exclusive use
- `wa reservations` — list active reservations
- `wa approve` — grant allow-once approvals
- `wa workflow` — run a workflow manually (guarded)
- `wa audit` — audit trail of actions (redacted)
- `wa history` — action timeline + undoability
- `wa undo` — undo supported actions (with confirmation)
- `wa rules` — list/test rule packs, show matching traces
- `wa accounts` — list/refresh accounts, show rotation picks
- `wa setup` — canonical WezTerm configuration (local/remote)
- `wa doctor` — environment checks (wezterm presence, DB health)
- `wa diag bundle` — sanitized diagnostic bundle export
- `wa export` — export slices/history/audit
- `wa web` — optional HTTP server (`fastapi_rust`) if enabled
- `wa tui` — optional TUI (`charmed_rust`) if enabled
- `wa sync` — optional sync (`asupersync`) if enabled

Robot mode commands (stable JSON envelope; token-efficient):
- `wa robot state [--domain <name>] [--agent <type>]`
- `wa robot get-text <pane_id> [--tail N] [--escapes]`
- `wa robot send <pane_id> "<text>" [--no-newline] [--wait-for "<pat>"] [--timeout-secs N]`
- `wa robot wait-for <pane_id> "<pat>" [--timeout-secs N]`
- `wa robot search "<fts query>" [--pane-id <id>] [--since <iso8601>] [--limit N]`
- `wa robot events [--unhandled] [--pane-id <id>] [--type <event>] [--limit N]`
- `wa robot workflow <name> <pane_id> [--force]`
- `wa robot reserve <pane_id> --ttl <secs> --reason <text>`
- `wa robot release <pane_id>`
- `wa robot reservations`
- `wa robot accounts [--service <openai|anthropic|google>]`
- `wa robot accounts refresh [--service <openai|anthropic|google>]`
- `wa robot rules list [--pack <name>]`
- `wa robot rules test "<text>" [--agent <type>]`
- `wa robot quick-start`

### 4) MCP reference (PLAN Appendix A)
Tools (names are short and obvious):
- `wa.state`
- `wa.get_text`
- `wa.send`
- `wa.wait_for`
- `wa.search`
- `wa.events`
- `wa.workflow_run`
- `wa.accounts`
- `wa.accounts_refresh`
- `wa.rules_list`
- `wa.rules_test`
- `wa.reserve`
- `wa.release`
- `wa.reservations`

Resources:
- `wa://panes`
- `wa://events`
- `wa://accounts`
- `wa://workflows`
- `wa://rules`
- `wa://reservations`

### 5) Library integration map (PLAN Appendix F)
| Library | Role in `wa` |
|---------|--------------|
| `cass` (`/dp/coding_agent_session_search`) | Correlation + session archaeology; used in status + workflows |
| `caut` (`/dp/coding_agent_usage_tracker`) | Usage truth + selection; used in accounts + `handle_usage_limits` |
| `rich_rust` | Human-first CLI output (tables/panels/highlight) |
| `charmed_rust` | Optional interactive TUI (pane picker, event feed, transcript viewer) |
| `fastmcp_rust` | MCP tool surface for agent control (mirrors robot mode) |
| `fastapi_rust` | Optional HTTP server for dashboards/webhooks (read-only first) |
| `asupersync` | Remote bootstrap/sync layer (configs, binaries, DB snapshots) |
| `playwright` | Automate device auth flows with persistent profiles |
| `ast-grep` | Structure-aware codebase scans in “unstick agent” workflows |

## Testing / doc correctness
Docs must not drift.

- The quickstart commands shown in README should be validated regularly:
  - either by referencing existing E2E scripts, or
  - by adding a small “docs smoke” CI step that runs the exact commands from the docs in a controlled environment (tracked by `wa-nu4.3.9.9`).

- Robot mode docs should match the schema contract:
  - reference the versioned JSON schemas and keep field names consistent.

## Acceptance Criteria
- A new engineer can get to a running watcher and see events with no oral tradition.
- CLI/robot/MCP references match implemented command surfaces and schemas.

title: Version/build metadata: `wa --version` shows semver + build info + enabled features
description:
# Task: Version/build metadata (`wa --version`)

## Goal
Make it easy to know exactly what build of wa is running when debugging bugs, comparing machines, or filing issues.

This becomes non-optional once we span multiple machines and (optionally) a vendored WezTerm build.

## Output contract
- `wa --version` prints a **single, stable** line by default (human-friendly, scriptable).
- `wa --version --verbose` prints a multi-line block with detailed metadata.
- Output must not require a TTY.

## Fields to include (when available)
- `wa` semver
- build timestamp (UTC)
- git commit hash (if built from a git checkout)
- rustc version
- target triple
- enabled cargo features (mcp/web/tui/sync/browser/vendored/etc.)

Vendored mode (PLAN Appendix H):
- when `--features vendored` is enabled, include:
  - vendored WezTerm commit hash (the pinned commit)
  - any compatibility/version string we can reliably extract

## Why this matters
When automation spans multiple machines, “what version is running?” is the first diagnostic question. Vendored mode adds an additional critical dimension (which WezTerm commit?).

## Testing
- Unit tests for `--version` output:
  - non-empty
  - contains semver
  - stable (no ANSI, no random ordering)

- Verbose output tests:
  - includes the detailed fields and feature list
  - when built with vendored feature (in CI matrix), includes vendored commit hash

## Acceptance Criteria
- `wa --version` output is stable and does not require a TTY.
- `wa --version --verbose` provides enough metadata to uniquely identify the build.
- Vendored builds surface vendored commit metadata deterministically.

- Follow the standard E2E harness logging contract (`wa-4vx.10.6`) and runner (`wa-4vx.10.11`).
- Emit per-step start/end markers with timestamps + durations.
- Include case name and pane ids in every log line.
- Redact secrets (device codes, tokens) in logs and artifacts.

## Acceptance Criteria
- A CI failure includes enough artifacts to diagnose whether the bug is in:
  - policy decision
  - approval granting
  - retry behavior
  - audit/export


## Testing
- CI self-check:
  - Ensure the job logs include the artifacts upload location.
  - Consider a “known fail” dry run to verify artifact upload and summary formatting.

title: CI setup job: run wa setup idempotency E2E (temp home, artifacts on failure)
description:
# Task: CI setup job (dotfile patching safety)

## Goal
Continuously validate that wa setup is safe and idempotent.

Dotfile patching is one of the fastest ways to lose user trust. This CI job ensures:
- dry-run does not write
- apply mode changes only the intended block
- re-running is a no-op

## Behavior
- Run the setup idempotency E2E:
  - ./scripts/e2e_setup_test.sh --all --verbose
  - or reuse ./scripts/e2e_test.sh if we unify harnesses

- Always upload artifacts on failure:
  - before/after copies
  - diffs
  - logs

## Dependencies
- Uses the E2E setup test described in wa-nu4.3.3.10.

## Registry
- Not a case. CI job focuses on setup idempotency cases from the registry.

## Logging
- Follow the standard E2E harness logging contract (`wa-4vx.10.6`) and runner (`wa-4vx.10.11`).
- Emit per-step start/end markers with timestamps + durations.
- Include case name and pane ids in every log line.
- Redact secrets (device codes, tokens) in logs and artifacts.

## Acceptance Criteria
- CI failures include all artifacts needed to debug the patcher step.


## Testing
- CI self-check:
  - Ensure the job asserts it is operating on a temp home directory and never touches `~`.
  - Include an intentional failure variant to verify artifact upload (diffs/before-after) works.

title: Docs smoke tests: quickstart commands stay executable in CI
description:
# Task: Docs smoke tests (quickstart stays executable)

## Goal
Prevent docs drift by ensuring the README/quickstart instructions remain executable and safe.

This is a user-trust feature: if the quickstart breaks, new users churn.

## Scope
- Focus on commands that docs will recommend for a fresh install:
  - `wa --help`
  - `wa --version --verbose`
  - `wa robot quick-start`
  - `wa setup --dry-run` (in a temp HOME)
  - `wa doctor` (in a minimal environment; may be expected to warn but must be actionable)

- For commands that require a real WezTerm environment, docs should point to the E2E scripts as the canonical tested path rather than embedding fragile “just run this” snippets.

## Deliverables
1) A small docs-smoke runner (CI-friendly)
- Runs in a temp HOME + temp workspace.
- Captures stdout/stderr to artifacts.
- Never modifies real user dotfiles.

2) A mapping from “docs claims” → “test coverage”
- For each quickstart step, link to either:
  - a docs-smoke command, or
  - an E2E script case (e.g., `wa-4vx.10.7`, `wa-nu4.3.3.10`).

3) CI integration
- Add a CI job/step that runs docs smoke and uploads artifacts on failure.

## Logging & artifacts (must match the E2E philosophy)
- Artifacts directory contains:
  - `env.txt` (OS, rustc, cargo, enabled features)
  - `commands.txt` (exact commands executed)
  - `stdout.txt` / `stderr.txt` per command (or per step)
  - `summary.json` (pass/fail + durations)

- Logs must never contain secrets (even if users have real configs on their machine).

## Testing
- Unit-ish tests:
  - if docs smoke is implemented as a Rust subcommand, validate output schemas and deterministic ordering.
  - if implemented as a shell script, include at least one self-test that verifies it creates artifacts and returns correct exit codes.

- CI tests:
  - docs smoke runs on every PR and fails when a quickstart command regresses.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Docs smoke runs in CI and fails when a referenced quickstart command breaks.
- Failures are diagnosable from artifacts without rerunning locally.


## Testing
- “Tests for the tests”:
  - include one intentionally-failing step under a special flag (or a dedicated CI mode) to ensure artifact capture + summaries are working.

title: [EPIC] Phase 5: Advanced — vendoring, streaming, distributed mode, coordination
description:
# Phase 5 — Advanced Features

## Objective
Push wa from “solid local orchestrator” into “fleet-grade system”:
- Selective WezTerm vendoring (feature-gated) for streaming output / lower overhead.
- Real-time output streaming (reduce polling and gaps).
- Optional distributed mode: `wa-agent` near mux servers + central aggregator.
- Multi-agent coordination helpers.

## Why this phase exists
The core system can ship without this. These features are justified only when they deliver measurable wins:
- latency, correctness (fewer gaps), or usability.

## Deliverables
- Vendored client prototype + benchmarks vs CLI.
- If ROI confirmed: ship `--features vendored` with strict version checks.
- Distributed protocol design + first implementation.

## Acceptance criteria
- Benchmarks show clear advantage for vendored/streaming modes.
- Distributed mode can ingest deltas from at least one remote domain without stalling the central watcher.



## Success Criteria
- Advanced capabilities (vendoring, streaming, distributed mode, coordination) remain optional and do not compromise core safety.
- Each advanced feature has clear boundaries, tests, and safe defaults.


## Testing
- Performance ROI validation:
  - Benchmarks must prove vendored/streaming modes are meaningfully better than CLI polling for target workloads.

- Safety/regression:
  - Optional features must compile-gate cleanly and have their own unit/integration tests.

- E2E (when distributed mode is implemented):
  - Distributed E2E tests must validate persistence, ordering, and secret-safe artifacts (`wa-nu4.4.3.5`).

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Success Criteria, Deliverables.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.

title: [EPIC] Selective WezTerm vendoring (feature vendored) + version compatibility
description:
# [EPIC] Selective WezTerm vendoring

## Mission
Unlock capabilities not available via `wezterm cli`, while preserving a CLI-first default:
- zero-copy scrollback access
- real-time output streaming (enables true subscription vs polling)

## Default posture
- CLI-first remains the foundation.
- Vendoring is an **optional acceleration lane** behind `--features vendored`.

## Key risks
- Upstream API churn
- Version compatibility problems
- Larger binary / more complex build

## Definition of done
- `--features vendored` builds successfully.
- wa can detect local WezTerm version compatibility and surface it in `wa doctor`.
- Unified client picks best available backend (vendored when compatible, otherwise CLI).


## Success Criteria
- Vendored WezTerm components are minimal, clearly version-pinned, and do not break upstream compatibility expectations.
- CI validates vendor build and ensures core features still work without vendoring enabled.


## Testing
- Feature-gate tests:
  - Ensure `--features vendored` builds and unit tests run, and `--no-default-features` (or default) still works without pulling vendored deps.

- Compatibility tests:
  - Fixture-based tests for version/commit matching logic (supported/unsupported versions).
  - `wa doctor` should surface compatibility deterministically.

- RPC smoke tests:
  - Basic mux RPC framing tests with fixtures so failures are diagnosable without a live WezTerm.

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Success Criteria, Definition of Done.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.

title: Vendored feature scaffolding: add wezterm crates + compile behind feature flag
description:
# Task: Vendored feature scaffolding

## Goal
Add the minimal dependency + feature wiring to compile vendored WezTerm crates behind `--features vendored`.

## Deliverables
- Cargo feature `vendored`.
- Optional dependencies on the selected WezTerm crates (selective, not full fork).
- A build that succeeds in both modes:
  - default (CLI-only)
  - vendored

## Testing
- Build/test matrix:
  - `cargo check --all-targets` (default)
  - `cargo check --all-targets --features vendored`
  - ideally `cargo test --features vendored` once minimal unit tests exist

- Ensure feature gating is strict:
  - enabling `vendored` must not pull heavy deps into default builds

## Acceptance Criteria
- `cargo build` works without vendored deps.
- `cargo build --features vendored` works and does not affect default behavior.

title: DirectMuxClient: connect to mux socket + basic RPC framing (vendored)
description:
# Task: DirectMuxClient (vendored)

## Goal
Implement a direct mux client that can connect to the WezTerm mux socket and perform RPCs using vendored protocol types.

This is the foundation for vendored scrollback reads and real-time subscriptions.

## Socket discovery
- Discover mux socket path via:
  - WezTerm defaults
  - wa config override (must exist for unusual setups)
- Support multiple platforms (macOS/Linux) as needed.

## Connection + framing
- Implement:
  - connect with timeout
  - request/response framing with bounded reads
  - graceful close

## Robustness
- Never allow unbounded reads from the socket.
- Return structured errors that can be surfaced in `wa doctor` and `wa status`.
- Treat protocol decode errors as “incompatible version” signals (and fall back to CLI where appropriate).

## Testing strategy
- Offline unit tests:
  - frame encode/decode round-trips
  - truncated/invalid frames handled without panics

- Optional manual smoke:
  - on a machine with a running mux server, connect and perform a simple request (e.g., list panes)

## Acceptance Criteria
- In vendored mode, wa can connect to a running mux server and perform a simple request (e.g., list panes).
- Decode errors are handled gracefully and do not panic.

title: UnifiedClient: use vendored scrollback when available; fallback to CLI
description:
# Task: UnifiedClient backend selection

## Goal
Expose a single WezTerm client API that:
- uses vendored direct access when available and compatible
- falls back to `wezterm cli` otherwise

The rest of wa (ingest/workflows/robot/MCP) should not care which backend is used.

## Selection rules
- Prefer vendored backend only when:
  - feature `vendored` enabled
  - version compatibility checks pass
  - mux socket discovery succeeds

- Otherwise, fall back to CLI client.
- Selection decision should be observable:
  - log which backend was chosen and why (no secrets)
  - optionally expose via `wa doctor` / `wa status`

## API constraints
- Maintain a stable high-level API across backends:
  - list panes
  - read scrollback/text
  - send text / ctrl sequences

- Normalize semantics:
  - error types are consistent
  - timeouts behave similarly

## Performance expectations
- Vendored mode should be measurably faster for large scrollback reads.
- Add (or reuse) benchmarks to quantify the improvement.

## Testing strategy
- Unit tests:
  - selection logic chooses the expected backend under different synthetic conditions
  - compatibility gating behavior

- Integration tests:
  - ensure the same call (`get_text`) works in both modes (fixtures where possible)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Same high-level call (`get_text`) works in both modes.
- Vendored mode is measurably faster on large scrollback reads.
- Fallback behavior is correct and observable.

title: Vendored version compatibility: compare local wezterm vs vendored commit/version
description:
# Task: Vendored version compatibility

## Goal
Prevent mysterious breakage by checking whether the running WezTerm is compatible with the vendored protocol.

## Deliverables
- Function to determine local WezTerm version.
- Embed vendored version/commit in build metadata.
- Compatibility classification:
  - matched
  - compatible (warn)
  - incompatible (disable vendored backend; suggest fix)
- Surface in `wa doctor` and `wa status --health`.

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - parse representative local version strings (stable + nightly-ish)
  - compatibility classification matrix is deterministic
  - incompatible → vendored disabled (fallback to CLI) and warning message is stable

## Acceptance Criteria
- On mismatch, wa clearly explains what to do.

title: Vendored tests: feature build + compatibility gating + basic RPC fixtures
description:
# Task: Vendored tests (feature vendored)

## Goal
Ensure vendored mode does not rot.

Vendored mode is optional and higher-risk (we’re embedding upstream code). If it compiles but breaks at runtime, it becomes a maintenance trap.

## Test tiers
### 1) Build-level verification (always in CI)
- `cargo test --features vendored` (or at least `cargo check`) must succeed.
- Ensure the default (non-vendored) build still works.

### 2) Pure unit tests (offline)
- Version compatibility logic:
  - local wezterm version parsing
  - compatibility decisions are deterministic

- Client selection logic:
  - “vendored available” → prefer vendored
  - “vendored unavailable” → fall back to CLI client

### 3) Fixture-based protocol tests (offline)
- Where possible, test mux RPC framing using fixtures:
  - encode/decode round-trips
  - error cases (truncated frames, invalid message types)

### 4) Optional manual smoke
- On a dev machine with a real mux server, run a smoke command that:
  - connects
  - reads minimal pane metadata
  - exits cleanly

## Acceptance Criteria
- CI includes at least a vendored build/test step.
- Core selection + compatibility logic is unit-tested.
- Protocol handling is exercised with offline fixtures (no live mux required).


## Testing
- Meta-validation:
  - Add at least one intentionally-invalid RPC frame fixture to ensure error handling paths are tested.
  - Ensure CI runs both default and vendored test commands so regressions don’t hide behind feature flags.

title: Vendoring ROI decision: CLI gaps + benchmarks + go/no-go
description:
# Task: Vendoring ROI decision (go/no-go)

## Goal
Decide whether WezTerm vendoring delivers enough value to justify the maintenance cost.

## Why
Vendoring increases complexity and build cost. We should only proceed if it meaningfully improves:
- output capture latency
- CPU usage
- fidelity (fewer gaps)

## Work items
- Benchmark CLI polling baseline (CPU, latency, gap rate) under realistic workloads.
- Identify concrete pain points that vendoring solves (e.g., streaming, zero-copy scrollback).
- Define success thresholds for vendored mode (e.g., 5x lower polling CPU, <50ms avg latency).

## Deliverables
- Go/no-go decision recorded in this bead.
- If go:
  - list of required vendored APIs
  - minimal supported WezTerm version window
- If no-go:
  - defer vendoring tasks and document reasons

## Testing
- Use existing benchmark harness (`wa-4vx.10.2`) to capture baseline numbers and include them in the decision.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Decision includes measurable evidence and clear thresholds.

title: Vendoring maintenance plan: pin commit, embed commit metadata, CI vendored build+smoke
description:
# Task: Vendoring maintenance plan (pin commit + build metadata + CI job)

## Goal
If we enable `--features vendored`, make it maintainable and diagnosable by implementing the maintenance posture from PLAN.md Appendix H.

## Why
Vendoring WezTerm increases:
- build complexity
- upgrade burden
- risk of subtle compatibility breaks

Without explicit maintenance infrastructure, vendored mode becomes a “rotting optional feature”.

## Deliverables (Appendix H, made concrete)
1) **Pin to a commit hash**
   - Decide the mechanism:
     - git dependency pinned to commit, or
     - vendored subtree/submodule
   - Record the exact commit hash and update procedure.

2) **Embed vendored commit in build metadata**
   - `wa --version --verbose` includes:
     - vendored commit hash (when vendored feature enabled)
     - local wezterm version (if detectable)
   - `wa doctor` can compare local WezTerm against vendored compatibility info.

3) **Add CI coverage for vendored feature**
   - Add a CI job that:
     - builds `wa` with `--features vendored`
     - runs a minimal offline mux protocol smoke test (fixtures)
     - reports compilation breakage early

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - build metadata includes vendored commit when feature enabled
  - `wa doctor` compatibility reporting is deterministic

- CI tests:
  - `cargo test --features vendored` (or `cargo check` + targeted tests) runs and is non-flaky

## Acceptance Criteria
- Vendored mode has an explicit, repeatable “update vendored commit” procedure.
- CI will catch vendored compilation breakage quickly.
- Users can report issues with enough metadata to know whether compatibility is the cause.

title: [EPIC] Real-time output streaming: subscribe to pane deltas (vendored)
description:
# [EPIC] Real-time output streaming

## Mission
Move from polling-based capture to subscription-based capture when vendored WezTerm is available.

## Why
- Lower latency
- Less CPU
- Eliminates missed scrollback windows under heavy load

## Scope
- Subscribe to pane output events and feed them into the existing ingest/event bus.
- Preserve current polling path as fallback.

## Definition of done
- Vendored mode can stream deltas for a pane.
- Ingest can switch between polling and streaming based on capabilities.


## Success Criteria
- Real-time streaming of pane output is optional, performant, and does not regress ingest correctness.
- Backpressure and resource limits prevent runaway memory/CPU usage.
- Tests validate correctness under streaming and non-streaming modes.


## Testing
- Correctness tests:
  - Streaming mode must preserve the same seq/gap invariants as polling.
  - Compare streaming vs polling capture on the same fixture transcript (when possible) and assert equivalence.

- Backpressure tests:
  - Simulate slow consumers and ensure bounded queues drop/slow appropriately without unbounded memory.

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Success Criteria, Definition of Done.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.

title: Streaming design: event types, backpressure, integration with existing seq/gap model
description:
# Task: Streaming design

## Goal
Specify how streaming output integrates with wa’s segment/seq/gap invariants.

## Key constraints
- We must preserve monotonic per-pane `seq`.
- We must still emit explicit GAP events when discontinuities occur.
- Streaming must not overwhelm storage/event bus.

## Deliverables
- Definition of the streamed unit (bytes, lines, or “delta string”).
- Mapping to `OutputSegment` + seq assignment.
- Backpressure strategy:
  - bounded channels
  - drop policy (prefer emitting GAP over silent drop)

## Testing
- Property/invariant tests:
  - given an input stream with drops/out-of-order events, we either:
    - re-order safely, OR
    - emit a GAP deterministically (explicitly choose and lock down)

- Integration tests with a fake stream:
  - slow consumer behavior
  - bounded channel behavior
  - cancellation/reconnect paths do not leak resources

## Acceptance Criteria
- A reviewer can implement streaming ingestion from this issue alone.
- The design includes an explicit plan for invariant testing (seq monotonicity + gap semantics).

title: Implement subscribe_output (vendored): stream pane output events as deltas
description:
# Task: Implement `subscribe_output` (vendored)

## Goal
In vendored mode, subscribe to pane output events and expose a stream of deltas that integrates with wa’s existing seq/gap model.

Polling scrollback works, but subscriptions enable:
- lower latency
- lower CPU
- better fidelity (fewer missed segments)

## Deliverables
- Vendored mux subscription wiring (connect → subscribe → receive events).
- Stream adapter that yields a typed event (proposed: `PaneDelta`).
- Cancellation/shutdown handling:
  - dropping the stream unsubscribes
  - process shutdown closes cleanly

## Backpressure & robustness
- The stream must not allow unbounded buffering.
  - bounded channel
  - drop policy or slow-consumer handling (explicitly choose and document)

- Handle reconnects/timeouts gracefully:
  - transient errors → reconnect with backoff
  - permanent errors → surface a structured error and fall back to polling (if caller chooses)

## Integration with seq/gap
- Define how subscription events map to:
  - seq numbers
  - gaps (if the stream reports dropped events)

## Testing strategy
- Offline unit tests with fixtures:
  - decode/encode subscription messages
  - simulate event stream and ensure adapter produces ordered deltas
  - simulate dropped/out-of-order events and ensure we emit a GAP or diagnostic

## Acceptance Criteria
- Can subscribe to a pane and receive deltas while a command runs.
- Slow consumer does not cause unbounded memory growth.
- Error paths are deterministic and do not panic.

title: Integrate streaming tailers: prefer subscription when available; fallback to polling
description:
# Task: Integrate streaming tailers

## Goal
Teach the ingest system to choose between:
- polling tailers (CLI get-text)
- streaming tailers (vendored subscribe)

The objective is reduced CPU/latency without changing downstream semantics.

## Capability detection
At runtime, decide per workspace/domain:
- if subscription is supported and healthy → use streaming
- otherwise → use polling

The decision should be:
- deterministic
- observable in logs/health snapshot

## Semantics must match polling mode
Regardless of tailer type:
- segments are written with seq
- gaps are emitted on discontinuity
- pattern detection and workflows behave the same

## Failure & fallback behavior
- If streaming connection drops:
  - record a diagnostic event
  - fall back to polling with backoff

- If polling is too slow or misses data:
  - record explicit GAP events (existing invariant)

## Performance expectations
- Vendored streaming mode should show significantly lower polling load and better latency.
- Add counters to compare:
  - messages/sec
  - dropped events
  - gap rate

## Testing strategy
- Unit tests with a fake stream:
  - normal ordered stream → segments
  - dropped/out-of-order stream → GAP behavior
  - stream disconnect triggers fallback

## Acceptance Criteria
- In vendored mode, ingest runs with significantly lower polling load.
- In non-vendored mode, behavior remains unchanged.
- Streaming failures degrade gracefully (no crashes, clear diagnostics).

title: Expose streaming subscriptions to agents (MCP resource/stream or web SSE) [optional]
description:
# Task: Expose streaming subscriptions (optional)

## Goal
Allow agent integrations to subscribe to:
- pane output deltas
- event stream
without polling.

## Options
- MCP streaming resource (if supported)
- Web server SSE/WebSocket endpoint (feature web)

## Requirements
- Backpressure and rate limiting.
- Privacy: apply redaction rules where appropriate.

## Testing
- Unit/contract tests:
  - stream message schemas are stable
  - backpressure behavior is bounded and deterministic
  - redaction is applied (no raw transcript secrets)

- E2E tests (optional, but preferred if we ship this):
  - a client subscribes and receives a bounded stream of updates
  - disconnect/reconnect does not leak resources

## Acceptance Criteria
- A client can subscribe and receive incremental updates with bounded memory.

title: [EPIC] Optional distributed mode: wa-agent + aggregator + wire protocol
description:
# [EPIC] Optional distributed mode

## Mission
Support multi-machine WezTerm setups by running a lightweight `wa-agent` near each remote mux server.

## Model
- `wa-agent` (remote): captures deltas/events locally and streams them to...
- `wa` aggregator (workstation): merges streams, persists to local SQLite, runs workflows.

## Guiding principles
- Keep the wire protocol small and deterministic.
- Prefer delta streaming over full scrollback dumps.
- Security by default (auth token, localhost bind unless configured).

## Definition of done
- A single remote `wa-agent` can connect to an aggregator and stream pane deltas/events.
- Aggregator persists the data and exposes it via CLI/robot/MCP.


## Success Criteria
- Distributed mode is optional, secure-by-default, and does not broaden the attack surface unintentionally.
- Aggregator/agent protocol is versioned, tested, and includes replay protection and safe bind defaults.
- Local-only mode remains the default with no required network listeners.


## Testing
- Protocol tests:
  - Encode/decode roundtrips for each message type; version negotiation behavior.

- Security tests:
  - Default bind is localhost; remote bind requires explicit dangerous flag.
  - Auth token required; missing/invalid token is rejected with stable error codes.

- E2E tests:
  - Agent→aggregator E2E validates persistence + visibility and produces artifacts (`wa-nu4.4.3.5`).

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Success Criteria, Definition of Done.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.

title: Wire protocol spec: PaneDelta/Detection/Gap/PanesMeta messages (versioned)
description:
# Task: Wire protocol spec

## Goal
Define the message protocol between `wa-agent` and aggregator.

## Requirements
- Versioned schema.
- Messages:
  - `PaneMeta` (pane_id, domain, title, cwd, size)
  - `PaneDelta` (pane_id, seq?, bytes/lines, captured_at)
  - `Gap` (pane_id, reason, last_seq, captured_at)
  - `Detection` (rule_id, pack_id, severity, extracted_json)
- Transport:
  - start with WebSocket over TCP (or similar)
  - allow future TLS

## Testing
- Schema tests:
  - encode/decode round-trips for each message type
  - backward/forward compatibility rules are explicit and validated

- Golden fixtures:
  - small set of example messages stored as fixtures
  - used by both agent and aggregator tests

- Robustness:
  - malformed messages must produce structured errors (no panics)

## Acceptance Criteria
- A future implementer can build agent + aggregator from this spec alone.
- The spec includes a concrete fixture + schema validation plan.

title: Implement wa-agent: local capture + stream to aggregator (best available capture mode)
description:
# Task: Implement `wa-agent`

## Goal
Create a lightweight daemon that runs near a mux server and streams:
- pane deltas
- detections
- gaps
- minimal metadata

## Design
- Capture engine:
  - default: polling tailers (CLI)
  - optional: streaming if vendored available
- Network:
  - connect to aggregator via configured URL
  - reconnect with backoff

## Safety
- Agent should be read-only unless explicitly given permission to perform pane-local actions.
- Network safety must follow the distributed security bead:
  - auth token handshake
  - never log tokens
  - bounded message rates / reconnect behavior

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - wire protocol encode/decode integration
  - reconnect/backoff behavior is bounded and deterministic

- Integration tests (offline):
  - stream fixture deltas into a fake aggregator endpoint
  - assert messages are well-formed and redacted where needed

- E2E coverage:
  - full agent→aggregator behavior is covered by `wa-nu4.4.3.5`.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `wa-agent` can connect to aggregator and stream at least one pane’s output deltas.

title: Aggregator mode: accept agent streams, merge per-domain data, persist, expose via CLI/MCP
description:
# Task: Aggregator mode

## Goal
Add an aggregator mode to `wa watch` that accepts remote streams and integrates them into the same pipeline as local capture.

## Responsibilities
- Accept connections from `wa-agent`.
- Merge streams (per-domain / per-pane) into the event bus.
- Persist segments/events to SQLite.
- Run workflows (and if an action must be pane-local, delegate back to the appropriate agent in future iterations).

## Security & safety
- Must enforce distributed security requirements (auth token, bind defaults, replay protection).
- Never accept unauthenticated traffic by default.

## Testing
- Unit tests:
  - per-pane ordering/merge behavior is deterministic
  - backpressure limits are enforced
  - malformed messages produce structured errors (no panics)

- Integration tests (offline):
  - accept a fake agent stream and ensure segments/events land in SQLite
  - ensure explicit gaps are preserved

- E2E coverage:
  - full agent→aggregator behavior is covered by `wa-nu4.4.3.5`.

## Acceptance Criteria
- With one `wa-agent` connected, `wa status` shows remote panes and `wa query` can search their output.

title: Distributed security: auth token, bind defaults, replay protection (minimal)
description:
# Task: Distributed mode security

## Goal
Prevent accidental exposure when running aggregator/agent networking.

Distributed mode turns wa into a networked system; the default posture must be “safe and local”, with explicit opt-in for anything remotely reachable.

## Requirements
### Bind defaults
- Aggregator binds to localhost by default.
- Public bind requires an explicit, scary flag (e.g., `--dangerous-bind-any`) and prints a prominent warning.

### Authentication
- Simple shared auth token between agent and aggregator (v0):
  - sent in a header or the first message
  - constant-time compare
  - never logged

### Replay / injection resistance
- Basic replay protection:
  - monotonic sequence numbers per agent session
  - reject stale/duplicate sequences

- Rate limiting / connection limits:
  - cap concurrent connections
  - cap messages/sec per connection

### Redaction
- Aggregator logs and any exposed query surfaces must use wa’s redaction rules.

## Testing strategy
- Unit tests:
  - token verification rejects wrong/missing token
  - replay checks reject duplicate/stale sequence numbers

- Integration tests:
  - unauthenticated client cannot inject fake events/segments
  - authenticated client can stream
  - logs do not contain token values

## Acceptance Criteria
- An unauthenticated client cannot inject fake events/segments.
- Public bind is never the default.
- Replay/injection controls are present and test-covered.

title: Distributed E2E tests: agent→aggregator stream, persistence, CLI visibility
description:
# Task: Distributed E2E tests (feature distributed)

## Goal
Validate distributed mode end-to-end so it can be trusted when enabled:
- agent → aggregator streaming
- persistence + indexing
- CLI/robot visibility of aggregated data

Distributed mode is optional, but if we ship it, it must not be flaky.

## E2E harness requirements
- Must run **offline** with no real WezTerm required.
- Prefer a deterministic “fake agent” producer that emits:
  - segments (PaneDelta)
  - explicit GAP events
  - detections/events
  - out-of-order or duplicated messages (to test robustness)

- Spin up an aggregator instance bound to localhost with an ephemeral port.
- Capture artifacts:
  - aggregator logs
  - agent logs
  - a small exported DB snapshot

## Test runner integration
- Must run via the shared E2E runner (`./scripts/e2e_test.sh`) and follow the harness artifacts contract.
- The runner should allow skipping this case when `--features distributed` is not enabled.

## Required scenarios
1) Happy path
   - agent streams a few segments
   - aggregator persists them
   - CLI/robot query surfaces can retrieve them

2) GAP preservation
   - agent emits a gap
   - aggregator records it
   - downstream queries reflect the discontinuity

3) Robustness
   - duplicated messages do not create duplicate persisted rows (or are deduped deterministically)
   - out-of-order messages either:
     - are re-ordered safely, OR
     - are recorded as a gap + diagnostic (explicitly choose and test)

4) Security baseline
   - auth token required when configured
   - logs + responses remain redacted

## Observability expectations
- Structured logs with correlation ids:
  - stream connection/session id
  - pane id
  - message counts
- On failure, E2E script prints where artifacts were written.

## Registry
- Register this case in the E2E case registry (`wa-4vx.10.20`).
- Mark it as **non-default** unless `--features distributed` (or equivalent) is enabled.

## Logging
- Follow the standard E2E harness logging contract (`wa-4vx.10.6`) and runner (`wa-4vx.10.11`).
- Emit per-step start/end markers with timestamps + durations.
- Include case name and pane ids in every log line.
- Redact secrets (device codes, tokens) in logs and artifacts.

## Acceptance Criteria
- An E2E script (or `cargo test --features distributed`) can spin up fake agent + aggregator and assert:
  - segments arrive
  - gaps are preserved
  - detections/events arrive
  - aggregated data is visible via CLI/robot query
- Failures produce actionable logs + artifacts.


## Testing
- Meta-validation:
  - Add a negative security scenario: missing/invalid auth token must be rejected and logged (redacted) with stable error codes.
  - Assert required artifacts exist (agent logs, aggregator logs, DB snapshot/export) before declaring PASS.

title: Distributed mode scope decision (when multi-machine coordination is needed)
description:
# Task: Distributed mode scope decision (when multi-machine coordination is needed)

## Goal
Resolve PLAN.md Open Question #6: **when do we actually need cross-machine wa instances to communicate?**

This is a decision gate: we should not invest in distributed mode unless there is a clear, measured user benefit.

## Why this matters (user value)
Distributed mode adds:
- operational burden (deploying and updating `wa-agent`)
- security surface area (network listeners, auth tokens)
- additional failure modes

If users do not need it yet, we should defer and keep the core system simpler and more reliable.

## Inputs to evaluate
1. **Scale triggers**
   - Number of remote domains/panes where CLI polling becomes slow or flaky.
   - Average tail latency and gap rates with current CLI/Lua approaches.

2. **User-story triggers**
   - Does any priority user story *require* cross-machine aggregation (e.g., H1 across many hosts)?
   - Are there cases where local-only wa cannot observe all panes reliably?

3. **Reliability/operations**
   - Does a single workstation failure represent an unacceptable single point of failure?
   - Do we need to keep local capture alive when aggregator is offline?

4. **Security/constraints**
   - Are there environments where outbound agent→aggregator streaming is forbidden?
   - Are there compliance constraints that require local-only capture?

## Work items
- Collect baseline metrics from the CLI/Lua-only mode:
  - capture latency
  - gap rate
  - CPU usage on busy mux servers
- Define **thresholds** that justify distributed mode, e.g.:
  - N domains/panes beyond which latency or gap rate exceeds target.
  - Latency SLO violation (e.g., > 250ms p95) under normal load.
- Decide **go/no-go** for distributed mode in the next release cycle and document:
  - timeline (v0.2? later?)
  - minimal MVP scope if “go”
  - deferral rationale if “no-go”

## Deliverables
- Decision note recorded in this bead with measurable thresholds and timeline.
- If “go”:
  - update distributed epic to reflect MVP scope and prerequisites.
- If “no-go”:
  - document the specific triggers that would cause a re-evaluation.

## Testing / validation
- Use existing perf/metrics harnesses (e.g., `wa-4vx.10.2`, `wa-nu4.3.4.2`) to gather baseline numbers.
- Evidence should be reproducible (logs or summary table in the decision note).

## Acceptance Criteria
- Decision is documented with thresholds tied to measurable data.
- The decision explicitly references user-story impact (what it enables or why it’s unnecessary).
- Re-evaluation triggers are clear and actionable.

# [EPIC] Multi-agent coordination

## Mission
Turn wa from a single-pane automator into a coordination substrate for many agent panes.

## What this includes
- "swarm" workflows that coordinate multiple panes safely
- guidance/docs/skills so agents can use wa effectively
- optional integrations that help unstick agents (e.g., ast-grep scans)

## Principles
- Coordination is still built from the same primitives:
  - observe
  - decide
  - act (guarded)
  - verify

## Definition of done
- At least one multi-pane workflow exists and is safe-by-default.
- Docs/skills explain how to use wa for swarm operations.


## Success Criteria
- Coordination primitives enable multi-pane workflows safely (locks, scoped broadcasts, verification) without spamming terminals.
- Skills/docs make it easy for agents to use coordination features correctly.
- Tests cover group lock semantics and safe broadcast behavior.


## Testing
- Unit/integration tests:
  - Group lock semantics (no deadlocks, deterministic ordering).
  - Safe broadcast behavior: verify-before-act per pane and rate limiting to avoid spam.

- E2E (optional but valuable):
  - A multi-pane scenario that coordinates two dummy panes and produces artifacts proving no duplicate sends.

## Acceptance Criteria
- All items in the following sections are satisfied: Success Criteria, Definition of Done.
- All Testing requirements pass (unit/integration/E2E) with the logging/artifacts described above.
- Any explicit dependencies for this bead are implemented and validated via tests or E2E artifacts.

title: Coordination primitives: multi-pane selection, group locks, safe broadcast semantics
description:
# Task: Coordination primitives

## Goal
Define the primitives required for safe multi-pane workflows ("swarm" behavior) without turning wa into a chaos machine.

Multi-pane automation is powerful but risky: we need deterministic selection, locking, and per-pane auditing.

## Concepts
### Pane groups
- Define grouping strategies:
  - by domain
  - by inferred agent
  - by project (cwd-based)
- Group selection must be deterministic and explainable.

### Group locks
- Build on per-pane workflow locks to support multi-pane coordination:
  - lock acquisition across N panes is all-or-nothing (or explicitly partial with clear reporting)
  - timeouts and deadlock avoidance

### Safe broadcast semantics
- Observe each pane first.
- Only act on panes that pass preconditions (prompt state, no gap, not alt-screen, etc.).
- Execute actions with policy gating + rate limiting.
- Record per-pane results:
  - allowed/denied
  - verification success/failure
  - timing

## Testing strategy
- Unit tests with synthetic panes:
  - group selection and determinism
  - lock acquisition behavior
  - partial failure reporting

## Acceptance Criteria
- A workflow can target N panes and produce an auditable per-pane outcome.
- Preconditions prevent “spray and pray” broadcasting.

# Task: Unstick workflow (ast-grep integration)

## Goal
Provide a workflow that helps an agent that is stuck by running **structure-aware**, **read-only** scans and returning actionable suggestions.

The value proposition is: “when the agent doesn’t know what to do next, give it a constrained, high-signal map of likely fixes.”

## What this workflow does
Run a small, curated set of ast-grep queries such as:
- TODO/FIXME hotspots
- `unwrap()` / `expect()` / `panic!()` usage
- suspicious error handling patterns
- targeted patterns for the repo’s dominant languages (Rust first)

## Safety constraints (strict)
- Read-only only: no codemods and no file writes in v0.1.
- Do not allow arbitrary shell commands.
- If user-provided queries are supported, validate them and enforce:
  - timeouts
  - file count / file size limits
  - language whitelist

## Output contract
- Produce a structured report:
  - finding type
  - file:line
  - short snippet (bounded length)
  - suggested next action
- Human mode prints a concise summary.
- Robot mode returns a stable JSON payload.

## Testing strategy
- Fixture-based tests that:
  - run the workflow against a small fixture repo
  - assert findings are returned deterministically
  - assert no files are modified

## Acceptance Criteria
- Workflow runs ast-grep read-only and returns a concise, actionable report.
- Output is deterministic and bounded.
- Running the workflow does not modify any repository files.

title: Implement `wa why` command: explain any recent policy decision
description:
# Task: Implement `wa why` command

## Goal
Create a dedicated CLI command that explains any recent policy decision with full context.

## Why This Matters
When wa denies a send or takes unexpected action, users need to understand why. The `wa why` command provides that answer instantly without diving into logs.

## Command Interface
```bash
# Explain the most recent denial
$ wa why denied

# Explain a specific decision by ID
$ wa why denied --decision-id abc123

# Explain denial for a specific pane
$ wa why denied --pane 3

# Explain a workflow decision
$ wa why workflow-skipped --workflow handle_compaction

# JSON output for automation
$ wa why denied --pane 3 --format json
```

## Output Format
```
Decision: DENY
Type: SendText
Target: Pane 3 (claude_code @ /home/user/project)
Timestamp: 2026-01-18T14:32:01Z

Reason: Pane is in AltScreen mode
Rule: safety.alt_screen_block (severity: hard_deny)

Evidence:
  - AltScreen flag: true (detected at 14:31:55)
  - Last normal mode: 14:28:12
  - Pane title: "vim AGENTS.md"

Rationale:
  Sending input while AltScreen is active can corrupt TUI applications
  or cause unintended side effects. This is a safety guard.

To proceed:
  1. Wait for pane to exit AltScreen (close vim/less/etc.)
  2. Check pane state: wa status --pane 3
  3. If you truly need to override, use the allow-once approval flow:
     - rerun the original action to get an allow-once code
     - approve it: wa approve <code>
     - retry the action
```

## Implementation

### 1. Decision Context Storage
Extend the audit trail to store full decision context (see `wa-7wk`):
- conditions/capabilities
- rules evaluated
- determining rule
- evidence collected

### 2. Explanation Templates
Map `(rule_id, decision)` → explanation template:
```rust
struct ExplanationTemplate {
    reason: &'static str,
    rationale: &'static str,
    to_proceed: Vec<&'static str>,
}

static EXPLANATIONS: phf::Map<&str, ExplanationTemplate> = phf_map! {
    "safety.alt_screen_block:deny" => ExplanationTemplate {
        reason: "Pane is in AltScreen mode",
        rationale: "Sending input while AltScreen is active can corrupt TUI applications...",
        to_proceed: vec![
            "Wait for pane to exit AltScreen (close vim/less/etc.)",
            "Check pane state: wa status --pane {pane_id}",
            "If needed, use allow-once approvals: wa approve <code>",
        ],
    },
    // ... more templates
};
```

### 3. Query Interface
```rust
fn explain_decision(
    storage: &StorageHandle,
    decision_id: Option<&str>,
    pane_id: Option<PaneId>,
    decision_type: DecisionType,
) -> Result<Explanation, Error>;
```

### 4. CLI Integration
```rust
#[derive(Parser)]
struct WhyArgs {
    #[clap(subcommand)]
    decision_type: DecisionType,

    #[clap(long)]
    decision_id: Option<String>,

    #[clap(long)]
    pane: Option<PaneId>,

    #[clap(long, default_value = "text")]
    format: OutputFormat,
}
```

## Testing
- Unit tests: Each rule has a valid explanation template
- Integration tests: `wa why` returns expected explanations for known scenarios
- Template tests: All templates have placeholders filled correctly
- UX tests: Explanations are understandable (user testing)

## Acceptance Criteria
- `wa why denied` explains the most recent denial
- `wa why denied --pane 3` explains denial for specific pane
- All policy rules have explanation templates
- Output includes evidence, rationale, and "To proceed" steps
- JSON output is available for automation

JSON and plain text output. 1036 wa-core lib tests pass. cargo check clean.

description:
# [EPIC] Interactive Tutorial: wa learn

## Mission
Provide an in-terminal interactive tutorial system that guides new users through wa's capabilities, builds confidence, and dramatically reduces time-to-first-success.

## Why This Matters
Terminal automation tools are intimidating. Users face a steep learning curve:
- "Where do I start?"
- "What can this tool actually do?"
- "How do I know if I set it up correctly?"

An interactive tutorial transforms this experience:
- **Guided**: Step-by-step progression with clear goals
- **Safe**: Sandbox/simulation mode prevents accidents
- **Immediate**: Users see results within minutes
- **Contextual**: Tutorial adapts to user's environment

## Core Insight: Learning by Doing
Reading docs is passive. `wa learn` provides active learning:
1. User runs `wa learn`
2. Tutorial detects their environment (WezTerm running? Agents present?)
3. Presents contextual exercises with immediate feedback
4. Tracks progress across sessions

## Scope

### Core Tutorial Tracks
- **Track 1: Basics** (5 min) - What is wa? Start watching. View status.
- **Track 2: Events** (10 min) - Understanding detections. Pattern matching.
- **Track 3: Workflows** (15 min) - Automating responses. Policy gates.
- **Track 4: Robot Mode** (10 min) - Building agent integrations.
- **Track 5: Advanced** (20 min) - Custom patterns. Multi-agent coordination.

### Features
- Progress persistence (resume where left off)
- Environment detection (skip irrelevant steps)
- Sandbox mode (no real actions, simulated feedback)
- Achievement system (motivates completion)
- Help escape hatch (`wa learn --help-me` for contextual guidance)

## Success Criteria
- New user can complete Track 1 in <5 minutes
- 80% of users who start Track 1 complete Track 2
- Time-to-first-success decreases by 50%
- Support burden decreases (users self-serve)

## Testing Requirements
- Unit tests for tutorial state machine
- Integration tests for environment detection
- E2E tests for full track completion
- Golden output tests for tutorial text
- User testing with 3+ developers unfamiliar with wa

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `wa learn` command launches interactive tutorial
- [ ] 5 tracks implemented with 3-10 exercises each
- [ ] Progress persisted in ~/.config/wa/learn.json
- [ ] Sandbox mode prevents real actions
- [ ] Environment detection guides appropriate exercises
- [ ] Help escape (`wa learn --help-me`) provides context
- [ ] Tests cover all tracks and state transitions

# Environment detection for tutorial

## Purpose
Detect the user's environment to provide contextual exercises and skip irrelevant steps. A user without WezTerm running shouldn't do "start watching" exercises.

## Background
Different users have different setups:
- WezTerm running vs not
- Agents present vs empty panes
- wa configured vs fresh install
- Existing DB vs first time

The tutorial should adapt to each situation.

## Implementation Details

### Environment Checks
```rust
pub struct TutorialEnvironment {
    wezterm_running: bool,
    wezterm_version: Option<String>,
    pane_count: usize,
    agent_panes: Vec<AgentInfo>, // Panes with detected agents
    wa_configured: bool,         // wa.toml exists
    db_has_data: bool,           // Segments/events exist
    shell_integration: bool,     // OSC 133 markers detected
}

impl TutorialEnvironment {
    pub async fn detect() -> Self { ... }
    
    pub fn can_run_exercise(&self, exercise: &Exercise) -> CanRun {
        match exercise.requirements {
            Requires::WeztermRunning if !self.wezterm_running => 
                CanRun::No("Start WezTerm first"),
            Requires::AgentPresent if self.agent_panes.is_empty() => 
                CanRun::Simulation("No agents detected, using simulation"),
            _ => CanRun::Yes,
        }
    }
}
```

### Exercise Requirements
Each exercise declares its requirements:
```rust
pub struct Exercise {
    id: ExerciseId,
    title: String,
    requirements: Vec<Requirement>,
    can_simulate: bool,  // True if exercise works in sandbox mode
}
```

### Adaptive Flow
1. User starts track
2. Detect environment
3. For each exercise:
   - Check requirements
   - If met: run exercise
   - If not met but can_simulate: run in sandbox
   - If not met and can't simulate: skip with explanation

## Testing
- Unit tests for each detection check
- Mock tests for different environment states
- Integration tests with real WezTerm (optional, CI skip)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] TutorialEnvironment struct with all detection fields
- [ ] detect() function checks all conditions
- [ ] can_run_exercise() returns appropriate guidance
- [ ] Clear user messaging for skipped exercises
- [ ] Tests for all detection paths

title: Sandbox mode: simulated WezTerm and safe execution for tutorial
description:
# Sandbox mode for tutorial

## Purpose
Provide a safe, simulated environment where tutorial exercises run without affecting real panes or executing dangerous commands.

## Relationship to Simulation Mode (wa-a0c)
**IMPORTANT**: This task builds on the simulation infrastructure from wa-a0c.

The tutorial sandbox is a **pre-configured simulation scenario** that:
1. Uses `MockWezterm` from wa-a0c for pane simulation
2. Uses the scenario system from wa-a0c.3 for mock data
3. Adds tutorial-specific features (visual indicators, command hints)

This is NOT a separate mock implementation - it reuses and extends wa-a0c.

## Background
Users may:
- Not have WezTerm running
- Not have agents in their panes
- Be afraid to let tutorial "do things"

Sandbox mode addresses all these concerns by using simulation.

## Implementation Details

### Sandbox as Simulation Wrapper
```rust
pub struct TutorialSandbox {
    /// Reuses simulation infrastructure from wa-a0c
    simulation: MockWezterm,
    
    /// Tutorial-specific state
    current_exercise: Option<ExerciseId>,
    hints_shown: Vec<HintId>,
    command_log: Vec<SandboxCommand>,
}

impl TutorialSandbox {
    pub fn new() -> Self {
        // Load tutorial-specific scenario
        let scenario = Scenario::load_builtin("tutorial/sandbox.yaml").unwrap();
        let mut simulation = MockWezterm::new();
        scenario.apply_to(&simulation).unwrap();
        
        Self {
            simulation,
            current_exercise: None,
            hints_shown: vec\![],
            command_log: vec\![],
        }
    }
}
```

### Tutorial Sandbox Scenario
```yaml
# scenarios/tutorial/sandbox.yaml
name: tutorial_sandbox
description: "Pre-configured environment for wa learn exercises"

panes:
  - id: 0
    title: "Local Shell"
    domain: "local"
    cwd: "/home/user/projects"
    
  - id: 1
    title: "Codex Agent"
    domain: "local"
    agent_type: codex
    initial_content: |
      codex> Ready to help with your project.
      What would you like to work on?

  - id: 2
    title: "Claude Code"
    domain: "local"
    agent_type: claude_code
    initial_content: |
      claude> Analyzing your codebase...

# Inject events based on exercise triggers
exercise_events:
  track1_ex2:  # When user reaches this exercise
    - at: 0s
      pane: 1
      action: append
      content: |
        [Usage Warning]
        Approaching daily usage limit.
```

### Visual Indicators
- `[SANDBOX]` prefix on all output
- Distinct colors for simulated vs real
- Clear "exit sandbox" instructions
- Hint tooltips for tutorial context

### Command Logging
```rust
impl TutorialSandbox {
    pub fn execute(&mut self, cmd: &WaCommand) -> Result<String> {
        // Log for tutorial feedback
        self.command_log.push(SandboxCommand {
            command: cmd.clone(),
            timestamp: Utc::now(),
            exercise: self.current_exercise.clone(),
        });
        
        // Execute against mock
        let result = self.simulation.execute(cmd).await?;
        
        // Wrap with sandbox indicator
        Ok(format\!("[SANDBOX] {}", result))
    }
}
```

## Testing
- Unit tests verify sandbox uses simulation correctly
- Tests for tutorial-specific features (hints, logging)
- E2E tests for full sandbox flow in tutorial context

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Sandbox uses MockWezterm from wa-a0c
- [ ] Tutorial scenario provides realistic mock data
- [ ] Visual indicators clearly show sandbox mode
- [ ] Command logging tracks tutorial progress
- [ ] Exercise-triggered events work
- [ ] Tests verify integration with simulation

title: E2E script: watch-and-notify mode (--notify-only events → notifications)
description:
# E2E script: watch-and-notify mode (`wa watch --notify-only`)

## Goal
Validate end-to-end that notify-only mode:
- detects events and emits notifications
- **does not auto-handle** (no workflows run, events remain unhandled)
- respects notify filters and throttling
- includes suggested actions in notifications

This is the integration proof for notify-only mode (`wa-spi`) + notifications (`wa-psm`) under the standard E2E harness.

## Key constraints
- Deterministic: **no fixed `sleep N`**. Use bounded waits (polling with timeouts) and a quiescence detector.
- Safe shutdown: watcher processes must be stopped gracefully and reliably (SIGINT/`wa stop`), with bounded waits.
- No global config mutation: use an isolated E2E workspace/config.
- Artifacts must be redacted (no transcript leakage).

## Test setup
- Start a harness-owned mock webhook server with:
  - `/received` to read captured notifications as JSON
  - `/attempt_count` (optional)
  - request logging to artifacts
- Start WezTerm mux + dummy panes that can deterministically emit known events.
- Start `wa watch` in notify-only mode in a dedicated E2E workspace:
  - `wa watch --notify-only …`
  - notifications configured to point to the mock server

## Scenarios

### 1) Notify-only mode does not auto-handle
- Start watcher: `wa watch --notify-only --workspace <e2e> …`
- Trigger a known event that would normally be auto-handled (e.g., compaction):
  - via dummy pane output (preferred) OR a harness `wa e2e emit` helper
- Wait until mock server has ≥1 received payload (poll with timeout).
- Assertions:
  - notification payload exists and references the correct `rule_id` / pane
  - `wa events --unhandled --format json` still lists the event (still unhandled)
  - `wa workflow executions` (or DB evidence) shows **no** workflow ran for that event

### 2) Notification filter
- Start watcher with a filter:
  - `wa watch --notify-only --notify-filter "usage_limit" …`
- Trigger two events:
  - one matching filter (usage limit)
  - one non-matching (compaction)
- Wait for quiescence (bounded).
- Assert mock server received exactly one notification, for the matching event.

### 3) Throttling in notify-only mode
- Configure a low throttle budget in the E2E config.
- Trigger a burst of N events quickly (deterministic dummy output).
- Wait for quiescence (bounded).
- Assert:
  - delivered notifications ≤ configured budget
  - watcher logs contain explicit “throttled” markers for skipped notifications

### 4) Suggested action included
- Trigger compaction.
- Wait for first notification.
- Assert the notification body includes a suggested remediation (e.g., `wa workflow run handle_compaction --pane <id>`).

## Registry
- Register this case in the E2E case registry (`wa-4vx.10.20`) with prerequisites and default inclusion status.

## Artifacts
- `wa_watch_notify_only.log`
- `notifications_received.json` (redacted)
- `events_unhandled.json`
- `workflow_executions_slice.json` (or other “no workflow ran” evidence)
- `mock_server.log`

## Logging contract
Every step logs:
- case/scenario name
- watcher PID/workspace
- mock server bind address
- timeouts used

Example:
```
[NOTIFYONLY_E2E] watcher started workspace=e2e pid=12345 notify_only=true filter=usage_limit
[NOTIFYONLY_E2E] emit rule_id=codex.usage_limit_reached pane=3
[NOTIFYONLY_E2E] wait received>=1 timeout=10s
[NOTIFYONLY_E2E] assert event still unhandled: OK
```

## Testing
- Determinism:
  - no fixed sleeps
  - all waits are “wait until condition” with explicit timeouts
- Correctness:
  - notification exists and matches expected `rule_id` + `pane_id`
  - event remains unhandled (no workflow execution)
  - filter and throttling behave as configured
- Shutdown reliability:
  - stop watcher via `wa stop --workspace <e2e>` when available, otherwise SIGINT + bounded wait
  - artifacts always include watcher exit status and last log lines

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Notify-only mode delivers notifications for detected events.
- [ ] Notify-only mode does not auto-handle (events remain unhandled, no workflows executed).
- [ ] Filters and throttling work deterministically.
- [ ] Notifications include suggested actions.
- [ ] Artifacts/logs are sufficient to debug failures.

title: [EPIC] Notification System: Webhooks, Desktop Alerts, Watch-and-Notify Mode
description:
# [EPIC] Notification System

## Mission
Alert users when important events occur **without requiring constant monitoring**.

## Why This Matters
Users often run wa in the background and cannot watch constantly:
- Agent hit usage limit at 3am
- Compaction happened while in a meeting
- Critical error needs attention

Notifications bridge the gap between "always watching" and "fire and forget":
- Get alerts for what matters
- Configure thresholds and filters
- Integrate with existing notification infrastructure

## Components

### 1. Webhook Notifications
HTTP POST to configured endpoints:
```toml
[notifications.webhooks]
enabled = true

[[notifications.webhooks.endpoints]]
url = "https://hooks.slack.com/services/XXX"
events = ["codex.usage_limit_reached", "workflow.failed"]
template = "slack"

[[notifications.webhooks.endpoints]]
url = "https://discord.com/api/webhooks/XXX"
events = ["*.error", "*.usage_limit_*"]
template = "discord"
```

Payload:
```json
{
  "event_type": "codex.usage_limit_reached",
  "pane_id": 3,
  "timestamp": "2026-01-18T14:32:01Z",
  "summary": "Codex hit usage limit on Pane 3",
  "quick_fix": "wa workflow run handle_usage_limits --pane 3",
  "workspace": "/home/user/project"
}
```

### 2. Desktop Notifications
Native OS notifications:
```toml
[notifications.desktop]
enabled = true
events = ["*.error", "*.usage_limit_*", "workflow.paused"]
```

Uses:
- macOS: osascript/terminal-notifier
- Linux: notify-send
- Windows: PowerShell toast

### 3. Watch-and-Notify Mode
Run wa in background, get notifications only:
```bash
$ wa watch --background --notify
Started wa watch (PID 12345)
Notifications: desktop, webhook (Slack)
Stop with: wa stop
```

### 4. Event Filtering
Fine-grained control over which events trigger notifications:
- By event type: `codex.usage_limit_reached`
- By severity: `severity >= warning`
- By pane: `pane.agent = codex`
- By glob: `*.error`, `workflow.*`

### 5. Notification Throttling
Prevent notification spam:
- Rate limit per event type
- Aggregate similar events
- Quiet hours support

## Configuration
```toml
[notifications]
enabled = true
throttle_minutes = 5

[notifications.filters]
include = ["*.error", "*.usage_limit_*", "workflow.paused"]
exclude = ["*.debug"]

[notifications.desktop]
enabled = true

[notifications.webhooks]
enabled = true
```

## Testing
- Unit tests: Filter matching, payload generation
- Integration tests: Webhook delivery (mock server)
- E2E tests: Desktop notification trigger

## Success Criteria
- Webhooks deliver to configured endpoints reliably
- Desktop notifications work on macOS/Linux
- Filters allow fine-grained control
- Throttling prevents notification spam

## Acceptance Criteria
- Webhook and desktop notifications can be enabled per config.
- Filtering and throttling prevent notification spam.
- Failures are logged without breaking core workflows.
- wa-psm.4 tests pass.

title: Webhook notification delivery: HTTP POST with configurable templates
description:
# Webhook Notification Delivery

## Purpose
Deliver event notifications to external services via HTTP webhooks.

## Configuration
```toml
[[notifications.webhooks.endpoints]]
url = "https://hooks.slack.com/services/XXX"
events = ["codex.usage_limit_reached", "workflow.failed"]
template = "slack"
```

## Payload Templates

### Generic
```json
{
  "event_type": "codex.usage_limit_reached",
  "pane_id": 3,
  "timestamp": "2026-01-18T14:32:01Z",
  "summary": "Codex hit usage limit on Pane 3",
  "quick_fix": "wa workflow run handle_usage_limits --pane 3",
  "workspace": "/home/user/project"
}
```

### Slack
```json
{
  "text": "wa: Codex hit usage limit",
  "blocks": [...]
}
```

### Discord
```json
{
  "content": null,
  "embeds": [{"title": "wa: Codex hit usage limit", ...}]
}
```

## Implementation
```rust
pub struct WebhookNotifier {
    client: reqwest::Client,
    endpoints: Vec<WebhookEndpoint>,
    circuit_breaker: CircuitBreaker,
}

impl WebhookNotifier {
    pub async fn notify(&self, event: &Event) -> Result<()> {
        for endpoint in &self.endpoints {
            if endpoint.matches(event) {
                let payload = endpoint.template.render(event);
                self.deliver(endpoint.url, payload).await?;
            }
        }
        Ok(())
    }
}
```

## Reliability
- Retry with exponential backoff
- Circuit breaker per endpoint

title: Event filtering and throttling: pattern matching and rate limiting
description:
# Event Filtering and Throttling

## Purpose
Control which events trigger notifications and prevent notification spam.

## Event Filtering

### Pattern Syntax
```
*.error              # All error events
codex.*              # All codex events
workflow.failed      # Specific event
severity >= warning  # By severity
pane.agent = codex   # By pane attribute
```

### Configuration
```toml
[notifications.filters]
include = ["*.error", "*.usage_limit_*", "workflow.paused"]
exclude = ["*.debug", "test.*"]
```

### Implementation
```rust
pub struct EventFilter {
    include: Vec<GlobPattern>,
    exclude: Vec<GlobPattern>,
}

impl EventFilter {
    pub fn matches(&self, event: &Event) -> bool {
        let type_matches = self.include.iter().any(|p| p.matches(&event.event_type));
        let excluded = self.exclude.iter().any(|p| p.matches(&event.event_type));
        type_matches && !excluded
    }
}
```

## Throttling

### Rate Limiting
```toml
[notifications]
throttle_minutes = 5  # Max 1 notification per event type per 5 min
```

### Aggregation
When multiple similar events occur within throttle window:
```
"3 usage limit events in last 5 minutes (Panes 1, 3, 7)"
```

### Quiet Hours
```toml
[notifications.quiet_hours]
enabled = true
start = "22:00"
end = "08:00"
timezone = "America/Los_Angeles"
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Glob pattern matching works
- [ ] Severity filtering works
- [ ] Rate limiting prevents spam
- [ ] Aggregation groups similar events
- [ ] Quiet hours respected

description:
# Phase 5: Advanced Features

## Overview
This epic covers advanced capabilities that provide significant value but aren't strictly necessary for v0.1.0. These features differentiate wa from simpler monitoring tools and lay groundwork for future multi-machine orchestration.

## Strategic Importance
Phase 5 features enable:
- Higher performance through selective vendoring
- Real-time responsiveness through output streaming
- Fleet-scale coordination through multi-agent features
- Long-term maintainability through optimization and documentation

## Key Components

### 1. Selective WezTerm Vendoring

#### Analysis
| Approach | Pros | Cons |
|----------|------|------|
| CLI Only | Simple, stable | Limited capabilities, subprocess overhead |
| Lua IPC | Event-driven, rich data | Requires user config modification |
| Full Vendor | Maximum capability | Maintenance burden, version tracking |
| Selective Vendor | Best of both worlds | Careful design required |

#### Implementation
\`\`\`toml
[dependencies]
wezterm-mux-proto = { git = "https://github.com/wez/wezterm", optional = true }
wezterm-term = { git = "https://github.com/wez/wezterm", optional = true }

[features]
default = []
vendored = ["wezterm-mux-proto", "wezterm-term"]
\`\`\`

DirectMuxClient for zero-copy scrollback access
UnifiedClient that uses best available method
Version compatibility checking

### 2. Real-Time Output Streaming
With vendoring enabled:
- Subscribe to pane output events
- Eliminate polling latency entirely
- Lower CPU usage
- Foundation for responsive UIs

### 3. Multi-Agent Coordination Features

#### Cross-Session Communication
- Pane-to-pane messaging primitives
- Shared state for coordinated workflows
- Dependency-aware task distribution

#### Distributed Mode (Optional)
Mode A (Single-node): wa runs on workstation, connects to all domains
Mode B (Distributed): wa-agent runs near each mux server

\`\`\`
┌─────────────────┐     ┌─────────────────┐
│   Workstation   │     │   dev-server    │
│  wa-aggregator  │◄────│    wa-agent     │
│  (central)      │     │   (local tail)  │
└─────────────────┘     └─────────────────┘
\`\`\`

Benefits:
- Lower latency (local capture)
- Fewer bytes (only deltas over wire)
- Isolation (one domain failing doesn't stall all)

### 4. Performance Optimization Pass

#### Targets
- Quick reject: < 1μs for typical non-matching text
- Pattern engine: < 1ms for full detection
- FTS query: < 50ms for common queries
- Watcher loop: < 100μs per pane check when idle

#### Benchmarks
\`\`\`rust
#[bench]
fn bench_quick_reject_no_match(b: &mut Bencher) {
    let engine = PatternEngine::new();
    let boring = "ls -la\ndrwxr-xr-x...".repeat(100);
    b.iter(|| black_box(engine.detect(&boring)));
}
\`\`\`

#### Memory Optimization
- LRU cache for output hashes
- Rolling hashes per pane
- Prune old entries

### 5. Documentation and skills.md
- Complete README with architecture overview
- CONTRIBUTING.md for new contributors
- API documentation for all public interfaces
- skills.md for AI agent integration
- Workflow specification docs

### 6. Observability Enhancements

#### Health Model
\`wa status --health --format json\` reports:
- wezterm: cli_ok, mux_ok, vendored_ok
- ingest: lag_max_ms, lag_avg_ms, panes_tracked
- event_bus: queue depths
- storage: db_writable, wal_pages, last_checkpoint
- workflows: active count, oldest_running_ms

#### Prometheus Metrics (optional)
\`wa watch --metrics :9464\`
- wa_ingest_deltas_total
- wa_ingest_lag_ms_bucket
- wa_pattern_detections_total
- wa_workflow_runs_total
- wa_db_write_latency_ms_bucket

#### Diagnostic Bundle
\`wa diag bundle --last 15m\` produces tarball with:
- Config (redacted)
- Version matrix
- Recent events
- Gap summary
- Health snapshot

### 7. Fuzzing
cargo-fuzz targets:
- Pattern pack parsing (malformed TOML)
- Regex extractors (pathological patterns)
- OSC marker parsing (invalid escapes)
- FTS queries (malformed queries)

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Vendored build provides real-time streaming
- [ ] Performance benchmarks meet budgets
- [ ] Multi-agent coordination works for 2+ agents
- [ ] Documentation is complete and accurate
- [ ] Observability provides full visibility
- [ ] Fuzzing finds no crashes

## Dependencies
- Depends on Phase 1-4 (all prior work)

## Definition of Done for v0.1.0
wa is "meaningfully real" when:
- [ ] It continuously captures pane output and can search it with FTS
- [ ] It detects at least the primary patterns reliably
- [ ] It can run handle_compaction safely end-to-end
- [ ] It can run handle_usage_limits for Codex end-to-end
- [ ] It exposes robot mode + MCP so an agent can operate it
- [ ] It has documentation sufficient for another developer
- [ ] It passes CI (lint, test, build) on every commit

description:
# [EPIC] CLI Polish

## Mission
Make the wa CLI feel **polished and professional**—the kind of tool where attention to detail builds trust.

## Why This Matters
CLI UX is cumulative. Many small improvements add up to a tool that feels delightful:
- Tab completion → fewer typos, faster navigation
- Smart aliases → muscle memory efficiency
- Progressive disclosure → clean by default, detailed on request
- Consistent patterns → predictable behavior

## Components

### 1. Shell Completions
Full tab completion for all commands:
```bash
$ wa <TAB>
watch    status   events   send     workflow   ...

$ wa send --pane <TAB>
1 (codex @ /home/user/project)
3 (claude @ /home/user/other)

$ wa workflow run <TAB>
handle_compaction    handle_usage_limits    handle_auth_required
```

Implementation:
- clap derives completions for bash/zsh/fish/powershell
- Dynamic completions for pane IDs, workflow names
- `wa completions bash > ~/.bash_completion.d/wa`

### 2. Smart Aliases
Built-in short forms for common operations:
```bash
was     → wa status
wae     → wa events --unhandled
waq     → wa query
waw     → wa watch
wat     → wa timeline
```

Also support user-defined aliases in config.

### 3. Progressive Disclosure
Output verbosity levels:
- Default: Essential info only
- `-v`: Additional context
- `-vv`: Debug details
- `--format json`: Machine-readable (stable schema; intended for scripts/automation)

Notes:
- `-v/-vv` controls *how much* information we include.
- `--format {auto|plain|json}` controls *how* we render it (TTY-rich vs stable plain vs machine JSON).

Example:
```bash
$ wa status
Panes: 4 observed, 1 ignored
Events: 2 unhandled

$ wa status -v
Panes:
  1: codex [PromptActive] /home/user/project (last: 2m ago)
  3: claude [CommandRunning] /home/user/other (last: 5s ago)
  ...

Events (unhandled):
  - codex.usage_limit_reached (Pane 1, 2m ago)
  - session.compaction (Pane 3, 5m ago)
```

### 4. Consistent Help Patterns
Every command has:
- `--help`: Usage and options
- `-h`: Brief usage
- Examples in help text
- Cross-references to related commands

```bash
$ wa send --help
wa send - Send text to a pane

USAGE:
    wa send --pane <ID> [OPTIONS] <TEXT>

OPTIONS:
    --pane <ID>      Target pane ID (required)
    --dry-run        Preview without executing
    --wait-for <PAT> Wait for pattern after send
    --timeout <SEC>  Wait timeout (default: 30)

EXAMPLES:
    wa send --pane 3 "hello"
    wa send --pane 3 --dry-run "hello"
    wa send --pane 3 --wait-for ">>>" "continue"

SEE ALSO:
    wa status       List available panes
    wa why          Explain send failures
```

### 5. Output Consistency
All commands follow the same patterns:
- Success: Clean output, exit 0
- Error: Error message with remediation, exit 1
- JSON mode: Structured output with envelope
- No ANSI when piped

## Testing
- Completion tests: Verify completions are generated correctly
- Alias tests: Aliases resolve to correct commands
- Output tests: Progressive disclosure works as expected
- Help tests: All commands have valid help text

## Success Criteria
- Tab completion works for all commands and dynamic values
- Aliases are documented and work as expected
- Output verbosity is consistent across all commands
- Help text is comprehensive and includes examples

## Acceptance Criteria
- Shell completions are generated and kept in sync with CLI.
- Aliases and verbosity levels behave consistently.
- Help output follows a unified style across commands.
- wa-rnf.5 tests pass.


## Testing
- Unit: clap completion generation + alias expansion + verbosity routing.
- Snapshot/contract: help output + non-TTY no-ANSI checks; JSON output schema validation.
- CI: smoke tests ensure generated completions and help text remain in sync.
